questions.text: What is the most common inflammatory myopathy in children?
questions.solution:
Dermatomyositis is the most common inflammatory myopathy in children.

Two types of dermatomyositis are known—juvenile and adult.

  Juvenile dermatomyositis Adult dermatomyositis
Age of onset  7 years 4th to 6th decade
Common associations

Calcinosis

Lipodystrophy

Cardiac and lung involvement

Underlying malignancy (15-25%)

Myositis-specific antibodies
Prognosis Better Worse

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented with left-sided nasal blockage and discharge for 3 years. Endoscopy revealed a pale, polypoidal mass arising from the nasal mucosa of the lateral wall of the nose, as shown in the image below. Biopsy from the mass showed a hyperplastic papillomatous tissue growing into the stroma. Which of the following statements is false about the management of the condition?

choices.text: Endoscopic medial maxillectomy can be tried.
MRI helps in localizing the extent of the lesion.
Radiotherapy is the preferred line of management.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the endoscopic image are suggestive of inverted papilloma. The false statement about this condition is that radiotherapy is the preferred line of management. Radiotherapy is avoided as it may induce malignancy.

Inverted papilloma (Ringertz tumor or transitional cell papilloma or Schneiderian papilloma) is a benign neoplasm of the non-olfactory mucosa of the nose (also called the Schneiderian membrane) and paranasal sinuses.

The lateral wall of the nose in the middle meatus is the most common site of origin. The hyperplastic papillomatous tissue grows into the stroma. It is common in the 4th to 7th decades of life, with a male preponderance. It is almost always unilateral and presents with unilateral nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and epistaxis. 
 
It can invade sinuses and the orbit; invasion of the latter causes proptosis, diplopia, and lacrimation.
 
On inspection or endoscopy of the nose, the papilloma presents as a polypoidal mass resembling simple nasal polyps, as depicted by arrows in the endoscopic image above. A CT scan and/or MRI scan show the location and extent of the lesion, and the latter differentiates the sinus secretions from the actual tumor mass. A biopsy is essential for diagnosis. Histology shows a thin respiratory epithelium overlying the surface and an underlying stroma containing multiple nodules of thick neoplastic epithelium growing inward. 
 
Medial maxillectomy is the treatment of choice, preferably done via endoscopy. Recurrence is common and malignancy has been observed in up to 15% of the cases.

Related Pearl: Inverted Papilloma

Inverted papilloma is also known as transitional cell papilloma or Ringertz tumor or Schneiderian papilloma. It is a common benign tumour of the paranasal sinuses. It is a premalignant condition with 10-15% chances of turning malignant.

Etiology: Human papillomavirus has been implicated in its etiology.

Origin: Arises from the lateral wall of the nose from the non-olfactory epithelium of the nose

Clinical features:

  • More common in men.
  • Predominance between 40-70 years.
  • Unilateral nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and epistaxis are the main presenting symptoms
  • It is a locally invasive tumor and can invade orbit and paranasal sinuses.
  • Proptosis, diplopia, and lacrimation can result from orbital invasion

Findings: It is seen as a pale polypoidal mass resembling a simple nasal polyp.

Investigations: A biopsy is needed for diagnosis.

Treatment: Medial maxillectomy via lateral rhinotomy or midfacial degloving approach. Radiotherapy can lead to malignancy.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man  came to the hospital with complaints of progressive swelling of his legs. On examination, you note bilateral non-pitting edema of the lower limbs with thickening of the overlying skin. Which of the following is the infective form of the given parasite to man?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of lymphatic filariasis (elephantiasis). Lymphatic filariasis is caused by Wuchereria bancrofti and Brugia malayi. For both of them, the infective form to man is third stage filariform larva.

The image given below shows the life cycle of W. bancrofti:

Elephantiasis is a delayed sequel to repeated lymphangitis, obstruction, and lymphedema. Repeated leakage of lymph into tissues first results in lymphedema, then elephantiasis.

Diethylcarbamazine is the drug of choice.

questions.text: A 17-month-old girl presented with abnormal vaginal bleeding. A gynecological examination showed abnormal vaginal tissue protruding through the introitus. Histopathological analysis showed sheets of spindled cells in a myxoid stroma, which stained positive for desmin and Myo-D1. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of sarcoma botryoids, which is a variant of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma. It is a malignant mesenchymal tumor with skeletal muscle differentiation. 

Rhabdomyosarcomas are the common soft tissue sarcomas of childhood and adolescence, classified into four subtypes: alveolar, embryonal, pleomorphic, and spindle-shaped/ sclerosing.

  • Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma: It contains sheets of both primitive round and spindled cells in a myxoid stroma. Sarcoma botryoids is a variant that occurs in the walls of hollow, mucosal-lined structures, such as the nasopharynx, common bile duct, bladder, and vagina.
  • Alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma: consists of the network of fibrous septae that divide the cells into clusters or aggregates, creating a crude resemblance to pulmonary alveoli. 
  • Pleomorphic rhabdomyosarcoma - consists of large, sometimes multinucleated, bizarre eosinophilic tumor cells.
  • Spindle cell/sclerosing rhabdomyosarcoma - Consists of fusiform cells with vesicular chromatin arranged in long fascicles or in a storiform pattern.

On immunohistochemistry, they are positive for desmin, myoglobin, myogenin, MyoD1, and vimentin. Pleomorphic rhabdomyosarcoma is seen predominantly in adults.

The botryoid variant of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma has the best prognosis, while the pleomorphic subtype is often fatal.

questions.text: Identify the illumination system in the image below.
questions.solution:
Illumination system/ light source of microscope is marked as 2 in the image. It is a steady light source used in place of a mirror.

1 is objective lens. There are usually 3 or 4 objective lenses on a microscope. They almost always consist of 4X, 10X, 40X and 100X powers.

3 is coarse focusing knob. It moves the body tubes with its lenses.

4 is condenser. The purpose of the condenser lens is to focus the light onto the specimen.

questions.text: A patient with long standing liver cirrhosis presents with renal dysfunction and is suspected to have hepatorenal syndrome. Which of the following statements regarding its management is true?

choices.text: Treatment involves concomitant liver and renal transplant
Definitive treatment of this condition is renal transplant
Recovery of kidney function can occur spontaneously post liver transplantation
Terlipressin has no role in management of this condition

questions.solution:
Renal function can recover spontaneously in cases of hepatorenal syndrome (HRS) after a liver transplantation. 

Hepatorenal syndrome is a progressive renal failure in patients with acute or chronic liver disease. The diagnostic criteria for hepatorenal syndrome include:

  • Cirrhosis with ascites
  • Diagnosis of acute kidney injury (AKI)
    • Increase in serum creatinine of ≥ 0.3mg/dL in 48 hours, OR
    • 50% increase in serum creatinine from baseline within 7 days
  • Absence of shock
  • No evidence of recent use of nephrotoxic agents
  • Absence of intrinsic renal disease
  • Other criteria that also apply:
    • Urine red cell excretion of fewer than 50 cells per high power field (when no urinary catheter is in place) and protein excretion less than 500 mg/day
    • Lack of improvement in kidney function after volume expansion with intravenous albumin (1 g/kg of body weight per day up to 100 g/day) for at least two days and withdrawal of diuretics

Management of hepatorenal syndrome includes:

  • Norepinephrine
  • Octreotide
  • Terlipressin (Option D)
  • Midodrine
  • Intravenous albumin 
  • Liver transplantation - definitive treatment

Renal transplantation (Options A and B) is not indicated in HRS.

questions.text:
In a village with 200 eligible couples, family planning data of contraceptive methods is as follows:

Vasectomy – 30 Tubectomy – 30 IUD users – 12 Oral pill users – 30 Condom users – 18

What is the couple protection rate in the village?
questions.solution:
Couple protection rate (CPR) is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.

In this scenario, a total of 120 couples out of 200 eligible couples are using contraceptive methods.

Therefore, CPR = (120/200) x 100 = 60% 

Eligible couple: It refers to a currently married couple, wherein the wife is at the reproductive age, which is generally assumed to lie between the ages 15 and 45 years.

Related Pearl: Pearl index and couple protection rate:

Pearl Index is defined as the number of contraceptive failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).

  • In this formula, the total accidental pregnancies that are used as the numerator must include every known conception, irrespective of its outcome.
  • In the denominator, total months of exposure is obtained by deducting, 10 months for full-term deliveries and 4 months for abortion, from the total period under review.

Couple Protection Rate:

  • It is an indicator of couple protection practice in the community.
  • It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.
  • Attaining a 60% CPR would mean restricting all third or higher-order births.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of Virchow's triad?
questions.solution:
Hyperviscosity is not part of Virchow’s triad. However, hyperviscosity states as in polycythemia vera may, in turn, cause small vessel stasis that may cause thrombosis.

Virchow's triad in thrombosis:

  1. Injury to endothelial cells can alter local blood flow and affect coagulability.
  2. Abnormal blood flow (stasis or turbulence), in turn, can cause endothelial injury.
  3. Hypercoagulability of blood

These factors may promote thrombosis independently or in combination.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents with an excessive desire for sexual intercourse. What is this called?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a man with an excessive desire for sexual intercourse is suggestive of satyriasis. 

Satyriasis refers to uncontrollable or excessive sexual desire (hypersexuality) in males. It is also known as Don Juanism. Don Juan is a legendary, fictional libertine who devoted his life to seducing women.

In patients with this condition, sexual activity is usually a means to mask their deep feelings of inferiority. Some patients may have unconscious homosexual impulses, which they deny through compulsive sexual contact with women. They are usually not interested in women after sex.

Other options: 

Option B: Frotteurism is a form of paraphilic disorder, wherein the affected male achieves sexual gratification by rubbing his penis against the buttocks or other body parts of a fully clothed woman, usually in crowded places.

Option C: Nymphomania refers to excessive sexual desire or hypersexuality in women. It is a form of sexual addiction. 

Option D: Sexual masochism is a form of paraphilia, wherein the individual has sexual fantasies or urges that involve acts of being beaten, bound, or humiliated. It is more commonly seen in men.

questions.text: Anaplerosis is the process of refilling the catalytic intermediates of the citric acid cycle that carry acetyl CoA as it gets oxidized. All of the following are anaplerotic reactions, except _____.

choices.text: Conversion of succinyl CoA to heme
Conversion of propionyl CoA to succinyl CoA

questions.solution:
Conversion of succinyl CoA to heme is not an anaplerotic reaction. It is an example of a cataplerotic reaction.

The anaplerotic process is the replenishment of the intermediates of the citric acid (Krebs) cycle to replace the catalytic processes and to ensure the continuation of the cycle.

The most important anaplerotic reaction is the carboxylation of pyruvate to oxaloacetate, which is catalyzed by pyruvate carboxylase. This reaction is important to maintain an adequate concentration of oxaloacetate for the condensation reaction with acetyl-CoA. On accumulation, acetyl-CoA acts as an allosteric activator of pyruvate carboxylase and an inhibitor of pyruvate dehydrogenase, thereby providing an adequate supply of oxaloacetate.

Other anaplerotic reactions:

  • Glutamate and glutamine to α-ketoglutarate, a reaction catalyzed by glutamate dehydrogenase and glutaminase, respectively
  • Compounds that produce propionyl CoA can be then carboxylated and isomerized to succinyl CoA.
  • Transamination of aspartate to form oxaloacetate.
  • Pyruvate can be carboxylated to malate.

The cataplerotic process is the metabolism of the citric acid cycle intermediates that leave the cycle and participate in the biosynthesis of other compounds. These processes are required to redirect citrate toward fatty acid synthesis; succinyl CoA to heme synthesis, malate to gluconeogenesis; and α-ketoglutarate to amino acid synthesis, purine synthesis, and neurotransmitter synthesis.

Related Pearl: Steps involved in TCA cycle

Step 1

Acetyl CoA + Oxaloacetate → Citrate

     (2C  + 4C  =   6C)

Enzyme: Citrate Synthase

Irreversible, Exothermic reaction
Step 2

Citrate → Cis –aconitate  → Isocitrate 

( 6C    →          6C →             6C)

Enzyme:   Aconitase

Cofactor:   Fe2+

The Reaction occurs in 2 steps:         

1st step:  Dehydration      

2nd step:  Rehydration

Inhibited by: Fluoroacetate (Non- Competitive)
Step 3

Isocitrate →[Oxalosuccinate]→α- Keto glutarate

        (6C) →         [6C]         →         (5C)

Enzyme:  Isocitrate Dehydrogenase

Cofactor:   Mn2+ or Mg2+

Reaction:  Oxidative  Decarboxylation

Intermediate:   Oxalosuccinate [ Unstable]

Release:    1 NADH and CO2
Step 4

α- Keto glutarate → Succcinyl Co A 

       (5C             →         4C)

Enzyme: α- Ketoglutarate Dehydrogenase(Multienzyme complex)

Reaction:  Oxidative Decarboxylation

Inhibited by: Arsenite  (Non – Competitive)

Physiologically unidirectional step.

Release: 1 NADH and CO2
Step 5

Succinyl- CoA  → Succinate

      ( 4C          →         4C )

Enzyme:  Succinate Thiokinase

Cofactor: Mg2+

Release:  1 ATP / GTP

Substrate level phosphorylation
Step 6

Succinate  →   Fumarate

( 4C          →         4C )

Enzyme:  Succinate Dehydrogenase (Part of 2nd complex ETC)

Cofactor:  FAD and Fe-S protein 

The only enzyme of TCA cycle attached to the inner mitochondrial membrane.

Inhibited by: Malonate ( competitive)

Release: FADH2
Step 7

Fumarate  →   Malate

( 4C         →     4C )

Enzyme:  Fumarate Hydratase

Reaction: Hydration
Step 8

Malate  →  Oxaloacetate  

( 4C     →        4C )

Enzyme:  Malate Dehydrogenase

Release:  1 NADH

Oxaloacetate is regenerated.

questions.text: A woman is admitted to the antenatal ward at 35 weeks. Her BP is 170/110 mmHg and her urine dipstick is 3+. She developed a generalized seizure attack during the examination.  What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Give a 4 g bolus of MgSO4 by slow IV injection
Give a 40 mg bolus IV injection of labetalol

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is that of a patient with eclampsia, where the first step of treatment is the management of the airway and prevent aspiration.

The immediate measures in the medical management of eclampsia include the following steps:

  • Call for extra help (Communication)
  • To put the patient in a left lateral recumbent position
  • Maintain oral airway
  • O2 inhalation – non-rebreather mask; 10 L/minute
  • Commence IV lines; 1 or 2 wide bore cannulas
  • Catheterize the patient with a foley's catheter and an urometer
  • To monitor O2 saturation; pulse oximeter (SPO2 >95%)
  • Control of seizures: MgSO4 (IV/IM regimens)
  • To monitor vitals; fetal status and magnesium toxicity
  • Control of hypertension: Labetalol, Hydralazine
  • Fluids: Crystalloids (saline) or colloids (albumin/blood) <125 mL/h
  • Oropharyngeal suction
  • Diuretics administration for pulmonary edema, if present

MgSO4 regimens:

Regimen Loading Dose Maintenance Dose
Intramuscular (Pritchard) 4 g (20% solution) IV over 3-5 minute
followed by 10 g (5O%), deep IM
(5 g in each buttock)		 5 g (5O%) IM 4 hourly in the alternate buttock
Intravenous (Zuspan or Sibai) 4g IV slow over 15-20 minute 1-2 g/h IV infusion

 

Delivery of the fetus resolves eclampsia. In most cases, labor sets in with antepartum eclampsia. If labor does not start and the seizures are controlled, a mature baby is vaginally delivered by induction of labor. If the baby is premature, steroids are given(<34 weeks) and delivery is conducted with an NICU setup.

If the seizures are not controlled for 6-8 hours, delivery is conducted by induction of labor and by shortening the duration of the second stage of labor. In case of obstetric contraindications for a vaginal delivery, a cesarean section should be done to deliver the fetus.

questions.text: You are tasked with holding a public service announcement about the benefits of getting vaccinated, at a small town of farmers. You want to deliver some statistical data to encourage vaccination. Which of the following is the best way to do so?
questions.solution:
A pictogram is the best method of presenting data to uneducated populations or people who cannot understand orthodox charts. 

In this method, small pictures or symbols are used to present the data. Fractions of the picture can be used to represent numbers smaller than the value of a whole symbol. Basically, pictograms are a form of bar charts.

The following image shows an example of a pictogram.

Once collected, statistical data must be arranged such that the relevant points are clearly presented. The various tools used to depict statistical data include tables, charts, diagrams, graphs, and pictures.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following image shows a histogram.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: In a school of 100 children, a child developed measles. Four days later, 3 of her classmates developed measles. What do these intervening four days correspond to?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the first child is the primary case and her classmates are the secondary cases. Hence, the interval between them developing the disease i.e., the intervening four days, is called the serial interval.

The time interval between the onset of the primary case and the secondary case is called serial interval.

By collecting information about a whole series of such disease onsets, the distribution of the secondary cases can be made. From this information, an approximation of the incubation period can be done.

Lead time/lead interval refers to the period between the first possible time of detection and the usual time of diagnosis.

Incubatory interval/ incubation period refers to the time period between invasion of a pathogen to appearance of the first sign or symptom.

Latent interval/ latent period refers to the period between disease initiation to detection of the disease. It is usually used for non-infectious diseases and is equivalent to the incubation period. 

Note :

  • Primary case is the first case of a communicable disease introduced into a population unit.  
  • Secondary case is one that develops after contact with the primary case.
  • Index case is the first case that comes to the notice of an investigator or physician.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy with intellectual disability was brought for psychiatric evaluation. His IQ was found to be 45. He also had mitral valve prolapse and macroorchidism. What is the genetic defect associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient has moderate intellectual disability, large ears, long face, and mitral valve prolapse. These findings are seen in fragile X syndrome.

Fragile X syndrome is caused by the X-linked loss of function mutation of the FMR1 gene. This is due to the unstable expansion of trinucleotide CGG base repeats.

Clinical features of fragile X syndrome:

  • Hyperactivity, inattention, anxiety
  • Speech and language delays
  • IQ decline
  • Gaze aversion, social avoidance, shyness
  • Learning disorder in some females; mild intellectual disability in affected females
  • Moderate to severe intellectual disability in males
  • Verbal IQ > performance IQ

Signs:

  • Long face
  • Large ears
  • Midface hypoplasia
  • High-arched palate
  • Short stature
  • Macroorchidism
  • Mitral valve prolapse (mid-systolic click after S1, may be followed by a late systolic crescendo–decrescendo murmur)
  • Joint laxity
  • Strabismus

Other options:

Option A: Trisomy 21 refers to Down's syndrome. Features of this condition include upward slanted palpebral fissure, flat wide nasal bridge, simian crease, etc. along with hyperactivity in childhood, verbal > auditory processing defect, an increased risk of depression, and dementia of the Alzheimer type in adulthood.

Option B: Partial deletion of 5p refers to cri-du chat syndrome. Features include round face with hypertelorism, epicanthal folds, slanting palpebral fissure, low-set ears, micrognathia along with an infant-like cry.

Option C: Deletion of 15q12 of paternal origin refers to Prader-Willi syndrome. This condition is characterized by obesity, microorchidism, cryptorchidism, almond-shaped eyes, prominent forehead, and bitemporal narrowing.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man living in Nellore, Andhra Pradesh, comes to the OPD with difficulty in walking. Oral examination reveals the following. Crippling permanent disability occurs when the concentration of the offending agent exceeds _____.
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the image given above are indicative of fluorosis. Permanent disability/crippling fluorosis occurs when the concentration exceeds 10 mg/L.

Fluorosis occurs when drinking water contains excess amounts of fluorine, in the range of 3–5 mg/L. It is endemic in parts of India- Andhra Pradesh, Punjab, Haryana, Karnataka, Kerala, Tamil Nadu. 

Symptoms correspond to levels of fluoride intake:

  • Dental fluorosis: (1.5 mg/L) Occurs if excess fluoride is ingested during the period of tooth calcification, i.e. in the first 7 years of life. It causes mottling on dental enamel, the appearance of chalky-white patches on the teeth, and loss of shine in the early stages. The white spots progressively turn yellow and can even become brown-black. The loss of enamel gives a corroded appearance. 
  • Skeletal fluorosis: (3-6 mg/L) Occurs due to the heavy deposition of fluoride in the skeleton. Fluorosis stimulates osteoblastic activity, fluorapatite crystals are laid down in bone and these are usually resistant to secondary osteoclastic resorption. This leads to calcium retention, osteosclerosis, and osteophytosis. Ossification of ligaments and fascial attachments is characteristic.
  • Crippling fluorosis: (>10 mg/L) Can lead to permanent disability. 

Genu valgum and osteoporosis of the lower limb are seen in a newer form of fluorosis. It is seen in people consuming jowar (sorghum), as it promotes greater retention of ingested fluoride.

Interventions for Fluorosis: 

  • Change the drinking water source with a lower fluoride content (0.5 to 0.8 mg/L). 
  • Nalgonda technique is used for the defluoridation of water; it involves the addition of lime and alum followed by flocculation, sedimentation, and filtration.
  • Fluoride supplements should not be prescribed for children who drink fluoridated water.
  • The use of fluoride toothpaste in areas of endemic fluorosis is not recommended for children up to 6 years of age.

questions.text: Given below are the four causes of abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) with the corresponding class of a PALM-COEIN classification. Which is incorrectly matched?
questions.solution:
Polycystic ovarian disease is an ovarian cause of abnormal uterine bleeding which comes under AUB-O, in the PALM-COEIN classification.

AUB in the reproductive age group was previously known as dysfunctional uterine bleeding, however, that term is now obsolete. AUB can be acute or chronic:

  • Acute AUB - it can start sporadically or be superimposed on chronic AUB
  • Chronic AUB - it lasts for 6 months (3 months minimum)

PALM-COEIN classification of AUB:

  • Polyp (AUB-P):
    • Endometrial polyps
    • Endocervical polyps
  • Adenomyosis (AUB-A)
  • Leiomyoma (AUB-L). Fibroids are further classified as:
    • Submucosal (SM)
    • Other (O)
  • Malignancy and hyperplasia (AUB-M) 
    • Endometrial hyperplasia 
    • Endometrial carcinoma
  • Coagulopathy (AUB-C)
    • von Willebrand's disease
    • Hemophilias
  • Ovarian causes (AUB-O)
    • PCOD
    • Hypothyroidism
    • Hyperprolactinemia.  
  • Endometrial causes (AUB-E)
    • Tubercular or chlamydial endometritis 
  • Iatrogenic causes (AUB-I)
    • Intrauterine contraceptive devices
    • Anticoagulants
    • Tricyclic antidepressants
  • Not yet classified (AUB-N) includes rare causes such as
    • Arteriovenous malformations 
    • Myometrial hypertrophy

questions.text: Which of the following fungi shows the phenomenon shown below?
questions.solution:
The image shows germ tube formation (also known as the Reynolds Braude phenomenon), which is seen in Candida albicans.

If a few colonies of Candida albicans are inoculated in serum, the yeast cells start to form elongations called germ tubes within 2 hours, when kept at 37 °C.

It is also positive for a relatively new characterized species, Candida dubliniensis.

It is negative in Candida glabrata.

Candida is the most common cause of opportunistic mycoses in the world. Morphologically, they are yeast-like fungi. They exist as yeast and pseudohyphae (buds do not separate from parent cells) and true hyphae forms.

Candida appears as budding gram-positive cells on wet films and smears. Mycelial forms suggest colonization. On Sabouraud dextrose agar, they appear as off-white pasty colonies. Candida albicans, the most commonly implicated pathogenic species form chlamydospores on corn meal agar.

The image below shows candidal hyphae and chlamydospores.

After incubation on CHROMagar for 1–4 days, colonies are seen: Candida albicans colonies appear green, as shown below; Candida glabrata colonies appear dark purple; Candida parapsilosis colonies have a pinkish hue.

The most common species implicated in candidal infections are C. albicans, C. parapsilosis, and C. glabrata. Vaginal mucosal invasion by the organism causes vulvovaginitis, marked by pruritus and vaginal discharge. A white pseudomembranous patchy lesion called thrush can occur on the tongue, lips, or gums.

The image given below shows oral thrush.

Immunocompromised individuals are at an increased risk of systemic candidiasis, which includes candidal endocarditis and urinary tract infections.

Mucocutaneous manifestations are managed with topical nystatin or oral ketoconazole.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: The sinus shown in the image opens into the ______.
questions.solution:
The structure shown in the image is the frontal sinus. It drains into the middle meatus.

The frontal sinus is the most superiorly located sinus. It is situated between the inner and outer tables of the frontal bone, above and deep to the supraorbital margin.

Paranasal sinuses are air-containing cavities that are present within the bones of the skull. These paranasal sinuses have been divided into two groups:

Anterior group:

  • Maxillary sinus (antrum of Highmore)
  • Frontal sinus
  • Anterior ethmoidal sinus

All of the above sinuses open in the middle meatus, and their ostia lie anterior to the basal lamella of the middle turbinate.

Posterior group:

  • Posterior ethmoidal sinuses: Opens in the superior meatus 
  • Sphenoid sinus: Opens in sphenoethmoidal recess

Note: 

Maxillary and ethmoid sinuses (including both anterior and posterior ethmoidal sinuses) are present at birth. The frontal and the sphenoid sinuses are not present at birth.

Related Pearl: Structures opening into meatuses of nose

  • Inferior meatus: Nasolacrimal duct, guarded by the valve of Hasner
  • Middle meatus: Frontal sinus, maxillary sinus, anterior ethmoidal sinus. All these together form the osteo-meatal complex or Picadle’s circle.
  • Superior meatus: Posterior ethmoidal sinus
  • Sphenoethmoidal recess: Sphenoid sinus

questions.text: A 7-year-old child was scheduled for strabismus correction surgery. The induction of anesthesia was uneventful. After conjunctival incision as the surgeon grasps the medial rectus the anesthetist looks at the cardiac monitor. Why do you think he did that?

choices.text: To check the depth of anesthesia
To see if there was an oculocardiac reflex
To ensure there were no ventricular arrhythmias

questions.solution:
The anaesthetist would have looked at the monitor as soon as the medial rectus was grasped, to see if there was an oculocardiac reflex.

The oculocardiac reflex is a trigemino-vagal-reflex (afferent through trigeminal nerve, efferent through vagus nerve). It is most common in pediatric patients undergoing strabismus surgery. It is caused by traction on extraocular muscles or pressure on the eyeball and surrounding structures, particularly the medial rectus muscle.

Mechanism of reflex: Stretch receptors are located in the extraocular muscles. Once activated, the receptors send afferents through short and long ciliary nerves. The ciliary nerves will merge with the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve at the ciliary ganglion. The trigeminal nerve carries impulses to the Gasserian ganglion resulting in increased parasympathetic tone and bradycardia.

The manifestation can range from bradycardia (most common) to sinus arrest and ventricular ectopic to ventricular fibrillation. Administration of antimuscarinic drug glycopyrrolate or atropine reduces the incidence of bradycardia during eye surgery.

Treatment is done by temporary cessation of any surgical manipulation, prevention of hypercapnia or hypoxemia with adequate ventilation, IV glycopyrrolate or IV atropine if bradycardia persists. 

Related Pearl: Oculocardiac Reflex

Traction on the extraocular muscles or pressure on the globe causes bradycardia, atrioventricular block, ventricular ectopy, or asystole.

In particular, it is seen with traction on the medial rectus muscle, but it can occur with stimulation of any of the orbital contents, including the periosteum.

Reflex arc involves-

  • Afferent: Orbital contents to ciliary ganglion to ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve to the sensory nucleus of trigeminal
  • Efferent: Vagus nerve to the heart.

Procedures evoking the reflex-

  • Strabismus surgery in the paediatric age (most common) 
  • Cataract extraction
  • Enucleation
  • Retinal detachment repair.

Management-

  • Temporary cessation of surgical stimulation until heart rate increases
  • Adequate ventilation, oxygenation, and depth of anaesthesia
  • IV atropine (10 mcg/kg) if bradycardia persists
  • In recalcitrant episodes, local anaesthetic infiltration of the rectus muscles.

Pretreatment with intravenous atropine or glycopyrrolate can be effective in preventing this condition.

questions.text: By what age would a normal child know his/her name and gender?
questions.solution:
A normal child knows his/her name and gender by 3 years of age.

Related Pearl: Language milestones

 
Age Milestone
1 month Alerts to sound
2 months Coos (musical vowel sound)
4 months Laughs aloud
6 months Monosyllables sounds (ma, ba)
9 months Bisyllables (mama, baba)
12 months 1-2 words with meaning
18 months 8-10 word vocabulary
2 years 2-3 word sentences (uses pronouns like I, me, you)
3 years Asks questions and knows name and gender
4 years Sings songs, poems and tells stories
5 years Asks meaning of words

Related Pearl: Important developmental milestones at various ages

Developmental milestones 

At 1 year

  • Motor: Walks with support
  • Adaptive: Mature pincer grasp
  • Language: Speaks a few words
  • Social: Plays simple ball game
  • Domestic mimicry at 18 months

At 2 years

  • Motor: Walks up and downstairs, one step at a time
  • Adaptive: Makes a tower of 6 blocks 
  • Language: Simple sentences, a vocabulary of 50-100 words, uses pronouns at 2.5 yrs
  • Social: Asks for food and starts toilet training, listens to stories

At 3 years

  • Motor: Rides tricycle
  • Adaptive: Makes a tower of 9 blocks, handedness is established
  • Language: Knows full name, age, gender
  • Social: Plays simple games and engages in parallel play with other children

At 4 years

  • Motor: Hops
  • Adaptive: Draws square and constructs a bridge with blocks
  • Language: Tells stories
  • Social: Goes to the toilet alone
 At 5 years
  • Motor: Skips
  • Adaptive: Draws a triangle
  • Language: Asks the meaning of words, names 4 colors
  • Social: Dresses and undresses

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient presented with symptoms of food impaction and dysphagia. He also reported having a burning sensation in his chest that did not improve on taking proton-pump inhibitors (PPIs). His barium swallow image is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with food impaction, dysphagia, and the barium swallow image showing a series of rings in the esophagus (feline esophagus sign) are suggestive of eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE).

Eosinophilic esophagitis is an idiopathic condition commonly affecting the proximal 1/3rd of the esophagus. Eosinophils migrate to the esophagus and contribute to extensive tissue damage and inflammation.  

Clinical features include difficulty in swallowing, food impaction, vomiting, heartburn, and symptoms similar to those of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). It is usually non-responsiveness to PPI therapy. 

Barium swallow shows the presence of a series of rings in the esophagus. These rings appear similar to stripes on a cat, and the appearance is referred to as the feline esophagus sign. It is thought to be due to contraction of the muscularis mucosae, with the resultant shortening of the esophagus and bunching up of the mucosa in the lumen. On endoscopy, the esophagus appears narrow and friable with transient or fixed mucosal rings, strictures, and linear furrows. 

The diagnosis requires a biopsy with a histologic finding of >15–20 eosinophils per high-power field.

First-line therapies include proton pump inhibitors (PPIs), elimination diets and swallowed topical corticosteroids (STCs).

Elimination diet therapy involves the empirical removal of common food allergies (milk, wheat, egg, soy, nuts, and seafood) and a systematic reintroduction of those foods. The goal of the elimination diet therapy is to identify specific food triggers.

Swallowed topical glucocorticoids (STC) like fluticasone, propionate or budesonide are also given. If dysphagia is not relieved with steroids, esophageal dilation is done

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect.

questions.text:
A patient with a bacterial infection was prescribed antibiotic 'X'. He develops a cutaneous reaction to the drug and blames the physician for not warning him of the possible side effects of the drug. The physician explains that this effect was not predictable. Which type of adverse drug reaction is this?

ADR: Adverse drug reaction
questions.solution:
This type of adverse drug reaction was unpredictable and is a Type B ADR. They are bizarre reactions that are idiosyncratic and not predictable on the basis of drug pharmacology. They can be based on the characteristics of patients.

Adverse drug reactions can be classified into the following types:

  1. Type A reactions - augmented reactions that are dose-dependent and predictable based on the pharmacology of the drug
  2. Type B reactions - bizarre reactions that are idiosyncratic and not predictable on the basis of drug pharmacology. 
  3. Type C reactions - continuing reactions that persist for a relatively long time; an example is osteonecrosis of the jaw with bisphosphonate
  4. Type D reactions - delayed reactions that become apparent after some time of using the medicine; the timing of these may make them more difficult to detect; an example is leucopenia occurring up to six weeks after a dose of lomustine
  5. Type E reactions - end-of-use reactions that are associated with the withdrawal of a drug; an example is insomnia, anxiety, and perceptual disturbances following the withdrawal of benzodiazepines.

questions.text: A patient was found to have an extra row of cilia on the eyelid on a routine ocular examination, as shown in the image below. Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
The condition shown in the image, where there is an extra row of cilia on the eyelid, occupying the position of the Meibomian glands is distichiasis.

Distichiasis can occur due to congenital or acquired causes.

In congenital cases, the primary epithelial germ cells which were destined to become meibomian glands turn into pilosebaceous units. Thus a second row of lashes develops near the orifice of the meibomian glands. They are asymptomatic till 5 years of age.

In acquired cases, there is metaplasia of the meibomian glands into pilosebaceous units. Causes include intense conjunctival inflammation (e.g. chemical injury, Stevens–Johnson syndrome, ocular cicatricial pemphigoid)

These lashes may irritate the cornea. Management is by lid splitting with cryotherapy to the base of the hair follicles.

Option A: Trichiasis is inward misdirection of cilia, with the normal position of the lid margin.

Option C: Tylosis is the thickening of the lid margin.

Option D: Madarosis is the loss of eyelashes or eyebrows.

questions.text: A 22-year-old primigravida who presented with 6 weeks of amenorrhea was diagnosed to be a case of unruptured ectopic pregnancy. Which of the following would be a contraindication to expectant management in her?

choices.text: Presence of fetal heartbeat on transvaginal ultrasound
Absence of evidence of bleeding or rupture on TVS
Serum β-HCG level of 300 IU/L and a falling trend

questions.solution:
In the case of ectopic pregnancy, the presence of a fetal heartbeat on transvaginal ultrasound is a contraindication for expectant management.

A gestational sac of 3 cm with no fetal cardiac activity, falling levels of serum β-HCG (with an initial level less than 1500 IU/L), and no symptoms are indications for expectant management of an unruptured ectopic pregnancy. It is done only in selected cases of asymptomatic women who are well-counseled and willing for subsequent follow-up visits.

Management of unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy:

  1. Expectant management
  2. Conservative management
    • Medical 
    • Surgical
Expectant management Medical management Surgical management

An observation with serum β-HCG monitoring.

 Systemic use or direct local use of chemotherapeutic drugs- 
  • Drugs used: Methotrexate (MTX 50 mg/m2 single dose intramuscularly), potassium chloride, prostaglandin, hyperosmolar glucose, actinomycin.
  • Regular monitoring of serum β-HCG.

laparoscopic salpingostomy/ salpingectomy, microsurgical laparotomy 

 

Indications:

  • Initial serum hCG level <1,500 IU/L and the subsequent levels are falling.
  • Gestation sac size less than 4 cm.
  • No fetal heartbeat on TVS. 
  • No evidence of bleeding or rupture on TVS.
  • Hemodynamically stable

Indications:

  • Patient is hemodynamically stable
  • Serum hCG level less than 5,000 IU/L
  • Tubal diameter less than 4 cm without any fetal cardiac activity
  • Absence of any intra-abdominal hemorrhage

 

Indications:

  • Cases that do not fit the medical therapy criteria
  • Serum β-HCG levels are elevated despite medical therapy
  • Persistence of fetal cardiac activity

 

 

Estimation of serum β-HCG should be done weekly till the value becomes less than 5.0 mlU/mL, following conservative surgery or medical treatment.

questions.text: A sleep pattern of a patient with hypersomnia is being studied. During rapid eye movement sleep, it was observed that the activity of the locus ceruleus of the brain was suppressed. What likely change is expected at the level of a neurotransmitter associated with it?
questions.solution:
Locus coeruleus secrets norepinephrine. A decrease in norepinephrine is the expected change in the case of suppression of locus coeruleus.

The brainstem ascending arousal system is composed of several groups of neurons:

  • Locus coeruleus secrets norepinephrine
  • Raphe nucleus  secretes serotonin
  • Pontine nucleus secretes acetylcholine

During wakefulness, the locus coeruleus and raphe nucleus are dominant and the pontine is suppressed. Therefore, when a person is awake, the levels of norepinephrine and serotonin are increased, while that of acetylcholine is decreased. There is also a decrease in GABA levels and increased histamine levels when the person is awake.

REM sleep occurs when the pontine nucleus is dominant and locus coeruleus & raphe nucleus are suppressed. Therefore, acetylcholine is increased and norepinephrine and serotonin are decreased. Non-rapid eye movement (NREM) sleep occurs when there is suppression of the thalamus and cortex due to an increase in GABA and a decrease in histamine.

Related Pearl: Difference between NREM and REM Sleep

Physiological Process

NREM

REM

Brain activity

Decreases from wakefulness

Increases in motor and sensory areas, while other areas are similar to NREM

Heart rate

Slows from wakefulness

Increases and varies compared to NREM

Blood pressure

Decreases from wakefulness

Increases (up to 30 percent) and varies from NREM

Sympathetic nerve activity

Decreases from wakefulness

Increases significantly from wakefulness

Muscle tone

Similar to wakefulness

Absent

Blood flow to brain

Decreases from wakefulness

Increases from NREM, depending on brain region

Respiration

Decreases from wakefulness

Increases and  varies from NREM, but may show brief stoppages; coughing suppressed

Airway resistance

Increases from wakefulness

Increases and  varies from wakefulness

Body temperature

Is regulated at lower set point than wakefulness; shivering initiated at lower temperature than during wakefulness

Is not regulated; no shivering or sweating; temperature drifts toward that of the local environment

Sexual arousal

Occurs infrequently

Greater than NREM

Related Pearl: Neurotransmitters

 

Neuro-transmitters  Major source  Function  Increased in  Decreased in

Regulation of mood, sleep, appetite, sexual behavior, decreases anxiety

Inhibits the dopaminergic function

Motor movement and alertness

Reward seeking, pleasure, motivation

questions.text: An infant with the following finding was diagnosed with incontinentia pigmenti. What does the pattern of these lesions represent?
questions.solution:
Incontinentia pigmenti is a rare X-linked dominant disorder in which the lesions are present along Blaschko’s lines. Blaschko's lines are lines of normal cell development in the skin.

The lines are believed to trace the migration of embryonic cells and are invisible under normal conditions, becoming apparent only when some diseases of the skin or mucosa manifest themselves according to these patterns.

They follow a "V" shape over the upper spine, 'S-shaped' whirls over the lower abdomen and sides, inverted U-shape from the breast area onto the upper arm, and wavy shapes on the head. The stripes are a type of genetic mosaicism.

Several other dermatological disorders are known to follow the lines of Blaschko as given in the table:

Disorder Examples
Genodermatoses
  • Melanotic macules of McCune-Albright syndrome
  • Focal dermal hypoplasia
Congenital/Nevoid conditions
  • Hypomelanosis of Ito
  • Nevus depigmentosus
  • Linear Darier's disease
  • Epidermal Naevus
Acquired dermatoses
  • Segmental vitiligo
  • Lichen striatus
  • Linear scleroderma

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient came with complaints of nasal congestion, stuffiness, discharge, and anosmia. CT scan of paranasal sinuses shows mucosal thickening with centrally hyperdense areas. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Allergic fungal sinusitis is the most probable diagnosis based on the above findings.

It is an allergic reaction to the causative fungus. There is no invasion of the sinus mucosa with fungus. It presents with sinonasal polyposis and mucin which consists of eosinophils, Charcot Leyden crystal, and fungal hyphae. 

CT scan shows mucosal thickening with centrally hyperdense areas. There is an expansion of the sinus or bone erosion due to pressure but no fungal invasion.

Treatment: Endoscopic surgical drainage and ventilation along with systemic steroids.

Other options:

Option B: Ethmoidal polyps are multiple and bilateral and arise from the lateral wall of the nose. Patients are mostly adults and present with bilateral nasal obstruction, anosmia/ hyposmia, sneezing, rhinorrhea, and a polypoidal mass from the nostril.

Option C: Antrochoanal polyp (Killian's polyp) arises from the mucosa of the maxillary antrum. They are usually unilateral and are seen in children and young adults. They present with unilateral nasal obstruction. X-rays of the paranasal sinuses show opacity of the maxillary sinus,

Option D: Nasoethmoidal carcinoma presents with nasal obstruction, blood-stained nasal discharge, diplopia, lateral displacement of the eyeball, broadening of nasal root, and retro-orbital pain.

questions.text: A physiologist studies normal pressure-volume changes during the cardiac cycle using the graph shown below. The occurrence of the first heart sound (S1)  would correspond to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Mitral valve closure is responsible for S1 heart sound, which corresponds to point B; it marks the beginning of the isovolumetric contraction phase.

The pressure-volume curve represents the changes in volume and pressure in the left ventricle during a single cardiac cycle. The relationship between ventricular pressure (Y-axis) and volume (X-axis) throughout the cardiac cycle is represented by this loop:

  • A - Mitral valve opens
  • B - Mitral valve closes
  • C - Aortic valve opens
  • D - Aortic valve closes

Phase I: Period of filling

  • In the given diagram, the period of filling lasts from point A to point B.
  • At point A, the volume of blood present in the left ventricle is the end-systolic volume, which corresponds to about 50 mL. It is at this point that the mitral valve opens and the venous blood flows into the left ventricle from the left atrium.
  • At point B—the end of the period of filling—the amount of blood present in the left ventricle is called the end-diastolic volume, which corresponds to about 120 mL. This is the point at which the mitral valve closes.
  • Diastolic pressure rises to about 5 to 7 mmHg.

Phase II: Period of isovolumic contraction

  • In the given diagram, the period of isovolumic contraction lasts from point B to point C.
  • A point B, the mitral valve closes and the volume of the ventricle does not change as all the valves are closed. However, the pressure inside the ventricle continues to rise.
  • At point C, the ventricular pressure increases to become equal to the pressure in the aorta (80 mmHg), and then, the aortic valve opens.

Phase III: Period of ejection

  • In the given diagram, the period of ejection lasts from point C to point D.
  • At point C, the aortic valve opens and the volume of the ventricle decreases as the blood flows out of the ventricle into the aorta.
  • The systolic pressure continues to rise as the ventricle contracts.
  • At point D, the aortic valve closes.

Phase IV: Period of isovolumic relaxation

  • In the given diagram, the period of isovolumic relaxation lasts from point D to point A.
  • At point D, the aortic valve closes and the ventricular pressure falls back to the diastolic pressure level. 
  • This decrease in intraventricular pressure occurs without any change in volume.
  • At point A, the ventricle now has an end-systolic volume of 50 mL of blood similar to the beginning of the cycle.

questions.text: A firefighter presented with a chronic non-healing painless ulcer over his left leg. He gave a history of sustaining  2nd-degree burns injury to the leg 10 years back during a rescue mission. The examination finding is as shown below. All of the following are true about this condition, except ______.
questions.solution:
The given scenario and image showing an irregular ulcer with cauliflower shaped granulation tissue points to a diagnosis of Marjolin’s ulcer. It is avascular.

Related Pearl: Marjolin’s Ulcer

  • Low-grade squamous cell carcinoma arising from:
    1. Long-standing ulcers like a venous ulcer
    2. Post-burn scar
    3. Chronic osteomyelitis
    4. Post-radiation ulcer
  • Slow growing since it is relatively avascular
  • Painless due to the absence of nerves in scar tissue
  • No secondary deposits since there are no lymphatics in scar tissue
  • Radioresistant due to avascularity

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient was undergoing a craniotomy procedure for a posterior cranial fossa tumor in a sitting position. Intraoperatively, there was a sudden drastic drop in EtCO2 to 8 mmHg and blood pressure dropped to 80/50 mmHg. A venous air embolism was suspected. What is the immediate next step of management?

choices.text: Compress jugular vein to limit air entry to chest circulation
Administer nitrous oxide to eliminate the emboli
Stop 100% oxygen administration to prevent further air embolism

questions.solution:
In this given scenario of venous air embolism (VAE), the immediate next step of management is to compress the jugular vein to limit air entry to chest circulation.

The goal of treatment in VAE is to prevent further air entry, treat the intravascular air and hemodynamic support.

  • The first immediate step is to notify the surgeon to cover the surgical field with a saline-soaked dressing and tilt the table to prevent further air entry. In surgeries done in a sitting position, the jugular venous compression can restrict air entry into chest circulation.
  • Improve patient oxygenation by administration of 100% oxygen. It also reduces embolus volume by eliminating nitrogen. Nitrous oxide should be discontinued even after minor embolic events to prevent the air from reaching left-sided circulation.
  • Air entry to the right side of the heart may be relieved by a partial left lateral decubitus position. Aspiration of air from the right atrium can be tried by the use of a Bunegin-Albin multi-orifice catheter.
  • Maintain optimum fluid status and stabilize the patient with inotropes or pressors if needed.
  • In case of massive VAE with cardiac decompensation, initiate rapid cardiopulmonary resuscitation with chest compression.
  • To decrease the severity of the disease, initiate anticoagulation therapy with heparin. The usage of steroids is controversial as steroids do not have any effect on cytotoxic brain edema resulting from air embolism.

VAE refers to the entrapment of exogenously delivered gas or air into the venous vasculature resulting in systemic effects. It may occur during surgeries like sitting neurological procedures (posterior cranial fossa surgeries), obstetrics, and orthopedic surgeries. Other causes include mechanical insufflation during laparoscopic surgeries, iatrogenic air entry during venous catheterization and dysbarism. 

VAE should be considered when unexplained hypotension or a sudden fall in end-tidal CO2 level occurs intraoperatively in high-risk cases. Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) is the most sensitive device for detecting intracardiac air embolus.

questions.text: A biochemist is studying the transcription process. The sequence of the RNA he produced from a fragment of DNA is CAAGGU. Which one of the following will be the sequence of the coding strand in the DNA that gave rise to this sequence?
questions.solution:
The sequence of the coding strand in the DNA will be CAAGGT.

The non-template strand or coding strand in the DNA will have the same sequence of the RNA that is produced, except that the non-template or coding strand has T in place of U. 

As all sequences are written in the 5′ to 3′ direction, unless otherwise specified, an RNA sequence of CAAGGU would correspond to a DNA sequence, on the non-template strand, of CAAGGT.

Both the non-template strand and RNA produced will be a complementary sequence to the template strand. Therefore, the template strand would be GTTCCA (written 5′ to 3′).

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman who was previously diagnosed with an ovarian fibroma presents with gradually progressive abdominal distension, cough, breathlessness, and pleuritic chest pain on the right side. On examination, the abdomen is distended, and fluid thrill is present. Chest x-ray shows a right-sided pleural effusion. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the triad of benign ovarian fibroma, right-sided pleural effusion, and ascites are suggestive of Meigs syndrome.

The following triad of features favors the diagnosis:

  • Gradual progressive distension of abdomen, positive fluid thrill – points towards ascites.
  • Cough on lying to the right side, breathlessness, chest pain on the right side, chest X-ray – point towards right-sided pleural effusion.
  • Diagnosis of ovarian fibroma– benign ovarian tumor.

Meigs syndrome is mostly caused by ovarian fibroma. CA-125 levels may also be elevated. As it is a diagnosis of exclusion, a workup should be done to rule out malignancy. Exploratory laparotomy with surgical staging is the treatment of choice. Conservative surgery (salpingo-oophorectomy) is done. The clinical features resolve on resection of the fibroma.

Other options: 

Option B: Pseudo-Meigs syndrome, which presents with ascites and pleural effusion in association with benign tumors of the ovary (other than fibromas). Other features may include fibroids/leiomyoma, secondary metastatic tumors to the ovary, Brenners tumors, and benign ovarian cysts (such as struma ovarii, mucinous cystadenoma, and teratomas).

Option C: Pseudo-pseudo Meigs syndrome is a manifestation of SLE (systemic lupus erythematosus) defined by ascites, pleural effusion, and elevated CA-125 levels.

Option D: Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome occurs as a complication of pelvic inflammatory disease caused by Chlamydia trachomatis or Neisseria gonorrhea. It is characterized by the inflammation of the peritoneum and the tissues surrounding the liver (perihepatitis). Symptoms include sudden onset of severe pain in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen, fever, chills, and malaise.

questions.text: A 47-year-old smoker presented with cough, chest pain, dyspnea, and right shoulder pain. Chest X-ray revealed homogeneous opacity at the lung apex and destruction of the first rib. Which of the following is not compressed?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario and chest X-ray features are suggestive of a tumor at the apex of the right lung, also called Pancoast tumor. The thoracic duct does not lie between the 1st rib and the apex of the lung, so it will not be compressed. The thoracic duct crosses from right to left in the mediastinum at the level of T5 and ascends upwards to drain into the venous system. 

The structures present between the 1st rib and apex of the lung (medial to lateral) can be remembered using the mnemonic SVAN:

  • Sympathetic trunk
  • Vein - Posterior intercostal
  • Artery - Superior intercostal
  • Nerve - T1 nerve

Clinical significance:

Pancoast tumors can cause destruction of the first rib by mass effect. Given below is an X-ray image of a Pancoast tumor (marked as P).

questions.text:
You are managing four different cases of drug toxicity in the medicine department. Which of the following cases would not require hemodialysis in the management protocol?
  1. Lithium toxicity in a patient with bipolar disorder
  2. Digoxin toxicity in a patient with chronic heart failure  
  3. Toxicity in a person with opioid addiction  
  4. Methanol poisoning
questions.solution:
Cases 2 and 3 would not require hemodialysis as part of their management. Digoxin and opioids cannot be removed by hemodialysis. 

Hemodialysis may be indicated in overdose and poisoning with lithium and methanol.

The efficiency of hemodialysis in drug overdose or intoxication depends on molecular weight, water solubility, protein binding, endogenous clearance, and distribution of the drug in the body. 

A drug can be removed by hemodialysis if it has any of the following:

  • Low molecular weight
  • Low volume of distribution
  • High solubility in water
  • Minimal protein binding
Hemodialyzable drugs  Non-hemodialyzable drugs
Methanol Digoxin
Salicylate Diazepam
Valproic acid Verapamil
Phenobarbital Opioids
Lithium Metoprolol
Metformin Amphetamines

Generally, dialysis is indicated when medical management fails to control the following:

  • Volume overload
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Acidosis
  • Toxic ingestions
  • Severe complications of uremia, like asterixis, pericardial rub or effusion, encephalopathy, and uremic bleeding

Related Pearl: Dialyzable and non-dialyzable drugs

Common dialyzable drugs: 

  • Barbiturates
  • Lithium
  • Salicylates
  • Theophylline/Caffeine (both are methylxanthines)
  • Methanol
  • Ethylene glycol
  • Sodium valproate
  • Isoniazid
  • Carbamazepine

Common Non-Dialyzable Drugs (AVOID Dialysis):

  • A- Amphetamines
  • V- Verapamil
  • O- Opiates, Organophosphorous
  • I- Imipramine
  • D- Digoxin
  • Dialysis- Diazepam

Related Pearl: Hemodialysis vs Peritoneal dialysis

Difference between Hemodialysis and Peritoneal dialysis

Hemodialysis Peritoneal dialysis
Comparatively difficult access Easy access
Better clearance Good clearance
Short time for treatment Longer time may be required
Principle:

Solute removal through a semi-permeable membrane.

Principle:

Solute removal through a peritoneal membrane
Must be done in hospital Can be done at home
Complications:
  • Hypotension
  • Disequilibrium syndrome
  • Muscle cramps
  • Anaphylaxis reaction

Complications :

  • Peritonitis
  • Catheter-associated non-peritoneal infections
  • Weight gain
  • Metabolic disturbances
  • Residual uremia

questions.text: Arden index is related to:
questions.solution:
Arden index is related to electro-oculography (EOG).

Arden index is the ratio of the light peak over the dark trough. A value above 185 is normal and below 150 is abnormal.

In electrooculography, electrodes are used to pick up changes in the resting ocular potential when the eyes are moved. These changes are recorded in accordance with changes in illumination. It indicates the activity of the pigmentary epithelium and the outer segments of visual receptors.

Other options:

Option A: Electroretinography measures changes in the resting potential of the eye, induced by stimulating the eye with light.

Option C: Specific alterations in an electroencephalogram (EEG) caused by visual stimuli are called as visual evoked responses (VER).

Option D: Perimetry is the measurement of a person’s field of vision.

questions.text: Imatinib is the drug acting on the receptor shown in the image below. For which of the following diseases is this drug indicated?
questions.solution:
Imatinib is indicated for the treatment of chronic myeloid leukemia.

Imatinib belongs to the class of tyrosine kinase inhibitors, which are the first-line drugs indicated for the treatment of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). It is also used to treat other conditions:

  • Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST)
  • Philadelphia chromosome-positive acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL)
  • Hypereosinophilia syndrome
  • Adult myelodysplastic/myeloproliferative diseases
  • Systemic mastocytosis

Classification of BCR-ABL kinase/tyrosine kinase inhibitors: 

  • First-generation: Most likely to be associated with resistance
    • Imatinib 
  • Second-generation: Active against imatinib-resistant CML cases, but not those with T315I mutation 
    • Nilotinib
    • Dasatinib 
    • Bosutinib 
  • Third-generation: Active against T315I-mutant CML cases and other known mutant cases. 
    • Ponatinib

Adverse effects of these drugs include GI symptoms (diarrhea, nausea, vomiting), edema, and hepatotoxicity. Nilotinib and dasatinib might prolong the QT interval.

 

Related Pearl: Indications for Imatinib

BCR-ABL kinase mutations

  • Chronic myelogenous leukaemia (CML)
  • Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL)

C-KIT mutations

  • Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST)

PDGFR mutations

  • Dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans
  • Hypereosinophilia syndrome
  • Chronic myelomonocytic leukaemia (CML)

questions.text:
A polytrauma patient receives a massive blood transfusion. He develops dilutional coagulopathy subsequently. What ratio of blood products could have prevented it?

FFP: Fresh frozen plasma 
pRBCs: Packed red blood cells
questions.solution:
In a massive blood transfusion protocol, the transfusion ratio of the blood components FFP, platelets, and pRBCs is 1:1:1.

Massive transfusion with PRBCs alone causes dilutional coagulopathy. Therefore, a fixed-ratio (1:1:1) transfusion strategy is used for trauma patients, consisting of a transfusion of FFP, platelets, and RBCs at a ratio of 1:1:1, while minimizing crystalloid infusion. Early initiation of such a balanced transfusion minimizes dilutional coagulopathy of trauma and decreases hemorrhage-related deaths, thereby reducing overall mortality.

Related Pearl: Complications of a Massive Transfusion

Massive transfusion (MT) is defined as the replacement by transfusion of 10 units of pRBCs in 24 hours or more than 4 units of pRBCs in one hour.

Complications from massive transfusion include:

Complication Mechanism
Hypothermia As blood products are normally stored between 1°C and 6°C
Coagulopathy

MT with PRBCs alone causes a dilutional coagulopathy (vs consumptive coagulopathy caused by massive hemorrhage)

Can be prevented by starting early transfusion of FFP, platelets, pRBCs in a 1:1:1 ratio
Acidosis/ Alkalosis

Mild acidosis - increased CO2 levels in stored blood by 21-35 days

Metabolic alkalosis - citrate gets metabolized to bicarbonate

Metabolic acidosis - due to tissue hypoperfusion
Hyperkalemia/ Hypokalemia

Initially - Hyperkalemia, as stored blood has high K+ levels due to inactivated Na/K/ATPase pump

Later - Hypokalemia, due to intracellular potassium uptake and metabolic alkalosis
Hypocalcemia Stored blood is anticoagulated with citrate, which binds calcium.
Hypomagnesemia Infusion of large volumes of magnesium-poor fluids and binding of magnesium to citrate
Impaired O2-carrying capacity of hemoglobin Decreased 2, 3 DPG
Volume overload Due to massive transfusion

questions.text: During your labor postings, you notice the resident performing the following procedure for a primigravida in labor. Which of the following structures will be cut during this process?

choices.text: Both superficial and deep transverse perinei muscles

questions.solution:
During episiotomy, both the superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles are cut.

Episiotomy refers to the surgically planned incision on the perineum and the posterior vaginal wall during the second stage of labor. It is an induced second-degree perineal tear. In mediolateral episiotomy, the incision is made downwards and outwards from the midpoint of the fourchette either to the right or to the left.

The other types of episiotomy include median, lateral, and J-shaped episiotomy.

Structures cut in mediolateral episiotomy:

  • Posterior vaginal wall
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles
  • Bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani
  • Fascia covering these muscles
  • Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves
  • Subcutaneous tissue and skin
Midline Episiotomy Mediolateral Episiotomy
Surgical repair is easy Surgical repair is difficult
Blood loss is lesser Blood loss is more
Healing is superior Healing is not so good
Dyspareunia is rare Dyspareunia is comparatively more

Postoperative comfort is maximum

Postoperative discomfort is more

Extension, if occurs, may involve the rectum

Relative safety from rectal involvement from extension 

 

The objective is to enlarge the vaginal introitus so as to facilitate easy and safe delivery of the fetus and to minimize overstretching and rupture of the perineal muscles and fascia, which might end up in complete tears. The below image shows the episiotomy scissors.

 

 

Related Pearl: Mediolateral Episiotomy

It begins within 3 mm of the midline in the posterior fourchette and is directed laterally at an angle of at least 60 degrees from the midline. This yields an incision of 45 degrees off the midline.

It is essentially an inflicted second-degree perineal tear.

Structures cut in mediolateral episiotomy:

  • Posterior vaginal wall
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani
  • Fascia covering those muscles
  • Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves
  • Subcutaneous tissue and skin

Advantage: Lesser risk of anal sphincter laceration, hence it is preferred over median episiotomy.

Disadvantage: Increased blood loss and causes more perineal pain and dyspareunia.

questions.text: A patient is mute and immobile but conscious. He is unresponsive to the environment. How would you describe his state?
questions.solution:
A patient is said to be in a stupor when he is conscious but mute, immobile, and unresponsive to the environment.

  Stupor Sopor Coma
Consciousness Conscious, but mute and immobile Drowsy, abnormally deep sleep, difficult to arouse Unconscious, cannot be awakened
Response to the environment No/Decreased Responds to harsh sound, bright light No 
Response to painful stimulus Yes Yes No
 

Option A: Akinetic mutism: The person is mute and immobile but responsive to the environment.

Option D: Twilight state: A state of disturbed consciousness with hallucinations, during which actions may be performed unconsciously.

Note: The oneiroid state is a dream-like state in which patients may be deeply confused and not fully oriented to time and place. The term oneiroid schizophrenia has been used for patients who are engaged in their hallucinatory experiences to the point of exclusion of involvement in the real world.

questions.text: Which among the following has been marked with the correct types of joints?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option C.

1- Intervertebral joint- Secondary cartilaginous joint

2- Suture- Fibrous joint

3- Knee joint- Synovial joint

Structurally, joints are classified as fibrous joints, cartilaginous joints, and synovial joints. 

Structural classification of joints
Type  Subtypes
Fibrous joints
  • Sutures
  • Syndesmosis
  • Gomphosis
Cartilaginous joints
  • Primary cartilaginous (synchondrosis)
  • Secondary cartilaginous (symphysis)
Synovial joints
  • Ball-and-socket or spheroidal joints
  • Sellar or saddle joints
  • Condylar or bicondylar joints
  • Ellipsoid joints
  • Hinge joints
  • Pivot or trochoid joints
  • Plane joints

 

The types of fibrous joints- sutures (a), syndesmosis (b), and gomphosis (c) are shown in the image below:

 

Types of cartilaginous joints:

  • Primary cartilaginous joint: The bones are united by a plate of hyaline cartilage, making the joint immovable. They are temporary joints because the cartilaginous plate gets replaced by bone. Examples are: 
    • The joint between epiphysis and diaphysis of a growing long bone
    • Spheno-occipital joint
    • First chondrosternal joint
    • Costochondral joints
  • Secondary cartilaginous joints: A thin layer of hyaline cartilage covers the articular surfaces, which are united by a fibrocartilaginous disc. These joints are permanent. Examples are :
    • Symphysis pubis
    • Manubriosternal joint
    • Intervertebral joints between the vertebral bodies

Primary (a) and secondary (b) cartilaginous joints are shown below.

 

The articular surfaces of synovial joints are covered with hyaline cartilage and are lubricated with synovial fluid. They are the most mobile joints. Types of synovial joints are shown in the image below: 

Related Pearl: Types of Synovial Joints

Classification of Synovial Joints
Type Articular surfaces Movement Examples
1. Plane Almost flat Minimal sliding movements Intercarpal, intermetacarpal, carpometacarpal (except first), intertarsal, intermetatarsal, tarsometatarsal, joints between articular processes of vertebrae, cricothyroid joint, cricoarytenoid joint, superior tibiofibular, interchondral joint (5-9 ribs), costovertebral, costotransverse, acromioclavicular, chondrosternal (except first) joints
2. Hinge Pulley shaped Uniaxial - flexion & extension Elbow, ankle, interphalangeal joints
3. Pivot Central pivot (peg) surrounded by osteoligamentous ring Uniaxial - rotation (supination and pronation) Superior and inferior radioulnar joints, median atlantoaxial joint
4. Condylar (bicondylar) 2 convex condyles articulate with concave or flat surfaces on the other side Biaxial - but predominantly one axis movement (flexion & extension) with limited rotation Knee joint, temporomandibular joint
5. Ellipsoid Oval convex surface fitting into an elliptical concavity Biaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction Radiocarpal (wrist), metacarpophalangeal joints
6. Saddle Each articular surface has a concave and convex region fitting the convex and concave regions of the other surface Biaxial - mainly 2 axis, flexion & extension,  abduction & adduction; very limited coupled axial rotation (conjunct rotation)  First carpometacarpal joint (of thumb), calcaneocuboid joints, incudomalleolar joint, sternoclavicular joint
7. Ball & Socket Globular head fitting into a cup-shaped socket Multiaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction, and rotation Shoulder, hip, talocalcaneonavicular, incudostapedial joint

questions.text: A 24-year-old primiparous woman with Grade 2 genuine stress incontinence did not respond to conservative management. Which of the following surgeries will not be beneficial for her condition?
questions.solution:
Latzko procedure is not beneficial for a patient with genuine stress incontinence as it is done for vesicovaginal fistula.

The various surgeries done for genuine stress incontinence (GSI) are as follows:

  • Vaginal approach
    • Kelly repair
    • Pacey repair
  • Marshall-Marchetti-Krantz operation - abdominal approach. It is not done anymore as it causes osteitis of the pubis.
  • Burch colposuspension
  • Combined vaginal and abdominal suspension - Pereyra operation
  • Slings
    • Tension-free vaginal taping
    • Transobturator taping
  • Laparoscopic suspension of the bladder neck
  • Periurethral collagen injection

questions.text: A primigravida presents to the labor room at 40 weeks of gestation with lower abdominal pain. Labor begins and as the obstetrician manages it, you observe the crowning, extension, and restitution of the fetal head. In which stage of labor is this woman likely to be?
questions.solution:
Crowning, extension, and restitution of the fetal head are the cardinal movements of labor. These events occur during fetal delivery occurring in the second stage of labor.

  1. The first stage of labor is characterized by dilatation and effacement of the cervix and can be divided into latent phase and active labor. The onset of latent labor is the point at which the mother perceives regular contractions. Cervical dilatation of ≥5 cm in the presence of uterine contractions can be taken to reliably represent the threshold for active labor. The first symptom to appear is intermittent painful uterine contractions followed by the expulsion of blood-stained mucus (show) per vagina. In the late first stage, the contraction comes at intervals of 3–5 minutes and lasts 45 seconds. 
  2. The second stage of labor begins with complete cervical dilatation and ends with fetal delivery.
  3. The third stage of labor is characterized by the delivery of the placenta.
  4. The fourth stage is a stage of observation for at least an hour after the full expulsion of the placenta.

The specific cardinal movements of labor are as follows:

  • Engagement is the mechanism by which the biparietal diameter (in occiput presentation) passes through the pelvic inlet.
  • Descent is a continuous process completed with the fetus's expulsion.
  • Flexion of the head occurs as soon as the descending head meets resistance from the pelvic floor/pelvic walls/cervix.
  • Internal rotation is the mechanism by which the occiput gradually turns away from the transverse axis. Crowning occurs after internal rotation.
  • Extension occurs when the flexed head reaches the vulva.
  • External rotation/restitution is the visible passive movement of the delivered head by which it untwists its neck and regains a transverse position.
  • Expulsion is the process by which the anterior shoulder is followed by the posterior shoulder and the rest of the fetal body is delivered.

The below image shows the cardinal movements of labor.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with scanty, foul-smelling ear discharge. Otologic examination shows the following finding. Which of the following is an appropriate management plan?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the image showing marginal perforation is suggestive of atticoantral type of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM), and the appropriate management plan is surgical intervention with tympanomastoid exploration.
