questions.text: A patient with a slow-growing ulcerated lesion was diagnosed with basal cell carcinoma. Which of the following statements about this condition is incorrect?

choices.text: They mostly occur on the head and neck

questions.solution:
Since basal cell carcinoma does not have a premalignant stage, option B is incorrect.

Basal cell carcinoma is a slow-growing malignant tumor with locally invasive characteristics affecting the pilosebaceous skin. Risk factors for BCC include ultraviolet radiation exposure, human papillomavirus infection, immunosuppression, photosensitizing drugs, occupational factors, and arsenic exposure. 

On histopathological examination, they can be the multifocal superficial type that extends over the skin surface or the nodular type that grows into the dermis. They have hyperchromatic nuclei in a mucinous matrix and are surrounded by fibroblasts and lymphocytes. They demonstrate peripheral palisading (option A).

The below image shows the histological features of BCC:

Gross morphology: The most common type of BCC is nodular BCC. They are pearly, have a rolled border, and may be ulcerated (option C). Ulcerated BCCs are called rodent ulcers. Nodular BCCs are most commonly present on the head and neck (option D). 

The below image shows a nodular BCC with ulceration over the supraorbital area. 

BCCs can be managed medically with imiquimod, 5 fluorouracil, and intralesional interferon alpha-2b. Surgical methods involve excision with predetermined margins, curettage and cautery, and Moh's micrographic surgery. 

Note: Squamous cell carcinomas (SCC) have premalignant stages. SCC may arise from actinic keratosis, cutaneous horn, arsenical keratosis, post-ionizing radiation keratosis, disseminated superficial actinic porokeratosis, and Bowen disease. However, these lesions are considered to have uncertain malignant potential and share histological characteristics.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with complaints of abdominal pain, bloody stools, and generalized muscle pain. Her blood pressure is 200/110 mmHg. She was diagnosed with polyarteritis nodosa (PAN). According to the modified Chapel Hill classification, this vasculitis falls under which category?
questions.solution:
According to the modified Chapel Hill classification, polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) falls under medium vessel vasculitis.

Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is a systemic vasculitis affecting the small to medium-sized arteries. PAN characteristically involves the renal and visceral vessels and spares the pulmonary vasculature. One-third of the patients with PAN are positive for hepatitis B, causing the formation of HBsAg-HbsAb complexes that deposit in affected vessels. It has no association with ANCA.

PAN is usually seen in young adults with long symptom-free intervals. It classically presents as rapidly accelerating hypertension, acute abdominal pain, bloody stools, diffuse myalgias, and motor peripheral neuropathy.

In PAN, there is segmental necrotizing transmural inflammation of small-medium-sized arteries with aneurysms and thrombosis of the vessels involved. All stages of histopathological changes coexist in different vessels or even within the same vessel.

They are seen at the bifurcation of arteries and may spread to veins, but venules are spared. The most common vessels involved are kidney > heart > liver > gastrointestinal tract in that order. Inadequate perfusion results in ischemia, ulcerations, infarcts, ischemic atrophy, or hemorrhage.

 The diagnosis is based on the histopathological findings seen on a biopsy of the involved organs. Diagnosis can also be made by the demonstration of aneurysms of small- and medium-sized arteries in the renal, hepatic, and visceral vasculature. 

Pulmonary involvement is characteristically absent. Given below is a histopathological image of the biopsy findings in PAN.

An angiogram showing aneurysms of small-medium-sized renal arteries seen in PAN is given below.

(Large vessel vasculitis)

Temporal, vertebral and ophthalmic arteries, aorta

>40 years old, polymyalgia rheumatica, granulomas, giant cells

Takayasu Arteritis

(Large vessel vasculitis)

(Medium-sized and large arteries) Aortic arch, great vessels, pulmonary artery, coronary and renal arteries

Lymphocytes, macrophages, neutrophils, granulomas, giant cells

Pulseless disease

 

Polyarteritis Nodosa

Small or medium-sized muscular arteries, typically involving renal and visceral vessels

Neutrophils, eosinophils, and mononuclear cells,

Spares pulmonary vessels, 30% of patients with  chronic hepatitis B

Capillaries, small arterioles, venules

Neutrophils, eosinophils, and mononuclear cells,

Necrotizing glomerulonephritism (90% of patients) and pulmonary capillaritis leukocytoclastic vasculitis

Churg-Strauss Syndrome

Medium and small arteries

 

Eosinophils (required), lymphocytes, macrophages, neutrophils

Associated with asthma, allergic rhinitis, lung infiltrates, peripheral hypereosinophilia, and extravascular necrotizing granulomata.

Related Pearl: Primary Forms of Vasculitis with Sites of Involvement

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with frequent falls, rigidity, slowness in his movements, and tremors. A lesion affecting the substanstia nigra of the brain was suspected. Which option correctly describes the tremors associated with this condition?

choices.text: Frequency 5 Hz, increased at rest, decreased on movement
Frequency 12 Hz, increased at rest, decreased on movement
Frequency 12 Hz, decreased at rest, increased on movement
Frequency 5 Hz, decreased at rest, increased on movement

questions.solution:
The likely clinical condition is Parkinson's disease (PD) in which the associated tremors increase at rest, decrease on movement, and are of frequency 5Hz.

Parkinson’s disease is the second most common neurodegenerative disorder after Alzheimer's disease. The UK Parkinson's Disease Society Brain Bank criteria are used for the diagnosis of PD.

Cardinal motor features in PD:

  • Resting tremors
  • Bradykinesia
  • Rigidity
  • Gait disturbance/postural instability

The frequency of the typical resting tremor seen in Parkinson's is 4–6 Hz. The classic parkinsonian tremor begins as a low-frequency, pill-rolling motion of the fingers, progressing to forearm pronation/supination and elbow flexion/extension.

It is typically asymmetric, occurs at rest, and becomes less prominent with voluntary movement. More than 70% of patients with PD have tremors as the presenting feature.

Mnemonic for clinical features: TRAP - Tremors + Rigidity + Akinesia + Postural instability

  • Other motor features:
    • Micrographia
    • Masked facies (hypomimia)
    • Reduced eye blinking
    • Soft voice (hypophonia)
    • Dysphagia
  • Non-motor features:
    • Anosmia
    • Sensory disturbance (pain)
    • Mood Disorders (depression)
    • Sleep disturbances (rapid eye movement behavior disorder)
    • Autonomic:
      • GI disturbances
      • Genitourinary disturbances
      • Sexual dysfunction
      • Orthostatic hypotension
    • Cognitive impairment

 

Related Pearl: Abnormal movements

 

 Movement Site Description Cause
Intentional tremor Cerebellum Only on activity 
  • Trauma
  • Stroke
  • Alcohol
  • Drugs
Resting tremor

Substantia nigra

Red nucleus

 Disappear on movement
  •  Parkinsonism

  • Anxiety 
  • Hyperthyroidism

  • Hepatic encephalopathy

  • Rheumatic chorea
  • Huntington chorea

  • Vascular>degenerative

questions.text: During ward rounds, a resident doctor inserts an intravenous cannula in the patient's hand as shown in the image. What is the gauge size of this cannula?
questions.solution:
The image shows a pink intravenous cannula and the size is 20G. It has a flow rate of 67 mL/ min.

Other options:

Option B: The blue IV cannula is 22G with a flow rate of 42 mL/min.

Option C: The orange IV cannula is 14G with a flow rate of 270 mL/min.

Option D: The green IV cannula is 18G with a flow rate of 103 mL/min.

A standard wire gauge (SWG) is used to size cannulas. It is a measure of the cross-sectional area. Larger cannulae have a smaller gauge number.

Tip:

A simple mnemonic to remember these in descending order of their flow rates is nature. The mantle zone of the earth is orange, the land is grey, the grass is green, the butterfly on the grass is pink, the sky is blue, and the sun is yellow.

Related Pearl: Color Coding of Intravenous Cannulae

Size Color Coding Flow Rate Uses

16G Grey 236ml/min Trauma Patients, Major Surgery, Intra Partum/Post Partum, GI bleeds, Multiple blood transfers, High volume of Fluids
17G White 125ml/min Newly added
18G Green 103 ml/min Blood products, delivery of irritant medications, major surgery, contrast study
20G Pink 67ml/min General use IV maintenance, IV antibiotics, IV analgesics
22G Blue 42 ml/min Small or Fragile veins, Cytotoxic Therapy
24G Yellow 20ml/min For pediatric Usage
26G Violet 13ml/min Newly added

questions.text: In the image shown below, markings 1 and 2  correspond to structures that contribute to the ______ mechanism, and this mechanism produces ______ urine normally.
questions.solution:
The markings 1 and 2 in the given image correspond to the loop of Henle, which is responsible for the countercurrent multiplier mechanism, and this mechanism produces concentrated urine.

The countercurrent mechanism is present in the testes, kidneys, gut, and lungs.  The inflow that runs parallel to, counter to, and in close proximity to the outflow for some distance is called the countercurrent mechanism. 

Spermatogenesis requires a temperature considerably lower than that of the interior of the body. The testes are kept cool by heat exchange between the spermatic arteries and veins via a countercurrent mechanism.

The concentration of urine by the kidney requires an osmolality gradient. This gradient is produced by the loop of Henle as a countercurrent multiplier and maintained by the vasa recta as a countercurrent exchanger. 

The functioning of the loop of Henle depends upon the following:

  1. The high permeability of the thin descending limb to water (via aquaporin-1)
  2. Active transport of Na+ and Cl- from the thick ascending limb, thereby diluting the tubular fluid.
  3. The inflow of tubular fluid from the proximal tubule and outflow to the distal tubule.

The countercurrent mechanism is used in the villi to decrease the oxygen availability for the local metabolic reactions of the gut. Hence, this will increase the blood flow in the intestine during gastrointestinal activity.

Countercurrent exchange of oxygen is seen in the lungs as well.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man visited a mining site 2 days ago, after which he had hearing loss for one day. He can now hear properly and on examination, the tympanic membrane looks normal. What is the most likely frequency range of noise that would have caused this?
questions.solution:
The given case suggests a temporary hearing loss, which happened after a specific exposure to noise at a mining site and disappeared after 24 hours. It is usually seen at the frequency range of 4000-6000 Hz.

Effects of noise exposure:

  • Auditory effects
    • Auditory fatigue appears at 90 dB and is greatest at 4000 Hz. Whistling and buzzing in the ear occur with auditory fatigue.
    • Temporary deafness or hearing loss occurs after a single exposure to noise, usually at a frequency range of 4000 – 6000 Hz. It disappears after 24 hours following noise exposure.
    • Permanent hearing loss can result after continuous or repeated exposure to noises around 100 dB. It occurs commonly as occupational hearing loss.
    • Exposure to noise above 160 dB may rupture the tympanic membrane and cause permanent hearing loss.
  • Non-auditory effects
    • Interference with speech occurs when the sound has a frequency of 300–500 Hz
    • Annoyance is a psychological response to noise that can greatly affect efficiency and concentration
    • Noise has also been known to cause some physiological changes like increased blood pressure, intracranial pressure, increased sweating, etc.

questions.text: A neonate with vomiting, irritability and progressive lethargy was investigated and was found to be deficient for ornithine permease enzyme. All the below laboratory findings are associated with this disorder, except _______.
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a child with a deficiency of ornithine permease points towards a diagnosis of HHH syndrome. Hyperargininemia is not a component of this disorder.

Components of HHH syndrome:

  • Hyperammonemia
  • Hyperornithinemia
  • Homocitrullinemia

The given scenario is HHH syndrome, due to a mutation of the gene coding for ornithine permease (ORNT1). This is an autosomal recessive condition. The import of ornithine from the cytosol to the mitochondrial matrix does not occur, which leads to the accumulation of cytosolic ornithine and, consequently, hyperammonemia and hyperornithinemia. 

Since ornithine is not present, mitochondrial carbamoyl phosphate converts lysine to homocitrulline, leading to homocitrullinuria. 

Hyperargininemia is an autosomal recessive defect in the gene for arginase. Unlike the case with urea cycle disorders, the first symptoms of hyperargininemia typically do not appear until the age of 2 to 4 years. Blood and cerebrospinal fluid levels of arginine are elevated.

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: While working as a resident in a hospital, you are asked by the consultant to prescribe a certain proton-pump inhibitor (PPI). It should be given only orally once daily before breakfast, even though it has a half-life of no more than 3 hours. What is the rationale behind this once-daily dosing?

choices.text: The drug can inhibit all gastric pumps.
The drug irreversibly inactivates the pump molecule.
The drug is gradually released irrespective of its formulation.
The drug suppresses basal but not stimulated acid production.

questions.solution:
The rationale behind the once-daily dosing is that the drug irreversibly inactivates the pump molecule.

Proton-pump inhibitors (PPIs) are prodrugs that are activated only after undergoing an acid-catalyzed cleavage in the canaliculi of the parietal cells of the stomach.

On administration, they are absorbed in the proximal small bowel and eventually, block the H+/K+ ATPase enzyme, the "proton pump" in the parietal cells of the stomach. The secretion of protons by an activated H+/K+- ATPase (proton pump) in the parietal cells into the gastric lumen is the final step involved in the production of gastric acid and inhibition of this enzyme prevents acid secretion into the stomach.

Once PPIs irreversibly inactivate the H+K+-ATPase pump, acid secretion resumes only after new pump molecules are synthesized and inserted into the luminal membrane. This leads to prolonged suppression of acid secretion for up to 24-48 hours, despite having a shorter plasma half-life of only 30 minutes to 3 hours.

In most individuals, once-daily dosing is enough to achieve effective acid inhibition. If necessary, a second dose can be given before an evening meal.

The number of H+K+-ATPase pump molecules increases after fasting and food decreases the oral bioavailability of the drug. Hence, PPIs are given around 30 minutes before the first meal of the day.

PPIs cannot inhibit all gastric acid pumps with oral dosing because not all pumps are active during the short half-life of the PPI in the blood. 

PPIs cause maximum suppression of gastric acid. They reduce the daily production of both basal and stimulated acid secretion by 85–90%. 

There are available in the form of delayed-release tablets, capsules, and oral suspension packets and for immediate acid suppression, there are intravenous formulations for PPIs like lansoprazole, pantoprazole, and esomeprazole. Therefore, the release of the drug depends upon the drug formulation.

questions.text: A newly pregnant woman is registered in the scheme where a cash incentive of 5000 rupees will be provided to her in installments only for the first living child of the family. What is this scheme?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is Option C. A cash incentive of 5000 rupees is provided in installments to all pregnant women and lactating mothers under Pradhan Mantri Matru Vandana Yojana (PMMVY) for the first living child of the family. This is subject to the fulfillment of specific conditions.

First Installment: Early Registration of pregnancy - 1,000 rupees

Second Installment: Received antenatal care (ANC) at least once (can be claimed after 6 months of pregnancy) - 2,000 rupees

Third Installment: Childbirth is registered and the child has received the first cycle of BCG, OPV, DPT, and hepatitis B vaccine or its equivalent/ substitute - 2,000 rupees

Other options:

Option A: Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan: Under this scheme, all pregnant women will receive a free checkup on the 9th of every month.

PMSMA aims to improve the quality and coverage of antenatal care, diagnostics, and counseling services. This is undertaken as part of the Reproductive, Maternal, Neonatal, Child Plus Adolescent Health (RMNCH+A) strategy. Under PMSMA, a pregnant woman receives at least 1 check-up in her second or third trimester by a doctor in the PMSMA clinic, on the 9th of every month.

After routine examination, pregnant women are categorized according to the risk factors, and different colored stickers are given as follows:

  • Green sticker: For women with no detected risk factor
  • Red sticker: For women with detected risk factor

Option B: At least 4 antenatal checkups and 6 home-based newborn care visits are provided under Surakshit Matritva Aashwasan (SUMAN). It is a new initiative for women and newborns where assured, dignified, respectful, and quality healthcare is provided free of cost.  It aims to end all preventable maternal and newborn deaths.

Option D: Under Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY), a cash incentive of 1400 rupees is provided to all pregnant women who had an institutional delivery in low-performing states. This scheme was launched under the National Rural Health Mission (NRHM) to promote institutional delivery.

questions.text: Identify the following instrument that was devised to measure the cooling power of air as well as low air velocities.
questions.solution:
The image shown above is of the kata thermometer, which is used to measure the cooling power of the air.

Related Pearl: Measurement of Air Temperature

A number of thermometers that employ mercury or alcohol are used for measuring air temperature.

These thermometers are mounted on a special screen called Stevenson screen as air should have free access to their bulbs and they must be protected from radiant heat.

The instruments used to measure air temperature are:

1) Dry bulb thermometers:

These are ordinary mercury thermometers mounted on a Stevenson screen at about 1.20 to 1.80 metres above sea level

2) Wet bulb thermometers:

These are just like the dry bulb variants but the bulb is kept wet by a muslin cloth that is fed with water from a bottle through a wick.

3) Maximum thermometer

This is a mercury thermometer that has a very fine constriction near the neck of the bulb

4) Minimum thermometer

The liquid in this thermometer is a spirit that has a dumb-bell shaped index immersed in it

5) Six’s maximum-minimum thermometer

  • This thermometer has both mercury and alcohol
  • It measures the maximum and minimum air temperatures reached over a period of time
  • A mercury-free variant of this thermometer is available

5) Globe thermometer:

  • It is used for the direct measurement of the mean radiant temperature of the surroundings.
  • It has a hollow metal globe (6 inches diameter) that has matte black paint which absorbs radiant heat. A specially calibrated mercury bulb thermometer is kept inside.
  • The difference between the readings of the globe thermometer and the bulb thermometer is the measure of the radiant heat.

7) Kata thermometers:

  • It is an alcohol thermometer and consists of a wet kata and a dry kata.
  • A wet kata reading of 20 and above and a dry kata reading of 6 and above were taken as indices of thermal comfort.
  • It was originally used to measure the cooling power of the air (air temperature, humidity and air movement) but currently it is used only as an anemometer to measure low air velocities.

questions.text: Enterokinase-mediated proteolysis of trypsinogen to trypsin is needed for the digestion of which macronutrient?
questions.solution:
Enterokinase-mediated proteolysis of trypsinogen to trypsin is necessary for the digestion of proteins.

All proenzymes are converted to their active form by selective proteolysis (removal of a few amino acids). Enterokinase cleaves trypsinogen to yield active trypsin. It is located on the brush border of duodenal enterocytes.

Enterokinase deficiency may result in protein malabsorption due to defective conversion of the proenzyme trypsinogen to trypsin. It is characterized by the following:

  • Diarrhea
  • Growth retardation
  • Hypoproteinemia

questions.text:
A middle-aged man presents with low mood, lethargy, and facial color change as shown below. He reports to be taking thyroxine 25 mcg daily for the past 3 days on his friend's suggestion for improvement in lethargy. On examination, his PR is 100 bpm and BP is 110/70 mmHg in the supine position and 90/60 mmHg on standing. His laboratory investigation results are given below. What is the probable diagnosis?

Random blood sugar: 120 mg/dL
Serum sodium: 120 mEq/L
Serum potassium: 6 mEq/L
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of low mood and lethargy, hyperpigmentation over the face, postural hypotension, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia points towards a diagnosis of Addison's disease.

Addison's disease occurs due to primary adrenal insufficiency. The secretion of both glucocorticoids and mineralocorticoids is impaired, resulting in various clinical manifestations.

Clinical features of Addison’s disease:

  • Features of hypoaldosteronism 
    • Abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, salt craving
    • Dizziness, postural hypotension
    • Acute kidney injury due to volume depletion
    • Hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis
  • Features of decreased cortisol level
    • Anorexia, weight loss, fatigue, myalgia, arthralgia, fever (increased IL-1)
    • Postural hypotension, hypoglycemia, hyponatremia (loss of feedback inhibition of ADH)
    • Slightly increased TSH level (loss of feedback inhibition)
  • Features of decreased androgen level
    • Loss of libido, loss of pubic and axillary hair
  • Features of elevated ACTH
    • Hyperpigmentation

Common causes of Addison’s disease:

  • Tuberculosis in developing countries
  • Autoimmune mechanisms (idiopathic atrophy) in developed countries
  • Metastasis to adrenal glands

Diagnosis:

  • Cosyntropin stimulation test
  • Plasma ACTH and cortisol levels
  • Plasma renin and aldosterone levels

Treatment involves replacement of glucocorticoids, mineralocorticoids, and androgen. Acute adrenal crisis may be precipitated by any illness, stress, infection, or hypothyroidism, contributing to the increased utilization of glucocorticoids. The diagnosis can be confirmed by the ACTH stimulation test. Acute adrenal crisis is treated with an intravenous infusion of saline and hydrocortisone bolus, followed by a maintenance dose of hydrocortisone.

Other options:

Option B: Conn's syndrome or primary hyperaldosteronism occurs due to aldosterone secreting adrenal adenoma leading to mineralocorticoid excess. It is characterized by hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, muscle weakness, proximal myopathy and muscle cramps.

Option C: Acute labyrinthitis patients might present with a history of falls and vertigo, without features of hyponatremia or hypotension. 

Option D: Cerebral salt-wasting disease presents with hyponatremia and hypotension, but with an antecedent history of cerebral injury or intervention, unlike the case with this patient. 

Related Pearl: Causes of Adrenocortical Insufficiency

Primary adrenal insufficiency:

  • Anatomical destruction of gland
  • Autoimmune (Addison's disease)
  • Isolated autoimmune adrenalitis (polygenic)
  • Infections - HIV, tuberculosis, fungi
  • Surgical removal
  • Acute hemorrhagic necrosis (Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome)
  • Amyloidosis, sarcoidosis, hemochromatosis
  • Metastatic carcinoma
  • Cytotoxic agents – mitotane
  • Enzyme inhibitors – metyrapone, ketoconazole
  • Congenital adrenal hypoplasia
  • Autoimmune polyendocrinopathy syndrome type 1 (AIRE1 gene on 21q22)
  • Autoimmune polyendocrinopathy syndrome type 2 (polygenic)
  • X-linked adrenal hypoplasia (DAX1 gene on Xp21)
  • Adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD gene on Xq28)

Secondary adrenal insufficiency:

Hypopituitarism due to hypothalamic or pituitary disease

  • Neoplasm
  • Infiltration (sarcoidosis)
  • Infection (tuberculosis, pyogenic, fungal)

Suppression of HPA axis

  • By endogenous steroids from tumor
  • By exogenous steroids

questions.text:
A patient with oral cavity cancer is planned for neck dissection. Given below are the structures present in the neck. If you are doing a type 3 modified radical neck dissection, then which structures will you remove?
  1. Levels 1, 2, and 3 lymph nodes
  2. Levels 4 and 5 lymph nodes
  3. Cranial nerve XI 
  4. Sternocleidomastoid muscle
  5. Internal jugular vein
questions.solution:
In a type 3 modified radical neck dissection/functional neck dissection, lymph nodes of levels 1-5 are removed. Cranial nerve XI, internal jugular vein, and sternocleidomastoid muscles are preserved. 

There are three types of modified radical neck dissection (MRND).

Structures preserved in the different types are as follows:

  • MRND 1 - Only spinal accessory nerve 
  • MRND 2 - Accessory nerve and internal jugular vein
  • MRND 3, i.e. functional neck dissection - Accessory nerve, sternocleidomastoid, and internal jugular veins 

Radical neck dissection involves the removal of the following structures:

  • All ipsilateral cervical lymph node groups, extending from the inferior border of the mandible to the clavicle and from the lateral border of the sternohyoid muscle, hyoid bone, and contralateral anterior belly of the digastric muscle medially to the anterior border of the trapezius muscle laterally
  • All lymph nodes from Levels I through to V
  • Spinal accessory nerve
  • Internal jugular vein
  • Sternocleidomastoid muscle
  • Tail of parotid
  • Submandibular gland

Radical neck dissection does not include the removal of the following:

  • Sub-occipital nodes
  • Peri-parotid nodes (except infraparotid nodes located in the posterior aspect of the submandibular triangle)
  • Buccinator nodes
  • Retropharyngeal nodes
  • Midline visceral (anterior compartment) nodes

Related Pearl: Types of Neck Dissections

Dissection LN removed Other structures removed/preserved
RND l-V CNXI, IJV, SCM removed
MRND l l-V CNXI preserved
MRND ll l-V CNXI, IJV preserved
MRND lll l-V CNXI, IJV, SCM preserved
END l-V CNXI, IJV, SCM removed+ one/more LN groups +/- non-lymphatic structures

 

SND LN removed Primary site of cancer
Supra-omohyoid l-lll Oral cavity
Extended supra-omohyoid l-lV Oral cavity and oropharynx
Postero-lateral

ll-V

Skin over posterior scalp and upper neck
Lateral ll-lV

Oropharynx, hypopharynx, larynx
Anterior(Central) Vl Thyroid/midline structures

RND- Radical Neck Dissection; MRND- Modified Radical Neck Dissection; END- Extended Neck Dissection; SND- Selective Neck Dissection

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the class of immunoglobulin shown in the image below?

choices.text: It exists as a monomer in serum.
It is the second most abundant class of serum immunoglobulins.

questions.solution:
The above image shows a dimeric structure, which is characteristic of secretory IgA; the incorrect statement is that it is a heat-labile antibody. 

IgE is the only heat-labile antibody; this is a property unique to IgE. It is inactivated when heated at 56°C for one hour.

IgA immunoglobulin is the major antibody responsible for mucosal immunity. It is predominantly present in the extravascular secretions. It is present in secretions such as milk, saliva, and tears, as well as in secretions of the respiratory, intestinal, and genital tracts.

IgA is the second most abundant class of antibodies, comprising about 10–13% of the serum immunoglobulins. The most abundant serum immunoglobulin is IgG. The order of abundance of the different immunoglobulins in serum is given as IgG > IgA > IgM > IgD > IgE.

When present in the serum, IgA exists as a monomer, similar to IgG. However, when it is secreted, it exists as a dimer. The dimeric structure consists of two monomers, which are stabilized by two additional polypeptides:

  • J chain, which stabilizes the molecule
  • The secretory component, which is incorporated into the IgA when transported through the epithelial cell

Related Pearl: Properties of immunoglobulin classes

IgG:

  • Half-life- 23 days
  • Appears late, indicates chronic infection
  • It is the only maternal Ig to cross the placenta.
  • Has 4 subclasses.
  • Causes complement fixation, precipitation, and neutralization of toxins and virus.

IgM:

  • Half-life- 5 days
  • Has the highest molecular weight and is a pentamer.
  • Polysaccharides and lipids mainly stimulate IgM secretion.
  • Intravascular distribution.
  • Appears early, indicates recent infection.
  • Acts as surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • It causes agglutination, hemolysis, complement fixation and opsonization.

IgD:

  • Half-life- 2-8 days.
  • Acts as a surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • Serves as recognition receptors for antigens.

IgE:

  • Half-life- 1-5 days
  • Causes type I hypersensitivity.
  • It is the only heat labile antibody.
  • Levels are raised in helminthic infections.

IgA:

  • Half-life- 6 days
  • It is of 2 types- Serum IgA and Secretory IgA 
  • Secretory IgA (A dimer) results in mucosal immunity.

questions.text:
A patient presents with complaints of hematuria and hemoptysis. His renal biopsy showed crescentic glomerular lesions suggestive of RPGN. Immunofluorescence findings are given in the image below. Which type of RPGN is this condition classified as?

RPGN - Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the immunofluorescence showing a linear, smooth diffuse pattern of staining is suggestive of Goodpasture syndrome, which is classified under type I RPGN.

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) is a clinical entity with features of nephritic syndrome and rapid loss of renal function. It is a syndrome associated with severe glomerular injury with necrosis and the formation of crescents, but it does not denote a specific etiologic form of glomerulonephritis.

In most cases, RPGN is immune-mediated. Circulating anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCAs) are detected in the pauci-immune type of RPGN. Serum analyses for anti-GBM antibodies, antinuclear antibodies, and ANCAs are helpful in the diagnosis of specific subtypes

Based on immunologic findings, RPGN is classified as:

Anti-GBM antibody-mediated disease (Type I) is characterized by linear GBM deposits of IgG and C3 on immunofluorescence and includes renal limited disease and Goodpasture's disease. Here, the antibodies are produced against a peptide present in the noncollagenous domain of the α3 chain of collagen IV of the GBM. This serves as the antigen which is common to the alveoli and the glomerulus.

Immune complex deposition (Type II) is characterized by granular deposits of antibodies and complement on immunofluorescence and can be a complication of any of the immune complex nephritides which include:

  • Postinfectious glomerulonephritis
  • Lupus nephritis
  • IgA nephropathy
  • Henoch-Schönlein purpura

Pauci-immune (Type III) exhibits no characteristic immunoglobulin or complement deposits on immunofluorescence. It includes

  • ANCA-associated
  • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
  • Microscopic polyangiitis

Goodpasture syndrome is an autoimmune disease affecting men more than women, with simultaneous hemorrhagic interstitial pneumonitis and rapidly progressive (crescentic) glomerulonephritis. The GBM antigen is a component of the noncollagenous domain of the α3 chain of type IV collagen, which is common to both alveoli and glomeruli.

On microscopy, the renal biopsy shows show linear GBM fluorescence for Ig and complement. Electron microscopy (EM) shows the wrinkling of the glomerular basement membrane with focal disruptions without any immune complex deposition.

Note:

  • Anionic antigens form subendothelial deposits.
  • Cationic antigens form subepithelial deposits.
  • Neutral antigens form mesangial deposits.

questions.text: A surgeon applies a very tight plaster cast on patient’s leg and asks the patient to inform if he develops any numbness. The patient develops numbness but does not inform the doctor immediately. Next day, when the patient informs the doctor, the doctor says he is too busy to remove the cast. After a few days, the patient develops a permanent injury. The doctor is held guilty under:
questions.solution:
This is a case of last clear chance doctrine and the doctor is held guilty.

In this case:

  • The doctor showed negligence by applying tight plaster cast, however, gave proper instructions to the patient.
  • The patient has neglected by not informing the doctor immediately after he developed numbness.
  • When the patient informed the doctor the next day, the doctor still had a chance to remove the cast and prevent permanent injury. But the doctor again neglected and thus missed the last clear chance.

So, the doctor cannot plead for contributory negligence and will be held guilty under the last clear chance doctrine.

Other options:

Option D: Medical maloccurrence is a defence against negligence for doctors. In certain cases, despite proper medical skill, attention, and care, the patient may fail to respond or suffer from the adverse effects of drugs. 

Related Pearl: Contributory negligence

Contributory negligence occurs when a patient or his personal attendant shows unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care, which when combined with the negligence of the doctor, has contributed to the injury. In this case, the patient’s or attendant’s negligence should be the direct, proximate cause and without which the injury would not have occurred.

So, contributory negligence occurs when both the doctor and patient are negligent. The direct or proximate cause of the injury should be the patient’s negligence, which means that if the patient was not negligent, the injury could have been prevented.

Contributory negligence usually occurs when the doctor is negligent and the patient:

  • Fails to give an accurate medical history, and as a result, the doctor may misdiagnose or mistreat the patient.
  • Fails to follow the doctor’s instructions
  • Refuses to take the treatment
  • Leaves the hospital against doctor’s advice
  • Does not inform the doctor or seek further medical assistance if the symptoms persist or worsens.

Contributory negligence is a defence for doctor’s negligence in civil cases. However, from case to case, the liability of a doctor may vary from complete non-liability to substantial liability for the damages. Under the doctrine of comparative negligence, the court has the right to hold both parties liable for their negligent actions.

Limitations / Exceptions to contributory negligence:

A. The doctor will be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. The doctor failed to provide proper instructions to the patient

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and did not tell the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (no proper instruction). The patient develops numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

 2. Last clear chance doctrine: It is applicable when the doctor fails to take necessary action to prevent damage due to a negligent act of the patient, even after getting a clear chance to take such action.

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and told the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (gave proper instruction). The patient developed numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). Next day patient informed the doctor, but the doctor did not remove the cast and said he was busy (There was a clear last chance, but the doctor neglected again). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

B. The doctor/person will not be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. Avoidable consequences rule: It occurs when an injury is caused due to doctor’s negligence, and the patient has done a negligent act, which further aggravated the injury caused by the doctor, and the patient could have avoided the consequence by not doing such act. In such cases, the doctor need not pay anything, and the patient will be held guilty.

  • Ex: A patient had a lacerated wound. The doctor examined the patient and had not done any dressing or provided any antibiotics (the doctor is negligent). However, the doctor instructed the patient to avoid contamination and asked him to visit the clinic next week. When the patient went home, he applied cow dung on his wound every day thinking that the wound would heal faster and didn't visit the doctor after one week. The wound got infected and developed pus and aggravated the injury.
  • Here, despite the doctor being negligent in the first instance, the patient is responsible for his injury as he performed an unnecessary, avoidable act, which aggravated the injury. The doctor need not pay anything.

2. Good Samaritan doctrine: A person who assists another person who is in serious danger cannot be charged with contributory negligence. unless such assistance is reckless or rash.

  • Ex: A person was travelling on a road and saw a car accident, where the victim was unconscious and was stuck inside the car. He called the ambulance. The paramedical staff instructed him not to mobilize the victim until they arrived. Meanwhile, the car was caught in fire (serious danger), and the person tried to remove the victim carefully out of the car (assisted the victim and was not reckless). However, the victim already had a cervical bone fracture due to the accident, which got mobilized while he was being removed out of the car and as a result, suffered an injury to the spine that led to paralysis (victim’s injury was aggravated). In such a case, the good samaritan doctrine would apply and the person who tried to help, will not be charged under contributory negligence.

questions.text: A transgender person who has undergone a gender transformation from male to female would like to sound more like a female. Which of the following phonosurgeries would be advised in this case?
questions.solution:
Lengthening of the vocal cords is the phonosurgery to elevate the voice pitch which transforms male character voice to female.

If someone who has undergone gender transformation from female to male would like to lower the voice pitch, a phono surgery involving shortening/relaxation of the vocal cord is advised.

Type

Thyroplasty

Uses

I

Medialization

In complete palsy (superior and recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy)

II

Lateralization

In recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy

III

Shortening (relax the vocal cord)

To reduce pitch

IV

Lengthening (tighten the vocal cord)

To increase pitch

Note to remember: MLSL

questions.text: In the syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion, there is a sudden increase in the urine volume with a decrease in the urine osmolality, despite increased levels of vasopressin. This occurs due to _____.
questions.solution:
In the syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion, there is a sudden increase in the urine volume with a decrease in the urine osmolality, despite increased levels of vasopressin, called 'vasopressin escape'. This occurs due to the downregulation of aquaporin- 2 channel production. 

Increased secretion of ADH (antidiuretic hormone) can cause water retention and increased loss of sodium in the urine which results in dilutional hyponatremia. Prolonged exposure to increased ADH levels will lead to downregulation of the production of aquaporin 2 channels. This results in increased urine flow and a decrease in urine osmolality. It helps to reduce the degree of hyponatremia.

Other options

Option A: Stimulation of the V1A receptors will lead to vasoconstriction and increased glycogenolysis in the liver

Option B: Stimulation of V1B receptors (also called V3 receptors) will lead to increased secretion of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) from the corticotropes.

questions.text: You are an ENT resident evaluating a patient with a fracture of the zygoma. Which of the following findings would you not expect to see in this patient?
questions.solution:
CSF rhinorrhea is not seen in patients with fractures of the zygoma.

It has the following clinical features:

  • Flattening of malar prominence.
  • Step deformity of infraorbital margin.
  • Anesthesia in the distribution of the infraorbital nerve.
  • Trismus, due to depression of zygoma on the underlying coronoid process.
  • Oblique palpebral fissure, due to the displacement of lateral palpebral ligament.
  • Restricted ocular movements, due to entrapment of inferior rectus muscle. It may cause diplopia.
  • Periorbital emphysema, due to escape of air from the maxillary sinus on nose blowing.

The following x-ray shows a right-sided zygoma fracture:

questions.text: A patient presents with fever,  vomiting, and watery diarrhea. He gives a history of having consumed shellfish and raw seafood a day before, at a party. The causative agent showed hemolysis on Wagatsuma agar. Which of the following organisms is responsible for his presenting features?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with culture findings of hemolysis on Wagatsuma agar, is suggestive of infection with Vibrio parahaemolyticus.

V. parahaemolyticus causes food poisoning due to the consumption of contaminated seafood, after an incubation period of 12–24 hours. The common sources of infection are raw seafood like molluscs and crustaceans.

Clinically, patients present with nausea, vomiting, abdominal cramps, fever, and watery or bloody diarrhea. Fecal leukocytes are often seen in stool samples.

Enteritis subsides spontaneously in 1–3 days with no specific treatment. Adequate hydration and electrolyte balance should be restored.

V. parahaemolyticus is a capsulated bacterium. It shows bipolar staining and has a tendency to pleomorphism. It is characterized by peritrichous flagella on solid media and monotrichous on liquid media and gives a positive string test.

V. parahaemolyticus grows well on blood agar, where it is identified by its oxidase-positive growth. On thiosulfate-citrate-bile salts-sucrose (TCBS) agar, it produces green colonies, as shown in the image below.

Pathogenic strains of V. parahemolyticus are hemolytic on Wagatsuma agar, while non-pathogenic strains are non-hemolytic. This is called the Kanagawa phenomenon and is due to a heat-stable hemolysin.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman was diagnosed with focal seizures and was prescribed ezogabine. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
Ezogabine is a potassium channel opener.

Ezogabine (retigabine) acts by opening neuronal potassium channels. By opening the K+ channels, it stabilizes the resting membrane potential and reduces the excitability of the nerve membrane.

It is used as an adjunctive treatment for focal seizures.

Serious side effects associated with long-term therapy include retinal abnormalities causing visual defects, skin discoloration, QT prolongation, and neuropsychiatric symptoms.

Other options:

Option B: Vigabatrin irreversibly inhibits GABA transaminase, which degrades GABA. Thereby, resulting in increased levels of extracellular GABA at its receptor and enhanced inhibitory GABAergic transmission.

It is indicated in refractory focal seizures with impaired awareness and infantile spasms in tuberous sclerosis. Vigabatrin is associated with progressive and permanent bilateral visual loss.

Option C: Ethosuximide inhibits the T-type calcium currents in thalamic neurons. It is the first-line agent for the treatment of generalized absence seizures.

Option D: Tiagabine inhibits the GABA transporter GAT-1 and thereby reduces GABA uptake into neurons and glia and prolongs the action of GABA in the synapse. It is also used an adjunct therapy for focal seizures.

questions.text: A child's height is plotted against his age in years in the image given below. The final height attained is still less, when calculated using mid-parental height. His chronological age is equal to skeletal age. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of familial short stature. The characteristic features in favor of the diagnosis are a short stature, with a normal growth velocity, Skeletal age being equal to chronological age and a short final height.

The 2 types of normal variants of short stature are as follows:

  • Constitutional delay: Bone age < Chronological age
  • Familial short stature: Bone age = Chronological age

Bone age is more than chronological age in precocious puberty. Bone age is less than chronological age in constitutional delay, undernutrition, and systemic illness.

Note: The mid parental height is a child's projected adult height based on the heights of the parents. It helps to assess an individual's height based on genetic potential.

Related Pearl: Short stature: Familial vs Constitutional

Feature Constitutional Delay Familial Short Stature  
Height Short Short
Final Height Normal Short  
Family history Delayed puberty Short stature  
Bone age Less than chronological age Normal  
Puberty Delayed Normal  
Height velocity Normal Normal

questions.text: A female patient presents with repeated episodes of slashing her wrists and attempted suicide. She also has a history of unstable interpersonal relationships, impulsive decision taking, and intense episodic dysphoria. There is no history of depression. Which of the following is the psychotherapy of choice?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of borderline personality disorder. The psychotherapy of choice in this condition is dialectical behaviour therapy (DBT). 

A borderline personality disorder is characterized by extraordinarily unstable affect, mood, behaviour, object relations, and self-image. According to DSM-5, a diagnosis of borderline personality disorder can be made if at least 5 out of the following are shown by the patient:

  • Panicky efforts to avoid real or imagined abandonment
  • Unstable interpersonal relationships
  • Marked and persistently unstable self-image or sense of self
  • Impulsivity in at least two areas of potentially self-damaging like sex, substance abuse, reckless driving, binge eating, etc.
  • Repeated suicidal behaviour, gestures, threats, or self-mutilating behaviour
  • Instability in affect due to a marked reactivity of mood
  • Prolonged feeling of emptiness
  • Inappropriate, intense anger or difficulty in controlling anger
  • Transient stress-related paranoid ideation

DBT is currently the only empirically supported treatment for borderline personality disorder and is particularly effective for those with parasuicidal behaviour, such as frequent cutting.

Patients are seen weekly to improve interpersonal skills and to decrease self-destructive behaviour by using techniques involving advice, metaphor, storytelling, and confrontation.

DBT is influenced by the philosophical perspective of dialectics: "balancing opposites." It helps the individual find ways to hold two seemingly opposite perspectives at once, thereby promoting balance and avoiding the all-or-nothing style of thinking.

Other modalities of treatment include:

  • Mentalization-based treatment
  • Transference-focused psychotherapy
  • Drugs such as antipsychotics, antidepressants (SSRI, TCA), and mood-stabilizing drugs

questions.text: An assault victim is rushed to the emergency department with a stab wound. You observe that the wound is wedge-shaped. Which weapon would have most likely produced this wound?
questions.solution:
A wedge-shaped wound is produced by a single-edged knife. A double-edged knife produces an elliptical wound.

questions.text: A patient presents with visual impairment. On fundoscopy, you notice dark streaks having irregular, serrated edges and radiating outwards from the peripapillary area. Your professor explains it to you as breaks in a calcified Bruch's membrane. What is this phenomenon known as?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes angioid streaks. 

Angioid streaks are breaks in a brittle, thinned-out, and calcified Bruch's membrane; they are associated with the atrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE).

Angioid streaks are associated with the following:

  • Pseudoxanthoma elasticum—most common condition associated: Since it is a connective tissue disorder, all the elastic fibers in the body are affected, including those in Bruch's membrane.
  • Paget disease: Metabolic bone disorder is thought to cause these streaks by calcium binding to the elastin of Bruch's membrane, imparting brittleness and fragility.
  • Hemoglobinopathies such as sickle cell trait and disease and thalassemia: In these conditions, iron deposition imparts brittleness to Bruch's membrane.

Signs associated with angioid streaks include a greyish to dark red streak on fundoscopy radiating outwards from the peripapillary area. These streaks have irregular, serrated edges.

Treatment includes observation. If choroidal neovascularization develops, then intravitreal anti-VEGF drugs are preferred.

Other options:

Option B: Choroidal folds are horizontal parallel grooves or striae on the inner choroid, Bruch's membrane, and retinal pigment epithelium. They usually occur on the posterior pole. These folds develop as a result of choroidal congestion and scleral compression. They may be idiopathic in nature, or they may be caused by conditions like papilledema, retroorbital and choroidal tumors, or inflammations like posterior scleritis.

Option C: Lattice retinal degeneration is a type of retinal degeneration associated with breaks in the retina. It is characterized by white arborizing lines arranged in a lattice pattern. it is associated with retinal thinning and abnormal pigmentation.

Option D: Stargardt disease is characterized by the accumulation of lipofuscin within the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE). They are seen as numerous yellow-white round lesions on the RPE, which are usually confined to the posterior pole.

questions.text: A middle-aged obese man presents with a history of chest pain during exertion which lasted for around 5 minutes. He further describes his chest pain as a squeezing type of pain located in the substernal region and the pain was relieved by rest. At present, he does not have any such symptoms. The ECG obtained is given below. What will be the expected levels of his blood cardiac markers?

choices.text: Both CPK-MB and troponin-I will be elevated
Both CPK-MB and troponin-I will be normal

questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of stable angina, and the assessment of blood cardiac markers is expected to show normal levels of both CPK-MB and troponin-I. The ECG given is also normal because the patient does not have any symptoms at the time of presentation and is at rest.  

Characteristic features of pain in stable angina:

  • Squeezing, central, substernal discomfort
  • Crescendo-decrescendo in nature
  • Typically lasts 2 to 5 min
  • Can radiate occasionally to the neck, jaw, epigastrium, shoulders, and left arm

Angina is rarely localized below the umbilicus or above the mandible. Myocardial ischemic discomfort does not radiate to the trapezius muscles; this radiation pattern is more typical of pericarditis.

Features Stable angina Unstable angina
Pain
  • Squeezing, central, substernal discomfort
  • Crescendo-decrescendo pattern
  • Precipitated by exercise, cold weather, or emotional stress duration of 2–5 min
  • Same as stable angina but may be more severe
  • Crescendo pattern
  • Pain occurs at rest and may last up to 20 min

 

 
Pathology

Ischemia due to fixed stenosis

Unstable plaques causing dynamic obstruction
Predictability

Predictable

Unpredictable

  • ECG during exercise contraindicated
  • Coronary angiography recommended

  • ECG in exercise: ST-segment depression and ischemic T-waves

questions.text: An investigator was studying the effects of various poisons on the enzymes of the glycolytic pathway. He plotted the graph for the enzyme catalyzing the conversion of phosphoenolpyruvate to pyruvate after adding alanine, which is a non-competitive inhibitor. Which of the following graphs shows the effect caused by alanine?

choices.text: The type of plot will depend on the relative concentration of alanine and enzyme.

questions.solution:
Graph C represents non-competitive inhibition. The inhibition of pyruvate kinase by alanine is an example of non-competitive inhibition.

Non-competitive inhibition: When the substrate and the inhibitor are chemically not similar and have different shapes, the inhibitor binds away from the active site, i.e., at the allosteric site. This type of inhibition is known as non-competitive inhibition.

In non-competitive inhibition,

  • Vmax decreases.
  • Km remains constant.

In a Lineweaver-Burk Plot, the addition of a non-competitive inhibitor causes plots with the same x-intercept (Km is unaffected) but different slopes and y-intercepts.

Lineweaver-Burk plot is also known as the double reciprocal plot.

Competitive inhibition (graph A) - Here, the inhibitor is a structural analog of the substrate. Inhibitor molecules are competing with the normal substrate molecules for binding to the active site of the enzyme.

Uncompetitive inhibition (graph B) - Here, the inhibitor does not have any affinity for the free enzyme. The inhibitor binds to the enzyme-substrate complex, but not to the free enzyme. Here, both Vmax and Km are decreased. Inhibition of placental alkaline phosphatase (Regan isoenzyme) by phenylalanine is an example of uncompetitive inhibition.

Related Pearl: Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Reversible inhibitors are of two types:

  • Competitive inhibitors
  • Non-Competitive inhibitors

Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Competitive inhibitors

Non-Competitive inhibitors

Succinate dehydrogenase is inhibited by Malonate

Pyruvate kinase is inhibited by alanine

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically similar & have same shape

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically not similar & have different shape

Inhibitor binds to active site

Inhibitor binds away from active site, i.e., at allosteric site

Inhibitor does not change the shape of the active site

Inhibitor changes the shape of the active site

Increase in substrate concentration reduces the inhibition

Increase in substrate concentration does not affect the inhibition

Vmax remains constant

Vmax decreases

Km Increases

Km remains constant

questions.text: A woman gave birth to twins. Although a detailed evaluation revealed the same gestational age, the father believed that the children did not belong to him and requested DNA testing. After testing, it was found that one child did not belong to him. What is this case best described as?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario where twins have different fathers is suggestive of heteropaternal superfecundation.

Superfecundation is the fertilization of 2 different ova in the same menstrual cycle (as indicated by the same gestational age) by separate acts of coitus. It can also occur after artificial reproductive therapy. Hence, after embryo transfer, intercourse must be avoided. The term heteropaternal superfecundation refers to instances of two different males fathering fraternal twins. This implies that the twins are half-siblings. Such cases may give rise to doubts about adultery and infidelity. 

Other options -

Option A: In a spurious pregnancy(pseudocyesis, phantom pregnancy), a woman believes she is pregnant despite there being no actual pregnancy. It is a psychological disorder observed in infertile women, who have an intense desire for a child. These patients present with all subjective symptoms of pregnancy associated with an increase in the size of the abdomen. Obstetric examination and USG or immunological tests do not show any signs of pregnancy.

Option C: In feigned pregnancy, a woman feigns pregnancy after the death of her husband and later produces a child to claim property and compensation. This child is known as a supposititious child. 

Option D: Superfetation is the fertilization of 2 different ova released in different menstrual cycles (i.e. ovulation and fertilization during pregnancy). This can occur within 12 weeks of pregnancy, after which the decidual space is obliterated; a detailed evaluation will reveal disparities in gestational ages varying from 1-3 weeks.

Related Pearl: Uterine Signs in Pregnancy

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient is referred to a dermatologist for evaluation of vesicles and bullae and increased pigmentation over sun-exposed areas such as the dorsal aspect of the hands and forearms, legs and feet, neck, and face. On further evaluation, she is diagnosed with variegate porphyria. Deficiency of which of the following enzymes causes this disease?
questions.solution:
The cause of variegate porphyria is the deficiency of the enzyme protoporphyrinogen oxidase.

Variegate porphyria is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by a mutation in the PPOX gene, which results in either the deficiency or decreased function of the enzyme protoporphyrinogen oxidase. Protoporphyrinogen IX and other intermediates prior to the block accumulate in the urine. Patients are photosensitive.

Option B: Uroporphyrinogen I synthase deficiency is seen in acute intermittent porphyria.

Option C: ALA synthase 2 deficiency is seen in X-linked dominant protoporphyria.

Option D: ALA dehydratase deficiency is seen in amino levulinic acid dehydratase porphyria.

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl was brought by her mother, who is concerned that her daughter has not achieved menarche so far. The history is otherwise unremarkable. You find that her breast development and other secondary sexual characteristics are normal. How will you proceed with this case?

choices.text: Delay investigations until 16 years of age

questions.solution:
This 14-year-old girl has amenorrhea with normal secondary sexual characteristics. Hence, investigations may be delayed until the age of 16 years, and the patient can be reassured.

Primary amenorrhea is defined as the absence of menstruation by 14 years without the development of secondary sexual characteristics or by 16 years regardless of the presence of secondary sexual characteristics.

Investigations may be delayed in girls of 14 years in the presence of secondary sexual characteristics since delayed puberty is a possibility in such cases. However, further investigations must be done if the patient presents with any other features suggestive of a specific cause (like short stature in Turner's syndrome) or if there is the absence of secondary sexual characteristics at 14 years, or if her age is 16 years or more.

Investigation algorithm for amenorrhea:

Causes of primary amenorrhea:

  • Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism
    • Hypothalamic and pituitary dysfunction 
    • Kallmann's syndrome
    • CNS tumors - craniopharyngioma
    • Delayed puberty
  • Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism
    • Primary ovarian failure
    • Resistant ovarian failure
    • 17-alpha-hydroxylase deficiency
  • Chromosomal abnormalities
    • Turner's syndrome (45 X)
    • Pure gonadal dysgenesis (46 XX or 46 XY)
    • Androgen insensitivity syndrome (testicular feminization syndrome) (46 XY)
  • Developmental defect of the genital tract
    • Imperforate hymen
    • Transverse vaginal septum
    • Vaginal atresia/cervical atresia
    • Absent uterus in Mullerian agenesis (Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome)
  • Others:
    • Uterine synechiae (congenital)
    • Adrenogenital syndrome
    • Cretinism
    • Juvenile diabetes
    • Malnutrition
    • Anemia
    • Weight loss
    • Tuberculosis

questions.text: Which of the following virus does not belong to the Picornaviridae family?
questions.solution:
Hepatitis E does not belong to picornaviridae family. It belongs to Hepeviridae family.

Picornaviridae family can be divided into following genera:

  • Enterovirus: Poliovirus, Coxsackievirus A and B, and Echovirus
  • Rhinovirus
  • Hepatovirus: Hepatitis A virus.
  • Parechovirus
