questions.text: A patient is asked to perform a Valsalva maneuver for the relief of an ear block. Which of the following nerve innervates the main structure that helps in opening the eustachian tube during this maneuver?
questions.solution:
The tensor veli palatini muscle is the main muscle that helps in opening the eustachian tube during the Valsalva maneuver. This muscle is supplied by the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve.

The eustachian tube is closed at rest and opens intermittently during swallowing, yawning, and sneezing. The opening of the tube is done by the contraction of the medial fibers of the tensor veli palatini which are attached to the lateral lamina of the tube. It is also called the dilator tubae muscle. Accessory muscles for opening are levator veli palatine & salpingopharyngeus.

The closure of the tube is mainly due to the elastic recoil of the cartilage aided by the high degree of elastin on the roof. Ostmann’s pad of fat helps to keep the tube closed.

Muscles of the Eustachian tube and their nerve supply

Muscle

Nerve supply

Action

Tensor veli palatine/ Dilator tubae

Mandibular branch of trigeminal nerve

Opens the tube

Levator veli palatine

Pharyngeal plexus 

Opens & lifts the tube

Salpingopharyngeus

Pharyngeal plexus 

Opens the tube

Sensory & parasympathetic supply to ET: Glossopharyngeal Nerve

questions.text: A 31-year-old male patient presents with recurrent epigastric pain, weight loss, and diarrhea. On investigation, his serum protein level was found to be low. An endoscopy was done, and an image obtained when the scope was in the stomach is shown below. The gastric aspirate showed a decrease in the acid content of the stomach. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows the presence of hypertrophied gastric mucosal folds, which are characteristic of Menetrier disease.

Menetrier disease is characterized by gross hypertrophy of the gastric mucosal folds, protein-losing gastropathy, and hypochlorhydria.

This disease is caused by the overexpression of TGF- alpha, which increases the growth of mucous cells. The increased number of mucous cells leads to giant rugal folds. The resulting excessive production of mucous in the stomach causes an increased loss of proteins and chloride from the body.

Patients with Menetrier disease usually present with diarrhea, hypoproteinemia, and anemia.

Some patients may respond to cetuximab (a monoclonal antibody against EGFR). Severe cases require a gastrectomy.

Gastric antral vascular ectasia (option C) shows the presence of parallel red stripes over the gastric mucosa (watermelon stomach).

questions.text: A diabetic patient sustained an abrasion wound while working in the field. After a few days, he presents with fever, hemoptysis, and upper lobe pneumonitis, along with a suppurative infection of the wound. Findings of staining and microscopy of samples from the exudate are shown below. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with the microscopic finding of gram-negative bacilli with a typical bipolar safety-pin appearance is characteristic of melioidosis.

Melioidosis is also known as Whitmore's disease. It is caused by Burkholderia pseudomallei. Infection is acquired by the contamination of abrasion wounds with soil and water containing the bacilli. Patients with underlying diseases like diabetes mellitus have an increased risk of acquiring the infection.

Clinically, melioidosis presents in two forms.

  • Acute - It causes acute pneumonia with upper lobe infiltrates or severe necrotizing disease. It can also mimic tuberculosis with fever, cough, and hemoptysis. It may lead to septicemia. Acute cases have a high case-fatality rate. 
  • Chronic - It can lead to the development of multiple caseous or suppurative foci, with skin and subcutaneous abscesses. These can lead to lymphangitis and lymphadenopathy. It may involve bones and other internal organs.

On microscopy, small, irregularly staining, gram-negative bacilli can be demonstrated for diagnosis. Methylene blue stain shows a typical bipolar safety pin appearance. ELISA for IgM and IgG antibody, indirect hemagglutination can be also used for diagnosis. Ashdown medium is a culture selective for B. pseudomallei.

The image below shows dry purple-colored wrinkled colonies of B. pseudomallei cultured in Ashdown medium.

Treatment is divided into two stages. An intensive phase of 2 weeks of therapy with ceftazidime (drug of choice) or a carbapenem. This is followed by  12 weeks of oral cotrimoxazole to eradicate the organism and prevent relapse.

Other options:

Option B: Chlamydia psittaci causes psittacosis. Psittacosis can cause mild illness or pneumonia.

Option C: Burkholderia mallei cause glanders disease. It is a gram-negative, irregularly staining bacillus with a beaded appearance. It is usually an equine infection. Human infection is possible and is usually occupational, found among veterinarians and those looking after horses. Acute infection presents with fever, mucopurulent nasal discharge, and severe prostration.

Option D: Burkholderia cepacia causes cepacia syndrome. It is rapidly fatal septicemia in cystic fibrosis patients.

Related Pearl: Common names of various bacteria

List of common names and scientific names of medically important bacteria:

Common name Scientific name
Klebs-Loffler bacillus Corynebacterium diphtheria
Koch week bacillus Haemophilus aegypticus
Tubercle or Koch bacillus Mycobacterium tuberculosis
Hansen’s bacillus Mycobacterium leprae
Eaton agent Mycoplasma pneumonia
Pfeiffer’s bacillus Haemophilus influenza
Friedlander’s bacillus Klebsiella pneumoniae
Glander’s Bacillus Burkholderia mallei
Whitmore Bacillus Burkholderia pseudomallei

questions.text: Masaoka staging system is used for which tumor?
questions.solution:
Masaoka staging system is used for staging thymoma. It is based on the presence or absence of metastasis and gross or microscopic invasion of the capsule and surrounding structures. 

Masaoka staging system for thymoma:

Stage

Features

Stage I

Encapsulated tumor with no gross or microscopic evidence of capsular invasion

Stage II

Gross capsular invasion or invasion into the mediastinal fat or pleura or microscopic capsular invasion

Stage III

Gross invasion into the pericardium, great vessels, or lung

Stage IVA

Pleural or pericardial dissemination

Stage IVB

Lymphogenous or hematogenous metastasis

Management of Thymoma:

Stage I - complete surgical excision only

Stage II & III - complete surgical excision followed by radiotherapy

Stage IV & metastatic disease - neoadjuvant chemotherapy + surgery + postoperative radiotherapy

questions.text: Match the following mammogram images with their diagnoses.

choices.text: 1- Duct ectasia  2- Malignancy  3- Traumatic fat necrosis   4- Fibroadenoma
1- Traumatic fat necrosis   2- Fibroadenoma  3- Malignancy  4-Duct ectasia
1- Fibroadenoma   2- Traumatic fat necrosis   3- Duct ectasia   4- Malignancy
1- Malignancy  2- Duct ectasia  3- Fibroadenoma   4-Traumatic fat necrosis

questions.solution:
The correct match is:

1- Traumatic fat necrosis 
2- Fibroadenoma 
3- Malignancy
4- Duct ectasia

Egg-shell calcification or lead pipe calcification is seen in traumatic fat necrosis. Usually seen with a  previous history of surgery or trauma. There are egg-shell calcifications in the wall of an oil cyst or as coarse dystrophic calcifications with scarring. 


Popcorn calcification is seen in fibroadenoma. These are the most common benign masses of the breast. On mammograms, they present as rounded or oval masses with coarse calcifications (popcorn calcifications) as shown in the image below.


Breast malignancies appear as ill-defined spiculated masses with microcalcifications as shown in the image below.


Duct ectasias present with broken needle calcifications. This occurs due to the calcification of debris within dilated ducts. Most of the time, these are bilateral.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a history of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)  presents with burning pain in the retrosternal region. An upper GI endoscopic biopsy sample taken from the lower part of the esophagus showed the presence of glandular columnar epithelium. What does this finding denote?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of intestinal-type metaplasia seen in Barrett's esophagus. Metaplasia is defined as the replacement of one type of cell with another type.

In Barrett's esophagus, the normal squamous epithelium of the esophagus is replaced by glandular columnar epithelium and goblet cells. Goblet cells are diagnostic of Barrett's esophagus. It is a complication of chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease.

The table below shows various types of metaplasia:

Tissue Metaplasia
Airways Squamous metaplasia: Normal pseudostratified epithelium is replaced by the squamous epithelium. The condition may occur due to chronic smoking.   Also, a deficiency of retinoic acid may cause squamous metaplasia.
Urinary bladder Squamous metaplasia: The presence of bladder stones may trigger metaplasia, where the normal transitional epithelium is replaced by squamous epithelium.
Esophagus Columnar metaplasia: In patients with chronic GERD, the normal squamous epithelium of the esophagus is replaced by the glandular columnar epithelium (Barrett's esophagus)
Cervix Squamous metaplasia: Due to the low pH of the cervix, the normal glandular epithelium may be replaced by the squamous epithelium.
Muscle Connective tissue metaplasia: In some cases, after intramuscular hemorrhage, there may be the formation of bone in the muscle tissue; the condition is known as myositis ossificans.

 

Anaplasia refers to the lack of differentiation that is seen in neoplastic cells. 

Dysplasia refers to disordered growth. It is encountered principally in epithelia and is characterized by a loss in the uniformity of the individual cells and a loss in their architectural orientation. Dysplasia may be a precursor to malignant transformation, but it does not always progress to cancer.

Related Pearl: Various Types of Epithelium, Their Location and Functions

questions.text: A farmer presents with lesions on his hand as seen in the image below. He gives a history of a thorn prick a few days ago. Histological examination of the lesion showed sclerotic bodies. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the image showing warty lesions on the hand and the presence of sclerotic bodies suggests the diagnosis of chromoblastomycosis.

Chromoblastomycosis is a type of subcutaneous mycoses caused by fungi of the genus Fonsecae and Cladophialophora. It can cause different patterns of lesions like verrucous, nodular, cicatricial, ulcerated, and tumorous.

The diagnosis can be established by the demonstration of yeast-like sclerotic bodies on KOH mount or by culture on Sabouraud agar.

The image given below shows sclerotic bodies seen in chromoblastomycosis.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: A  couple married for 11 years lives with their 9-year-old son. What type of family is this?
questions.solution:
The type of family described in the given scenario is a nuclear family. 

Types of families:

  • A nuclear family or elementary family consists of only the married couple and their offspring while they are dependants.
  • The term new family is applied when nuclear families are younger than 10 years and consist of parents and children.
  • A joint family or extended family consists of a number of married couples and their children who live together in the same household with usually the men being related by blood. All property in joint families is held in common with the family income going into a common pocket. A senior male member is usually the head of the family who makes decisions.
  • A three-generation family is one where there are representatives from three different generations in one house.
  • A communal family is one in which all the members play a part in its management.

Related Pearl: The Family as a Social Organization

  • A family is a group of biologically related individuals living together under the same roof and eating from a common kitchen.
  • It is the most primary and basic unit of all societies.
  • The basic and arbitrary model of a family cycle has six phases:

 

Phase

Beginning

End

1

Formation

Marriage

Birth of 1st child

2

Extension

Birth of 1st child

Birth of last child

3

Complete extension

Birth of last child

1st child leaves home

4

Contraction

1st child leaves home

Last child leaves parental home

5

Completed contraction

Last child leaves parental home

Death of 1st spouse

6

Dissolution

Death of 1st spouse

Death of survivor
  • Types of families:
    • A nuclear family or elementary family consists of only the married couple and their offspring while they are dependants.
    • The term new family is applied when nuclear families are younger than 10 years and consist of parents and children.
    • A joint family or extended family consists of a number of married couples and their children who live together in the same household with usually the men being related by blood. All property in joint families is held in common with the family income going into a common pocket. A senior male member is usually the head of the family who makes decisions.
    • A three generation family is one where there are representatives from three different generations in one house.
    • A communal family is one in which all the members play a part in its management.
  • Functions of the family:
    • Residence (patrilocal and matrilocal)
    • Division of labour
    • Reproduction and raising children
    • Socialization and social care
    • Economic functions
  • Problems families are those that lag behind the rest of the community in terms of standard and quality of life of its members.
  • Broken families are those in which the parental or family system has been disrupted by separation, divorce or death.

questions.text: During dissection, the anatomy professor teaches about the spaces of the upper limb. He asks the students to look below a muscle, and observe a quadrangular space with the axillary nerve as one of its contents.  Which muscle is he talking about?
questions.solution:
The muscle he is talking about is the teres minor. It forms the superior boundary of the quadrangular space hence below it lies the quadrangular space with the axillary nerve passing through it. 

Quadrangular space (Foramen of Velpeau- QS)

Formed by:

  • Anteriorly: Subscapularis
  • Superiorly: Capsule of the shoulder joint, teres minor
  • Inferiorly: Teres major
  • Medially: Long head of triceps
  • Laterally: Surgical neck of humerus

Content:

  • Axillary nerve
  • Posterior circumflex humeral artery and vein

Boundaries and contents of other spaces around the shoulder joint:

Triangular space (TS) (Upper triangular space):

Boundaries:

  • Superiorly: Subscapularis anteriorly, teres minor posteriorly
  • Laterally: Long head of triceps
  • Inferiorly: Teres major

Contents: 

  •  Circumflex scapular artery

Triangular interval (TI) (Lower triangular space):

Boundaries:

  • Superiorly: Subscapularis anteriorly, teres major posteriorly
  • Medially: Long head of triceps
  • Laterally: Humerus

Contents:

  • Radial nerve
  • Profunda brachii vessels

Note: Radial nerve injury results in wrist drop.

An easy way to remember these spaces is to represent your 4 fingers as structures around the 3 spaces as shown below.

questions.text: A 14-month-old infant fell from the stairs while trying to walk. The parents noticed a swelling in the right thigh and brought the child to the casualty ward. A radiograph revealed a mid-shaft femur fracture. Traction was applied as shown. Identify the skin traction.
questions.solution:
The image shown above is that of Gallows traction.

Gallows traction is used in fracture shaft of femur in children less than 2 years of age. Here skin traction is applied to both legs which are then suspended from a frame, providing just enough traction to keep the buttocks of the child just off the bed.

Other options:

Option B: Russell’s traction or Thomas splint is used to treat fractured femur. After 2–4 weeks, when the fracture has sufficiently progressed, it is replaced by hip spica.

Option C: Perkins' traction is used to treat fractures of the shaft femur in adults. Where a pin is inserted at 3 cm distal to the tibial tuberosity and traction is applied using one Bohler stirrup or two Thomas pin mounts.

Option D: Smith’s traction is used in the supracondylar fracture of the humerus.

Related Pearl: Some Important Traction and Their Uses

1) Gallow/Bryant traction: 

  • Type - Skin traction 
  • Use - Fracture shaft femur in children below 2 years

2) Perkin traction: 

  • Type - Skeletal traction 
  • Use - Fracture shaft femur in adults

3) Russell’s traction: 

  • Type - Skin traction 
  • Use - Trochanteric fractures

4) Dunlop/Smith traction: 

  • Type - Skeletal traction 
  • Use - Supracondylar fracture humerus

5) Buck's traction: 

  • Most common lower limb traction
  • Type - Skin traction 
  • Use - Femoral fractures, acetabular and hip fractures

6)Crutchfield traction: 

  • Type - Skeletal traction 
  • Use - Cervical spine injuries

7) Head halter traction: 

  • Type - Skin traction 
  • Use - Cervical spine injuries

8) Halo-pelvic traction: 

  • Type - Skeletal traction 
  • Use - Scoliosis

questions.text: A Pap smear was done for a woman with vulval warts and the following cells were noticed on microscopic examination. What are these cells called?
questions.solution:
The cells seen in the image have large hyperchromatic nuclei and a perinuclear halo, which is suggestive of koilocytes. These are seen in infections with human papillomavirus (HPV), which cause vulval warts.

HPV causes structural changes in the epithelial cells of the skin. These abnormal epithelial cells are called koilocytes, and their presence is characteristic of HPV infection. The koilocytes have large hyperchromatic nuclei and a perinuclear halo, as shown below:


Genital warts/ venereal warts/ condyloma acuminata are verrucous growths that affect the skin of the labia majora, perineum, perianal region, and vulva. The lesions may be discrete or coalesce to form cauliflower-like growth. The disease is sexually transmitted. The growth of the warts is favored by vaginal discharge, the use of oral contraceptives, and pregnancy.

The diagnosis is made by colposcopic studies. The lesions on the vulva are stained by toluidine blue. The abnormal areas of the skin retain the blue dye. These areas are then biopsied for histopathological examination.

Treatment: 

  • Local application of podophyllin 25% in alcohol or podophyllin 20% in tincture benzoin or podophyllin cream
  • 25% trichloracetic acid plus 5% fluorouracil
  • Diathermy loop, laser ablation, cryotherapy for larger lesions
  • Surgical excision
  • Interferon ointment or local injection

Other options:

Option B: Clue cells are epithelial cells with a fuzzy border due to the adherence of bacteria. These are seen in bacterial vaginosis.

Option C: Tadpole cells are seen with invasive cancer. These are usually seen along with other malignant cells, hemorrhage, and necrosis in the background.

Option D: Parabasal cells are seen in a normal Pap smear. They are small, round, and basophilic with large nuclei.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient was diagnosed to be a case of colorectal cancer. On further evaluation, he was found to have desmoid tumours, epidermoid cysts and osteoma of the mandible. Genetic studies revealed APC gene mutation. What could be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and APC gene mutation are suggestive of Gardner's syndrome(a variant of Familial adenomatous polyposis).

Gardner's syndrome is an autosomal dominant disease variant of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) caused by an abnormal APC gene on Chromosome 5. 

Components

  • Colorectal polyps
  • Osteomas of the jaw or skull
  • Epidermoid cysts
  • Soft tissue tumours like desmoid tumours

Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is defined clinically by the presence of more than 100 colorectal adenomas but is also characterised by duodenal adenomas and multiple extraintestinal manifestations. The lifetime risk of developing colorectal carcinoma in these patients is 100%. 

The aim of surgery in FAP is to prevent the development of colorectal cancer. The surgical options are:

  1. Colectomy with ileorectal anastomosis (IRA);

  2. Restorative proctocolectomy with an ileal pouch-anal anastomosis (RPC);

  3. Total proctectomy and end ileostomy.

The treatment of the FAP includes total proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis (IPAA).

Other Options:

Option A: If a brain tumor arises in a patient with either HNPCC or FAP, then the patient is considered to have Turcot syndrome.

Option B: Hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC)/ Lynch syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition caused by a mutation in one of the DNA mismatch repair genes. The most commonly affected genes are MLH1 and MSH2. It is characterised by an increased risk of colorectal cancer and also cancers of the endometrium, ovary, stomach and small intestine. 

Option D: Peutz-Jegher's syndrome is an autosomal dominant disease characterized by hyperpigmentation of the mouth and lips, and multiple hamartomatous polyps in the small and large intestines.

Related Pearl: Features of Familial Adenomatous Polyposis

Gastrointestinal manifestations:

  • Colon and rectum: Multiple adenomatous polyps usually >100
  • Gastric and duodenal polyps are present
  • Gastric polyp: fundal gland polyp, gastric adenoma
  • Duodenal polyp usually in the ampullary region: Adenomatous and premalignant

Extraintestinal manifestations

  • Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE) is seen. It is detected by indirect ophthalmoscopy.
  • Epidermoid cysts
  • Desmoid tumors in the abdomen
  • Osteoma in the skull, mandible, and tibia
  • Brain tumors
  • Tumors of the thyroid, adrenal, liver, pancreas, gallbladder, and bile duct

Related Pearl: Classification of colorectal polyps

Colorectal polyps can be classified as:

Neoplastic

Adenomatous polyps:

  • Tubular adenoma (Most common)
  • Tubulovillous adenomas
  • Villous adenoma (highest risk of malignancy)

Non-neoplastic:

  • Hyperplastic
  • Hamartomatous
    • Juvenile polyp(solitary)-benign
    • Juvenile polyposis syndromes (multiple)-premalignant
    • Peutz-Jeghers syndrome- occasionally carcinoma may develop.
    • Cronkite-Canada syndrome*
  • Inflammatory
    • Pseudopolyp
    • Benign lymphoid polyp

Note:

*Cronkite-Canada syndrome: Cancer occurs in the stomach, colon, and rectum, but it remains controversial whether these polyps  possess malignant potential. As many as 15% of patients with Cronkite- Canada syndrome have a malignant tumor at the time of diagnosis

questions.text: A one-and-a-half-year-old baby is brought to the emergency ward with a generalized tonic-clonic seizure that has lasted for 20 mins without regaining consciousness. The baby is stabilized and then administered intravenous lorazepam. Despite 2 doses, the seizure continues. Which drug is to be given next?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is that of status epilepticus (SE). The drug that is to be administered after lorazepam is IV fosphenytoin.

SE is characterized as ongoing convulsive activity or recurring generalized convulsive seizure activity without recovering consciousness. According to the new definition of SE, two time frames have been defined for each type of seizure. They are called t1 and t2. t1 is the time to reflect as to when the treatment should be initiated and t2 is the time at which continuous seizure activity will lead to long-term complications.

In generalized tonic-clonic seizures, t1 is 5 min and t2 is 30 min. The initial choice of therapy is a benzodiazepine, which includes either of the following:

  • Intravenous lorazepam
  • Intravenous diazepam 
  • Intramuscular midazolam- If IV access is not available

If the seizure still continues, we can repeat the above dose once again. If there is no response even after repeat doses, then a single dose of either of the antiepileptics can be given,

  • Intravenous fosphenytoin 
  • Intravenous valproic acid 
  • Intravenous levetiracetam 

The image given below depicts the management of this condition in a flowchart:

questions.text:
The following is the histopathological image of anaplastic carcinoma of the thyroid. What change would be observed in the neoplastic cells present in it compared to the normal cells?

N/C ratio=Nuclear cytoplasmic ratio
questions.solution:
Increased N/C ratio is a feature of neoplastic cells. The nuclei are disproportionately large for the cell. In normal cells, the nuclear-cytoplasmic ratio is 1:4, whereas it becomes 1:1 in malignant cells.

Other morphological features of malignancy:

  • Pleomorphism: Variation in the size and shape of the cells.
  • Increased N/C ratio: The nuclei are disproportionately large for the cell. In normal cells, the nuclear-cytoplasmic ratio is 1:4, whereas it becomes 1:1 in malignant cells.
  • Hyperchromasia: Coarsely clumped and darkly stained chromatin within irregular nuclei.
  • Increased mitosis: Atypical, bizarre mitotic figures, sometimes with tripolar, quadripolar, or multipolar spindles.
  • Loss of polarity: There is disruption of orientation of anaplastic cells with respect to each other or to supporting structures. Sheets or large masses of tumor cells grow in a disorganized fashion. 
  • Anaplasia: Lack of differentiation.

questions.text: The engaging diameter of the fetal skull in brow presentation is _____.
questions.solution:
The engaging diameter of the fetal skull in brow presentation is mento-vertical.

Mento-vertical diameter is the largest diameter of the fetal skull, at 14 cm.

Diameters of fetal skull

Diameters Measurement in cm (inches) Attitude of the head Presentation
Suboccipitobregmatic 9.5 cm Complete flexion  Vertex 
Suboccipito-frontal 10 cm Incomplete flexion  Vertex 
Occipitofrontal 11.5 cm Marked deflexion  Vertex 
Mento-vertical 14 cm Partial extension  Brow 
Submentovertical 11.5 cm Incomplete extension  Face 
Submentobregmatic 9.5 cm Complete extension  Face 

Related Pearl: Fetal Skull Dimensions

Note: 

Shortest diameters of fetal skull: Bimastoid - 7.5 cm (doesn't engage) < Bitemporal - 8 cm

Longest diameter of fetal skull: Mentovertical 14 cm > Submentovertical / occipitofrontal - 11.5cm

questions.text: A child with a high risk of amblyopia is planned for surgical correction of unilateral simple congenital ptosis. He has poor levator function. What is the treatment of choice in this case?
questions.solution:
Frontalis sling procedure is the treatment of choice for congenital ptosis with poor levator function.

questions.text: A newborn presents with bilious vomiting and bloody stools a few days after birth. An upper GI contrast study revealed midgut volvulus due to intestinal malrotation. The image below is a diagrammatic representation of the findings of the contrast study. Identify the defective mechanism.
questions.solution:
The given diagram shows the transverse colon lying behind the superior mesenteric artery and the duodenum, indicating reversed rotation of the midgut loop. Only the 1st rotation occurring in a clockwise direction (instead of the normal anticlockwise) is the defective mechanism.

Midgut rotation: The mechanism of midgut rotation is given and represented in the image below. 

The midgut, once formed, lies outside the abdominal cavity and has to rotate and enter the abdominal cavity. When viewed ventrally, this rotation occurs for 270° in an anti-clockwise direction with the axis formed by the superior mesenteric artery. The artery divides the intestinal loop into a pre-arterial and post-arterial segment.

The total rotation can be divided into three stages of 90° each:

Stage 1/1st rotation - Initially, the loop lies in the sagittal plane, the pre-arterial segment cranial, and the post-arterial segment caudal. The first 90° anticlockwise rotation results in the pre-arterial segment lying on the right and the post-arterial segment lying on the left of the axis.

Stage 2/2nd rotation - The pre-arterial segment undergoes lengthening to form coils of the jejunum and ileum. The second 90° anticlockwise rotation results in the coils of the jejunum and ileum lying behind the superior mesenteric artery and occupying the posterior left half of the abdominal cavity. As a result, the duodenum also lies behind the artery.

Stage 3/3rd rotation -  In this stage, the post-arterial segment enters the abdominal cavity with the last 90° anticlockwise rotation, resulting in the transverse colon lying in front of the superior mesenteric artery and the cecum lying on the right in the abdominal cavity, just below the liver. The cecum gradually descends to its final location in the right iliac fossa.

Other options:

Option B: Only the 1st rotation occurring only in an anti-clockwise direction presents with the colon and cecum in the left and small intestine on the right, resulting in a left-sided colon.

Option C: Absence of the 3rd rotation and failure of the descent of cecum can result in a sub-hepatic cecum.

Option D: Absence of the 2nd rotation results in the pre-arterial segment lying on the right and the post-arterial segment lying on the left of the axis.

questions.text: A middle-aged man with heart failure was started on a combination of sacubitril and valsartan. Which of the following is true regarding this drug combination?

choices.text: Lowers the levels of natriuretic peptides and increases the blood pressure
Lowers the levels of natriuretic peptides and lowers the blood pressure
Increases the levels of natriuretic peptides and increases the blood pressure
Increases the levels of natriuretic peptides and lowers the blood pressure

questions.solution:
The combination of sacubitril and valsartan increases the levels of natriuretic peptides and lowers blood pressure.

Sacubitril is combined with valsartan to treat heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF). Sacubitril is a neprilysin inhibitor. It reduces the breakdown of natriuretic peptides such as ANP, BNP, and CNP, thereby increasing their levels. Valsartan is an angiotensin receptor blocker, which lowers blood pressure. 

The drug combination is referred to as an angiotensin receptor–neprilysin inhibitor. It lowers vascular resistance and increases blood flow. It should not be used with an ACE inhibitor or when there is a history of angioedema during ACE inhibitor or ARB use.

questions.text: A patient with a history of chronic alcohol use was brought to the emergency room after a fall. On neurological examination, he had reduced coordination, an ataxic gait, dysarthria, and tremors. Despite initiating treatment for alcohol withdrawal and detoxification, his symptoms persisted. An MRI of his brain revealed the following finding. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the MRI showing sandwich sign of corpus callosum is suggestive of Marchiafava-Bignami disease (MBD).

MBD is a rare, idiopathic central nervous system disorder seen as a complication of chronic alcoholism. Early symptoms may include depression, paranoia, psychosis, or dementia. Seizures, hemiparesis, aphasia, abnormal movements, and ataxia are also seen. If not promptly identified and treated, the condition may progress to coma and death.

It is associated with central degeneration of the corpus callosum, sparing the dorsal and ventral parts. This characteristic pattern of degeneration presents as the sandwich sign, best visualized on sagittal MRI of the brain. 

Clinically, conditions such as Wernicke’s encephalopathy, delirium tremens, or pontine demyelination may have similar presentations and their features may overlap. Hence neuroimaging plays a significant role in the accurate diagnosis of MB disease.

Ophthalmoplegia and involvement of mamillary bodies and medial thalamic nuclei are associated with Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, not MBD.

The sagittal MRI image given below shows the characteristic sandwich sign in Marchiafava Bignami disease.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with GERD has no improvement after long-term medical therapy. He underwent surgical treatment for GERD. Identify the procedure.
questions.solution:
The procedure in the given image shows a 360-degree wrap, which is known as Nissen's fundoplication; this procedure is done for GERD. Nissen's fundoplication is a complete fundoplication procedure.

Fundoplication is the procedure in which the fundus of the stomach is wrapped around the lower end of the esophagus. In the Nissen's fundoplication procedure, the fundus is wrapped the entire 360 degrees around the esophagus. 

The most common complication of Nissen’s fundoplication is the gas-bloat syndrome. In this condition, patients are unable to belch gas from the stomach into the oesophagus. This causes increased gas in the stomach, resulting in a bloating sensation, abdominal discomfort, and flatulence.

Other options:

Option A: The toupet procedure is the re-creation of a sphincter around the EGJ done by wrapping the fundus around the oesophagus. A posterior 180-270-degree wrap is used.

Option B: The Dor procedure is fundoplication, most commonly used in the setting of the esophagal myotomy. It consists of an anterior 180-degree wrap.

Option C: Watson's fundoplication is a 90-degree anterior fundoplication. It is reported to achieve good reflux control while permitting burping and active vomiting and reducing gas bloat.

Related Pearl: Types of Fundoplication

Types of fundoplication

Degree of wrap

Thal

Toupet

questions.text: An HIV patient presents with persistent diarrhea. Microscopic examination of the stool reveals oocysts containing 2 sporocysts, each having two sporozoites, as shown in the image below. Identify the causative organism.
questions.solution:
Diarrhea in an HIV patient is suggestive of a coccidian (one-celled) parasitic infestation. Kinyoun stain–positive oocysts that are round, with 2 sporocysts, and each sporocyst having two sporozoites, as seen in the given image, are findings suggestive of Cyclospora.

Points in favor:

  • HIV patient with diarrhea
  • Oocysts are round, size of 8–12 μm, containing 2 sporocysts, each having two sporozoites which are variably acid-fast on staining.

The image given below shows the presence of four modified acid-fast stain-positive Cyclospora cayetanensis oocysts in the field of view. Note that the staining is variable among the four oocysts.

Treatment of Cyclospora infection includes fluid replacement and cotrimoxazole.

Other options:

Comparison of coccidian parasites causing diarrhea in an immunocompromised host:

Property  Cryptosporidium Cyclospora Isospora
Sporulated oocyst 4-6μm, round contains four sporozoites 8-12 μm, round contains 2 sporocysts each having two sporozoites 23-36 μm, oval contains two sporocysts, each having four sporozoites.
Acid-fast detection  Uniformly acid-fast Variable acid-fast Uniformly acid-fast
Sporulation of the oocyst Occurs inside the host cell Occurs in soil Occurs in soil
Diagnostic form Sporulated cyst Unsporulated cyst Unsporulated oocyst


The image given below demonstrates uniformly acid-fast oocysts of Cryptosporidium parvum.


The image given below shows the uniformly acid-fast, large, oval oocysts of Isospora belli.


Microspora spp. are unicellular, obligate intracellular parasites causing opportunistic illnesses, such as protracted diarrhea, in immunocompromised patients. They produce spores (not oocyst), which are the infective stage of microsporidia. Spores are 2–4 μm in size and oval to cylindrical in shape, with a polar filament. Spores are gram-positive and acid-fast.

questions.text: A 54-year-old male patient presented with quadriparesis for 6 months. Symptoms began as dysarthria and a stiff tongue, lower limb weakness which progressed to all four limbs. Bilateral extensor plantar response, exaggerated reflexes, fasciculations, and severe muscle atrophy are present. Bladder, bowel, and sensory functions are intact. Which of the following is used in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and riluzole is used in its treatment.

Progressive upper motor neuron (UMN) palsy (exaggerated reflexes, extensor plantar), lower motor neuron (LMN) palsy (muscle weakness, atrophy, fasciculations), and pseudobulbar palsy (dysarthria, tongue spasticity), with normal bladder, bowel and sensory function are suggestive of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).

Treatment:

  1. Riluzole acts by reducing excitotoxicity by diminishing glutamate release. It lengthens the survival of the patient. Side effects are minimal that include nausea, vomiting, dizziness, and elevated liver enzymes occasionally. 
  2. Edaravone (IV infusion) works in the central nervous system as a potent scavenger of oxygen radicals and is a newer drug that has the capability of slowing down ALS progression and improving survival.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is the most common form of progressive motor neuron disease. Genetic mutations in genes encoding cytosolic enzyme SOD1 (superoxide dismutase). The pathologic hallmark of motor neuron degenerative disorders is the death of lower motor neurons (consisting of anterior horn cells in the spinal cord and their brainstem homologs innervating bulbar muscles) and upper, or corticospinal, motor neurons (originating in layer five of the motor cortex and descending via the pyramidal tract to synapse with lower motor neurons, either directly or indirectly via interneurons).

Although at its onset, ALS may involve selective loss of function of only upper or lower motor neurons, it ultimately causes progressive loss of both categories of motor neurons.

Even in the late stages of ALS, sensory, bowel & bladder functions are preserved.

Clinical features:

  • LMN lesion: Fasciculations, muscle cramps, weakness, atrophy, and bulbar palsy
  • UMN lesion: Spasticity, increased reflexes, flexor spasms, and pseudobulbar palsy
  • Another frequent bulbar UMN symptom is the syndrome of the pseudobulbar effect. This is manifested as inappropriate laughing, crying, or yawning. 

Other options:

Option A- Tetrabenazine is a reversible VMAT2 inhibitor that depletes presynaptic catecholamines. It is used for chorea in Huntington's disease. The dosage is adjusted when it is given with CYP2D6 inhibitors like paroxetine, fluoxetine, bupropion as they decrease the metabolism of tetrabenazine. Adverse effects include hypotension and depression. 

Option B- Memantine acts by reducing excitotoxicity through use-dependent blockade of NMDA receptors. It is used in cases of moderate to severe Alzheimer's disease.

Option D- Rivastigmine is a carbamate derivative of physostigmine. It inhibits predominantly acetyl choline esterase enzyme (AChE). It is prescribed in cases of mild-moderate cases of Alzheimer's disease.

questions.text: An ICDS officer visits an Anganwadi center and explains to the workers about the program associated with the logo shown below. Identify the incorrect statements about the targets of the program.

choices.text: To reduce stunting at a rate of 2% per annum
To reduce LBW at a rate of 3% per annum
To reduce undernutrition at a rate of 2% per annum
To reduce prevalence of anemia at a rate of 3% per annum

questions.solution:
The image shown below is the logo of POSHAN Abhiyaan/ National Nutrition Mission (NNM). The incorrect statement about the target of this program is to reduce LBW at a rate of 3% per annum. LBW incidence should be reduced at a rate of 2% per annum (6% in three years), as per the goals of the program.

The goal is to achieve an improvement in the nutritional status during the next three years, beginning 2017-18. It is a flagship program of the Ministry of Women and Child Development (MWCD).

The target population of this program:

  • Children from 0 to 6 years
  • Adolescent girls
  • Pregnant women
  • Lactating mothers 

The following image depicts the targets of this mission:

Note: Nikshay Poshan Yojana is a government scheme in India to provide TB patients 500 rupees per month to buy food.

Initially, the scheme was targeted for three years until March 2021; later, the government clubbed various programs with similar objectives, such as the Supplementary Nutrition Programme and POSHAN Abhiyaan under one umbrella– Mission POSHAN 2.0—for the establishment of integrated nutritional services.

The National Nutrition Week is an annual event observed from 1st to 7th September every year; it has been initiated by the Food and Nutrition Board. The main objective of this even is to raise awareness regarding the importance of nutrition for health, which has an impact on development, productivity, economic growth, and ultimately national development.

questions.text: Two brothers were arguing over a property dispute when the elder of the two suddenly complained of chest pain. He was brought to the hospital. His family members reported that he was previously healthy and that there were no similar diseases in the family members. Echocardiography was done; the image below shows the findings. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of sudden chest pain in a previously healthy man under a stressful situation is suggestive of takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is also called broken heart syndrome, apical ballooning syndrome, or stress-induced cardiomyopathy. It is characterized by a transient myocardial stunning from microcirculation spams due to a catecholamine surge during stress. It is usually seen in middle-aged women. The patients may present with pulmonary edema, hypotension, and chest pain.

Echocardiography reveals apical dilatation with basal hypercontraction of the heart, resembling a takotsubo (pot for catching octopus). The ECG changes can mimic those of myocardial infarction. Therefore, coronary angiography may be needed to rule out coronary occlusion. 

Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is a self-limiting disorder, resolving within days to weeks. The prognosis is generally good.

The image below shows left ventriculography during systole showing apical ballooning, resembling the takotsubo pot.

questions.text: The Ministry of Health and Family Welfare is planning strategies to completely prevent the emission of nitrogen dioxide and carbon monoxide.  Which level of prevention does this fall under?
questions.solution:
Strategies to completely prevent the emission of nitrogen dioxide and sulfur dioxide fall under the primordial level of prevention. 

The primordial level of prevention involves the prevention of the emergence or development of risk factors in countries or population groups in which they have not yet appeared.

Primordial prevention consists of risk factor reduction targeted towards an entire population through a focus on social and environmental conditions. Measures taken for this level of prevention are typically promoted through laws and national policies. The main intervention in primordial prevention is individual and mass education.

Examples of the concerns addressed at this level include adult health problems, like obesity and hypertension, that have an early onset due to lifestyle factors, like smoking, poor eating patterns, and lack of physical exercise; preventive measures are directed at discouraging these practices from early childhood.

Other options

Option A- Secondary prevention includes early disease detection and targets healthy-looking individuals with subclinical forms of the disease. Secondary prevention is defined by intervention that halts the progress of the disease at its incipient stage and prevents complications.

Screening tests and early diagnosis are the specific interventional strategies used in the secondary level of prevention, and they help arrest the disease process. It is an imperfect tool in the control of the transmission of disease. It is often more expensive and less effective than primary prevention. A Papanicolaou (Pap) smear is an example of secondary prevention aimed to diagnose cervical cancer in its subclinical state before progression.

Option C - Tertiary prevention includes all rehabilitation measures available to reduce or limit impairments and disabilities and to minimize suffering caused by any stage of the disease. This also promotes the patient's adjustment to irremediable conditions. Tertiary prevention extends the concepts of prevention by rehabilitation.

Examples include occupational and physical therapy in burns patients and cardiac rehabilitation in post-myocardial infarction patients.

Option D - Primary prevention is defined as an action taken prior to the onset of disease, which removes the possibility that a disease will ever occur. Primary prevention is obtained by measures promoting general health and well-being and the quality of life of people by specific protective measures. This helps in the modification of risk factors of a  disease. They include two strategies:

  • Population (mass) strategy where the target group is the whole population
  • A high-risk strategy where the target group is limited to the people who are most at risk of developing a particular disease

Examples are sanitation, immunization, and the protection of food. 

Related Pearl: Levels of Prevention

questions.text:
A man with chronic alcoholism presents with abdominal distension. Laboratory tests show that the AST: ALT ratio is 3:1. What is the possible mechanism behind this finding?

AST: Aspartate aminotransferase
ALT: Alanine aminotransferase

choices.text: Deficiency of vitamin B6, leading to increase in AST levels
Deficiency of vitamin B12, leading to increase in AST levels
Deficiency of vitamin B6, leading to decrease in ALT levels
Deficiency of vitamin B12, leading to decrease in ALT levels

questions.solution:
The possible mechanism behind the finding of AST:ALT ratio of 3:1 in a chronic alcoholic patient is the deficiency of vitamin B6, leading to a decrease in ALT level.

The AST:ALT ratio can be interpreted as follows:

AST:ALT Condition
<1 Chronic viral hepatitis, Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease
>1 Cirrhosis
>2:1

Suggestive of alcoholic liver disease

Alcohol intake is associated with the deficiency of pyridoxal phosphate, which in turn leads to decreased levels of ALT enzyme. So, AST>ALT.
>3:1 Highly suggestive of alcoholic liver disease

Important liver function tests

  1. Serum bilirubin - the normal levels of serum total bilirubin is between 1-1.5mg/dL, out of which direct bilirubin is less than 0.3mg/dL. If the levels of indirect bilirubin are more than 85% of the total, then it is considered to be indirect hyperbilirubinemia. Important causes of indirect hyperbilirubinemia are hemolytic anemias, Crigler-Najjar, and Gilbert’s syndromes. Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia is seen in the liver or biliary tract disease. In the majority of liver diseases, both conjugated and unconjugated are elevated.
  2. Liver enzymes- aspartate aminotransferase (AST) and alanine aminotransferase (ALT) are the sensitive indicators of liver injury. Alkaline phosphatase and 5′-nucleotidase are the markers for cholestasis.
  3. Serum albumin - it is synthesized exclusively by hepatocytes. The level of albumin decreases in decreased liver function. However, the half-life of albumin is 18-20 days. Therefore it is not a good indicator of acute or mild hepatic dysfunction. It mainly indicates chronic hepatic dysfunction.
  4. Coagulation factors - with the exception of actor VIII, other blood clotting factors are synthesized in the liver. In contrast to albumin, they have a very small half-life ranging from 6 h for factor VII to 5 days for fibrinogen. Therefore, it can be helpful in diagnosing acute parenchymal diseases also.

Related Pearl: Laboratory Evaluation of Liver Disease

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient presented with complaints of burning micturition and fever with chills for three days. After a detailed workup, she was diagnosed with a urinary tract infection caused by Staphylococcus saprophyticus. Which of the following is correct regarding the biochemical properties of the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Staphylococcus saprophyticus is coagulase-negative and novobiocin resistant.

Coagulase-negative Staphylococci are a part of normal human flora and it includes S. epidermidis, S. haemolyticus, and S. lugdonensis apart from S. saprophyticus.

Staphylococcus saprophyticus is a gram-positive, coagulase-negative staphylococcus. It is non-pigmented, novobiocin resistant, and non-hemolytic on blood agar. It is a leading cause of cystitis in women. It is a part of the normal flora of human skin and periurethral area and thus causes cystitis in women who are sexually active.

questions.text: An investigating officer collects a bullet from the crime scene and compares it with a bullet from the firearm suspected to be used. Which of the following characteristic features will determine the specific firearm that was used?

choices.text: Make and model of the gun
Direction of twist of the rifling

questions.solution:
The secondary markings will determine the specific firearm that was used.

These markings, also known as individual or accidental characteristics, refer to the irregularities on the inner surface of the barrel itself, which are specific for that particular firearm. These markings are caused by the sticking of the particles of the bullet to the bore when shots are fired and are known as "metallic fouling." 

Secondary markings are used to identify a specific gun to the exclusion of all others by the process called bullet fingerprinting.

The class characteristics or the primary markings in a fired bullet are useful in identifying the make and model of the gun involved and are determined before the manufacture of the gun. These markings result from manufacturing specifications, design, and dimensions. They are formed when a bullet passes through a barrel and the sides are marked by the rifling of the barrel. 

Primary markings are based on the following factors:

(1) Caliber

(2) Number of lands and grooves

(3) Direction of twist of the rifling 

(4) Rate of the twist of the rifling

(5) Width of the lands and grooves 

The bullet found at the crime scene is known as a crime bullet or exhibit bullet. It is compared with a bullet fired from the suspected weapon, known as a test bullet. The suspected weapon is fired using the same brand and type of ammunition, into a box filled with cotton waste (bullet traps), a bag of rags, a sandbag, oiled saw-dust, blocks of ice, water tanks (bullet recovery tank), or against white blotting paper. Cleanly shaven fresh pork skins are used for comparison with patterns on human skin.

From the fired cartridge case, the caliber and type of cartridge can be determined. From the shape and size of the case and the stampings on the case head, its manufacturer can be determined. The marks left on the fired cartridges by the weapon can also help in the identification.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female has come for her routine annual checkup. During the breast examination, the following finding is noted. Which of the following is true regarding this finding?

choices.text: It is due to blockage of subcuticular lymphatics
It is usually associated with subareolar abscess and nipple discharge
It is due to thrombophlebitis of the superficial veins of the breast
It is most commonly associated with nipple retraction

questions.solution:
The image shows a thrombosed subcutaneous cord attached to the skin which is the pathognomic of Mondor's disease.

Mondor’s disease is the thrombophlebitis of the superficial veins of the breast and anterior chest wall. It may also occur in the arm or penis. Usually, the etiology is obscure in the absence of a clear history of injury or infection. On raising the arm, the skin over the chest gets stretched and a narrow, shallow groove alongside the cord is seen.

Symptomatic management & reassurance are best suited for it, as it typically resolves in a few weeks. The differential diagnosis to be considered is lymphatic permeation from occult breast carcinoma.

Other options:

The blockage of subcuticular lymphatics leads to edema, which deepens the mouth of the sweat glands and hair follicles. This gives rise to a typical orange peel appearance called Peau d'Orange, as shown in the image below. It is a classical sign of breast carcinoma.

questions.text: A young boy was rushed to the emergency room with complaints of respiratory distress and high-grade fever. The microscopy and culture of the sputum showed gram-positive cocci with α-hemolytic activity on blood agar. Which of the following antibiotics is the pathogen most likely susceptible to?
questions.solution:
Sputum showing gram-positive cocci with α-hemolytic activity in a patient with high-grade fever and respiratory distress is suggestive of pneumococcal pneumonia. Pneumococci show optochin susceptibility.

Both Streptococcus pneumoniae and Streptococcus viridans produce α-hemolysis on blood agar. The optochin sensitivity test is done to differentiate Streptococcus pneumoniae from commensal-like viridans Streptococci.

The image given below shows the classification of gram-positive bacteria.

Optochin sensitivity is observed using the disc diffusion method.

The image given below shows a sensitivity testing plate of Streptococcus pneumoniae.

Related Pearl: Differentiation between Streptococcus pneumoniae and Streptococcus viridans

Colonies Initially Dome Shaped, Later Draughtsman Colonies Dome shaped
Growth in Liquid Media Uniform Turbidity Granular Turbidity, powdery deposit
Bile solubility Bile soluble Bile insoluble
Inulin fermentation Positive Negative
Optochin sensitivity Sensitive Resistant
Intraperitoneal inoculation in Mice Fatal infection Non-pathogenic

questions.text: A diabetic patient who has developed chronic renal failure is prescribed a dipeptidyl-peptidase 4 (DPP4) inhibitor. No dose adjustment was done. Which of the following drugs was most likely prescribed to him?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the drug that was most likely prescribed to this patient is linagliptin. It is a DPP-4 inhibitor that can be safely used in renal failure. It is mainly excreted through the hepatobiliary route.

DPP4 inhibitors are orally acting novel drugs that act by the incretin pathway and stimulate insulin secretion. These drugs have significantly lesser chances of hypoglycemic side effects. These drugs are mainly eliminated unchanged by the kidneys, except Linagliptin which is eliminated by the hepatobiliary route and is therefore considered relatively safer in a patient with renal failure.

 

 

Other options:

Option A: Dulaglutide is safe in renal failure, but it is a GLP-1 analog.

Option B: Vildagliptin is a DPP-4 inhibitor but is excreted in the urine. The dose should be decreased in patients with renal failure.

Option D: Pramlintide is an amylin analog and can be used in moderate renal disease.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient came with complaints of fever, cough, multiple joint pain, and painful rashes on the leg as shown below. Chest x-ray showed bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and a pulmonary biopsy showed non-caseating granuloma. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A female patient with fever, arthritis, lesions suggestive of erythema nodosum, and chest x-ray of bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy with biopsy showing non-caseating granuloma are suggestive of Lofgren's syndrome.

Sarcoidosis is a granulomatous inflammatory condition with multisystem involvement. The most common organs affected are the lungs, liver, eyes, and skin. It is more often seen in women. 

There are two syndromes that are associated with sarcoidosis are: 

  • Lofgren's syndrome is characterized by erythema nodosum and hilar adenopathy. Periarticular arthritis may also be seen.
  • Mikulicz syndrome is the bilateral involvement of parotid, submaxillary, and sublingual glands. 

The most common presenting features are cough, dyspnea, fever, night sweats, and weight loss. Other manifestations of sarcoidosis include: 

  • Ophthalmologic - anterior uveitis, photophobia, dry eyes, and blurred vision
  • Neurological - myelopathy, basilar meningitis, and facial nerve paralysis
  • Dermatological - maculopapular lesions, keloid formation, and subcutaneous nodules. Lupus pernio refers to the skin involvement of the bridge of the nose, periocular region, and cheeks and points to a chronic state.

The investigations used in the diagnosis of sarcoidosis include:

  • Serum ACE (angiotensin-converting enzyme) levels - elevated
  • BAL- lymphocytosis and increased CD4/CD8 ratio. A ratio of >3.5 in BAL is strongly supportive of sarcoidosis.
  • Gallium scan shows the following signs:
    • Panda sign- due to bilateral involvement of parotid and lacrimal glands 
    • Lambda sign- due to bilateral hilar and right paratracheal lymph nodes 
  • Biopsy showing non-caseating granulomas along with features of sarcoidosis is confirmatory.
  • PET-CT scan - to identify areas of granulomatous disease

Other options:

Option A: Heerfordt–Waldenstrom syndrome also known as uveoparotid fever is a rare presentation of sarcoidosis characterized by fever, parotid enlargement, facial palsy, and anterior uveitis.

Option C: Loeffler's syndrome is transient pulmonary eosinophilia which occurs in response to the passage of helminthic larvae through the lungs. Most commonly, it is seen in roundworm (Ascaris species) infection.

Option D: Sweet syndrome is also known as febrile neutrophilic dermatosis. It is characterized by the presence of WBCs in the lower dermis. It is mostly seen in neutropenic patients with malignancies such as acute myeloid leukemia.

Related Pearl: Named lung diseases

Bagassosis

 Pneumoconiosis due to sugarcane
Byssinosis (brown lung disease/ Monday fever) Pneumoconiosis due to cotton fiber
Farmer’s lung Pneumoconiosis due to Thermophilic actinomycetes
Bird Fancier’s lung Hypersensitivity pneumonitis caused by bird droppings
Chalicosis (flint disease)  In stonecutters, due to inhalation of fine particles of stone
Caplan’s syndrome  RA + pneumoconiosis
Lofgren's syndrome An acute presentation of sarcoidosis, consisting of arthritis, erythema nodosum, and bilateral hilar adenopathy
Bornholm’s disease (epidemic pleurodynia) associated with Coxsackie B virus

questions.text: A 36-year-old female notices a midline swelling in her neck. On ultrasound, a unifocal 2*2 cm lesion is noticed in the right lobe of the thyroid without any lymph node enlargement. USG-guided FNAC is given below. What surgical management is recommended for this patient?

choices.text: Total thyroidectomy with central neck dissection

questions.solution:
The above clinical diagnosis of papillary carcinoma thyroid of unifocal lesion size 2*2cm without any lymph node enlargement is managed with hemithyroidectomy.

Management of papillary thyroid carcinoma.

  • Papillary carcinoma thyroid is managed by hemithyroidectomy/lobectomy or total thyroidectomy depending upon the stage of the disease.
  • Central neck dissection is done only in case of involvement of level VI nodes.
  • If level VI plus other lymph nodes are enlarged - then total thyroidectomy + central neck dissection + modified radical neck dissection is done.
  • In case of tumor size >4cm (T3 &T4), prophylactic central neck dissection is done.

Earlier, total thyroidectomy was the preferred surgery. However, according to the latest updates, hemithyroidectomy is an acceptable alternative to total thyroidectomy for low-risk differentiated thyroid carcinoma.

Differentiated thyroid carcinoma that is low-risk include:

  • Unilateral lesion
  • Size between 1-4cm
  • No extranodal extension.

Exceptions to the above include:

  • Radiation-induced Differentiated carcinoma thyroid.
  • Familial nonmedullary thyroid carcinoma.
  • Multifocal bilateral lesion.
  • Extra thyroidal extension present

Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid carcinoma. It is most common in iodine-sufficient areas, children, and those exposed to ionizing radiation. The mean age of presentation is a 3rd-4th decade and is more common in women than men (2:1). Dysphagia, dysphonia, and dyspnea are associated with local invasion. It usually presents as a cold nodule on the scan. Histological findings include:

    • Branching papillae 
    • Follicles with the fibrovascular stalk
    • Psammoma bodies.
    • Optically clear - Ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei
    • Pseudo-inclusions
    • Nuclear grooves.

 Below is the histopathological image of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid with characteristic Orphan Annie eye nuclei.

Lymph node metastasis is common. Lateral aberrant thyroid denotes a cervical lymph node invaded by papillary carcinoma. The most common sites of metastasis : lung > liver > bone > brain. It has an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents to the hospital with fever, malaise, and arthralgia for a duration of 1 month. She also complains of pain, numbness, and weakness in her right arm, which has been increasing over the past 1 week. Clinical examination reveals weak radial pulses, and her laboratory investigations show elevated ESR. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical features with a marked weakening of pulse in the upper extremities and laboratory findings of elevated ESR are suggestive of Takayasu arteritis. It is also known as pulseless disease. 

Takayasu arteritis is a systemic disease and may present with generalized and vascular symptoms. It commonly affects adolescents or young females. Generalized symptoms like fever, night sweats, weight loss, malaise, arthralgias, and anorexia may occur long before vascular symptoms.

Vascular symptoms depend on the vessel involved:

  • Arch of the aorta and its branches:
    • Subclavian artery (most commonly affected) - It leads to weak pulses in the upper extremities. Hence, it is also known as pulseless disease. It may also lead to Raynaud’s phenomenon.
    • Carotid arteries- It leads to weak pulses, blindness, and neurological deficits.
    • Aortic arch- It may lead to congestive heart failure.
  • Abdominal aorta, celiac axis, and superior mesenteric artery - leads to abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting
  • Iliac vessels - leads to claudication of the legs
  • Renal arteries - leads to systemic hypertension
  • Pulmonary artery - leads to pulmonary hypertension
  • Coronary arteries (least commonly affected) - lead to myocardial infarction

Investigations:

  • Laboratory tests reveal an elevated ESR level, anemia, and elevated immunoglobulin levels.
  • Arteriography is done as a confirmatory test.

Treatment includes glucocorticoid therapy, methotrexate, immunotherapy with anti-TNF agents, and surgery.

questions.text: You are an intern posted in the casualty ward. The casualty ward receives a call asking for arrangements to receive the patients of a road traffic accident that occurred nearby. The trauma PG wants you to assess the severity of the patients' condition. You check for eye-opening, motor response, and verbal response of the patients.  Which of the following scores would not require these assessments for calculation?
questions.solution:
Assessment of eye-opening, motor response, and verbal response of the patients are not required in the calculation of Mangled Extremity Severity Score (MESS).

Eye-opening, motor response, and verbal response are components of Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score. GCS is a component of Revised Trauma Score (RTS) and RTS is a component of Trauma and Injury Severity Score (TRISS). So, the assessment of the parameters listed in the question is required for the calculation of all these scores.

1. Glasgow coma scale(GCS) score:

  • Eye-opening
  • Verbal response
  • Motor response

2. Revised Trauma Score (RTS):

The Revised Trauma Score (RTS) is a well-studied physiologic scoring system that characterizes the injured patient’s condition by incorporating the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS), systolic blood pressure, and respiratory rate. These scores have been of value for research purposes and have been successfully used to make triage decisions.

3. Injury Severity Score (ISS):

The Injury Severity Score (ISS) is calculated by summing the squares of the Abbreviated Injury Scale (AIS) severity codes for the three most severely injured body regions. The ISS ranges from 1 to 75, with severity groupings being defined as minor injury (ISS less than 9), moderate injury (ISS between 9 and 16), serious injury (ISS between 16 and 25), and severe injury (ISS more than 25). 

4. Trauma and Injury Severity Score (TRISS):

  • Injury Severity Score (ISS)
  • Revised Trauma Score (RTS)
  • Age
  • Mechanism of Injury (blunt/penetrating)

5. Mangled Extremity Severity Score (MESS) :

The Mangled Extremity Severity Score (MESS) is the most widely validated classification system. It takes into consideration the following:

  • Energy that caused the injury, skeletal/soft tissue injury
  • Limb ischemia
  • Shock
  • Patient’s age

A score of 7 or higher consistently predicted the need for amputation, whereas all limbs with initial scores of 6 or less remained viable in the long term.

Related Pearl: Trauma Scoring Systems

Revised Trauma Score  - Total score 0-12 :

  • Glasgow coma scale
  • Respiratory rate
  • Systolic BP

Glasgow coma scale  - Total score 3-15 :

  • Eye-opening
  • Verbal response
  • Motor response

Abbreviated Injury Scale: AIS severity code – 1(minimal severity) to 6 (presumably fatal)

Injury Severity Score – Total score 1 to 75. Calculated summing the squares of the AIS severity codes for the three most severely injured body regions

Score Severity of injury
3-8 Minor
9-16 Moderate
16-24 Serious
>25 Severe/ Critical

  

Mangled Extremity Severity score: Mnemonic - ELiSA

  • Energy that caused the injury, skeletal and soft tissue injury
  • Limb ischemia
  • Shock
  • Patient’s age

TRISS (Trauma and Injury Severity Score) : Mnemonic - IRMA

  • Injury Severity Score
  • Revised Trauma Score
  • Mechanism of Injury (blunt/penetrating)
  • Age

questions.text: An 80-year-old patient is undergoing cataract surgery. During the surgery, there is a complication that results in a posterior capsule tear. The surgeon decides to use the following type of intraocular lens (IOL). Identify the lens used.

choices.text: Modified C loop posterior chamber IOL
Singh and Worst iris claw lens

questions.solution:
The image depicts the Kelman multiflex type of anterior chamber intraocular lens (ACIOL). 

Anterior chamber IOLs lie entirely in front of the iris and are supported at the angle of the anterior chamber. These are used when posterior chamber IOLs cannot be used due to some complications such as posterior capsule tear or zonular dialysis (deficient zonular support for the lens capsule).

ACIOLs are associated with a higher incidence of bullous keratopathy.

IOL implantation is the method of choice for correcting aphakia.

questions.text: A 25-year-old pregnant woman presents with complaints of easy fatiguability. Her blood examination showed mild anemia with target cells. She was diagnosed with β-thalassemia minor. What is the underlying pathology in this condition?
questions.solution:
Decreased β-chain synthesis is a basic pathology in β-thalassemia minor or β-thalassemia trait.

β-thalassemia is caused by point mutations of the β-thalassemia gene on chromosome 11, which diminish the synthesis of β-globin chains. The predominant mechanisms involved are as follows:

  • Splicing mutations are the most common cause of β+ thalassemia.
  • Promoter region mutations are associated with β+ thalassemia
  • Chain terminator mutations are the most common cause of β0 thalassemia.

These mutations cause a decrease in the synthesis of β-globin chains, leading to anemia due to the decreased synthesis of normal HbA (α2β2) and the decreased survival of red blood cells and their precursors due to the imbalance in α and β globin synthesis; the mutations also lead to increased γ- and δ-chain synthesis, thereby resulting in the increased production of HbF and HbA2, respectively.

β-thalassemia minor is a clinical syndrome caused by the heterozygous expression of one normal (β) gene and one abnormal β-thalassemia (β0/+) gene. It can either be present as β+/β or as β0/β. This type is more common clinically than the other forms of thalassemia. Patients are usually asymptomatic or present with symptoms of mild anemia. Peripheral blood smear typically shows hypochromic, microcytic red cells with basophilic stippling, and target cells, as shown in the image.

The diagnosis is confirmed by hemoglobin electrophoresis, which typically reveals raised levels of HbA2 (α2δ2) with normal HbF (α2γ2) levels. The Mentzer index is <13 in thalassemia minor syndrome.

Thalassemia minor seldom requires treatment, and treatment is usually indicated only after surgery, following childbirth, or for complications. Blood transfusions are the preferred modality of treatment.

β Thalassemia major is a clinical syndrome caused due to homozygous expression of abnormal abnormal β-thalassemia genes in the form of β+/β+, β+/β0, or β0/β0. The etiology is similar to that described above. Briefly, there is the complete absence or only minimal synthesis of the β-globin chain. The predominant type of hemoglobin is HbF, with very low HbA levels and normal to mildly increased HbA2 levels.

Blood smears show severe red cell abnormalities, including marked anisocytosis and poikilocytosis, microcytosis, and hypochromia. Target cells, basophilic stippling, and fragmented red cells also are common. The reticulocyte count is elevated. A radiographic image of the skull shows the classic 'crew cut' appearance.

Patients usually present with severe transfusion-dependent anemia and do not survive without them. Extramedullary hematopoiesis leads to hepatosplenomegaly and enlarged and distorted bony prominences over the face, leading to the characteristic chipmunk facies.

β-thalassemia intermedia is a third genetically heterogeneous β-thalassemia variant of moderate severity. This category includes milder variants of β+/β+ or β+/β0-thalassemia.

Note: Mentzer index is the ratio of MCV to RBC count. It is used to differentiate between iron-deficiency anemia and β-thalassemia trait.

Related Pearl: Thalassemia syndromes

Normally each individual carries 4 functional alpha chain genes and 2 functional beta chain genes. Alpha and beta-thalassemia are inherited disorders in which there is reduced production of alpha-globin or beta-globin chains, respectively.

  • Alpha thalassemia: Gene deletion is the most common cause of reduced α-chain synthesis.
  • Beta +- thalassemia: The most common cause is splicing mutation.
  • Beta 0- thalassemia: Chain terminator mutations are the most common cause.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with complaints of severe itching every time he takes a hot shower for the past few months. He also reports a burning sensation in his fingers and frequent headaches. His hemoglobin is 18 g/dL and his erythropoietin levels are low. Which of the following cannot be used in the above condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of polycythemia vera and nitrosourea is not used in the treatment of polycythemia vera. 

Alkylating agents like nitrosourea are leukemogenic in polycythemia vera and its contraindicated. 

Polycythemia vera is a chronic myeloproliferative disorder associated with a mutation on Janus kinase-2 (JAK2) which results in neoplastic proliferation of hematopoietic progenitor cells. 

Polycythemia shows a slight predominance in males. Most of the cases are incidental findings with high hemoglobin, hematocrit, or red cell count which are seen in other causes of erythrocytosis. Aquagenic pruritis is one of the most common symptoms associated with polycythemia vera. 

Digital ischemia, easy bruising, or gastrointestinal bleeding can occur due to thrombocytosis or vascular stasis.

Treatment: Phlebotomy serves initially to reduce the hyperviscosity by reducing the red cell mass. Ruxolitinib, hydroxyurea, pegylated interferon alpha are used for pruritis intractable to the antihistamine.

Related Pearl: WHO Polycythemia Vera Criteria

Major criteria:

1. Hemoglobin >16.5 g/dL in men

     Hemoglobin >16.0 g/dL in women 

Or

     Hematocrit >49% in men

     Hematocrit >48% in women 

2. Bone marrow biopsy showing hypercellularity with trilineage hyperplasia (panmyelosis) and prominent erythroid, granulocytic, and megakaryocytic proliferation with pleomorphic mature megakaryocytes in the bone marrow, and 

3. Presence of JAK2 exon 12 mutation

Minor criterion:

Subnormal serum erythropoietin level

Diagnosis of polycythemia vera requires meeting either all 3 major criteria or the first 2 major criteria along with the minor criterion
