questions.text: An infant was brought with a history of recurrent pneumonia and copious, adherent secretions. The history also was suggestive of chronic malabsorption with fatty stools and poor weight gain. Blood examination shows high levels of immunoreactive trypsinogen. What is the most common gene mutation in this condition?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in the given scenario is cystic fibrosis (CF). The most common gene mutation in CF is the F508del mutation.  

F508del mutation is a deletion of a phenylalanine residue at the CFTR position 508, which results in endoplasmic reticulum–associated degradation. At least 90% of patients with CF have this mutation. A mutation affecting protein degradation is termed a class II defect.

There are 6 classes of defects involving the CFTR gene:

Class Defect
Class I Absence of synthesis e.g., W1282X, G542X
Class II Defective protein maturation and premature degradation e.g., F508 deletion
Class III Disordered gating/regulation, e.g. G551D mutation
Class IV Defective conductance through the ion-channel pore
Class V Promoter or splicing abnormality leading to reduced CFTR transcripts
Class VI Accelerated turnover from the cell surface

Cystic fibrosis is an autosomal recessive disorder that affects fluid secretion in the exocrine glands and in the epithelial lining. It is primarily caused by a mutation in the CFTR gene, which codes for an anion channel in the apical membranes of epithelial cells. This leads to abnormally viscous secretions that obstruct organ passages, resulting in recurrent infections, pancreatic insufficiency, steatorrhea, malnutrition, hepatic cirrhosis, intestinal obstruction, and male infertility.

Diagnosis of CF is made at the time of newborn screening. Sweat electrolyte levels are measured after pilocarpine iontophoresis. In these patients, the chloride level is high. It is then confirmed through genetic testing with one of the 20–140 CFTR variants. 

The diagnosis of CF is confirmed if both of the following criteria are met:

  • Presence of
    • Clinical symptoms affecting at least one organ system (respiratory, gastrointestinal, or genitourinary) or
    • Positive newborn screening or
    • A sibling with cystic fibrosis
  • Evidence of dysfunction of the CFTR gene in the form of
    • Two positive sweat chloride test results obtained on separate days or
    • Identification of two CFTR mutations by genetic testing or
    • An abnormal measurement of nasal potential difference

Management of cystic fibrosis requires a multidisciplinary approach:

  • Mucus accumulation - chest physiotherapy, aerosolized dornase alfa (recombinant DNase), N-acetylcysteine, albuterol, corticosteroids, and hypertonic saline
  • Respiratory infections - antibiotics (oral for Staphylococcus and aerosolized for Pseudomonas)
  • Pancreatic insufficiency - pancreatic enzyme supplements
  • Malabsorption - nutritional supplementation along with fat-soluble vitamins (K, E, D, and A) and minerals 

Other options: 

Option A: In a G551D mutation, there is a glycine to aspartic acid replacement at the 551st position, which leads to the disruption in HCO3- and Cl- transportation. This is a class III defect. 

Option C: W1282X is the most common defect amongst Ashkenazi Jews. It is a class I defect. 

Option D: G542X is another class I defect that is not very common.

questions.text: The image shows methylene blue dye being injected in the peritumoral region. What is this procedure useful for?
questions.solution:
The utility of injection of methylene blue in the region around the tumor is done for sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLN) in patients without clinically positive lymph nodes.

SLN biopsy rationale:

  • Afferent lymphatics from a primary tumor first drain into the sentinel node before draining into the other nodes. So, if a sentinel lymph node is positive for metastsis, it is possible that the other axillary nodes are also involved. Hence, axillary dissection would be necessary.
  • If the sentinel node is tumor-free, then regional nodal metastasis is unlikely.

The nodes can be identified using fluorescein dye, methylene blue, or radioactive sulfur colloid-labeled albumin. The dye can be injected into the peritumoral tissue, subareolar, periareolar, or intradermal plane.

Contraindicated in patients with inflammatory breast cancer, stage T4 disease, a history of previous breast cancer or chest wall surgery, breast scarring, and radiotherapy.

questions.text: An orthopedic resident prescribes pain relievers for a patient diagnosed with Kohler's disease. Which of the following bones is usually affected in this condition?
questions.solution:
Osteochondritis of the navicular bone is known as Kohler's disease.

Osteochondrosis and osteochondritis are conditions in which a small segment of articular bone or cartilage is demarcated or separated and necrosed. The affected part shows features of ischemic necrosis. This is widely seen in adolescents and young adults, with trauma and repetitive stress being the common causes. An example of this disorder is osteochondritis dissecans.

Commonly affected sites are slightly bulbous areas with convex articular surfaces: 

  • Inner (medial) surface of the medial femoral condyle in the knee
  • Anteromedial corner of the talus in the ankle
  • Superomedial part of the femoral head
  • Humeral capitulum
  • Head of the second metatarsal bone

Clinically, they present with intermittent pain over the mid-foot, which may be accompanied by swelling and a small effusion in the joint. It typically resolves over the years, as the child grows up.

X-ray imaging, MRI, and radionuclide scanning with 99mTc-HDP are the imaging modalities used for diagnosis.

Treatment includes symptomatic treatment of pain. Special supportive shoes may also be considered.

Other options:

Option A: Osteochondritis of the lunate is known as Kienbock's disease.

Option B: Osteochondritis of the capitulum is known as Panner's disease.

Option D: Osteochondritis of the calcaneum is known as Sever's disease.

Related Pearl: Osteochondritis

questions.text: A middle-aged man presenting with chronic back pain was diagnosed with multiple myeloma. The urine analysis report showed the presence of light-chain proteins. What type of proteinuria does this patient have?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient has multiple myeloma. Thus the type of proteinuria this patient is likely to have is overflow proteinuria.

Various types of proteinuria:

  • Glomerular - Increased filtration of proteins due to the disruption of the basement membrane
  • Tubular - Impaired protein reabsorption in the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) due to damage to the tubules 
  • Overflow - Excess production of low-molecular-weight proteins, such as light chains, in multiple myeloma
  • Postrenal - Secretion of IgA and IgG by the urinary tract due to infections or stones

Type of Proteinuria

Albuminuria (mg/day)

<150  

Mainly Tamm-Horsfall protein (70–75 mg/day) 

<30
Moderately increased 150–500  30–300 
Severely increased >500  >300  
Orthostatic proteinuria 150–500   —

Normally, the following mechanisms prevent proteinuria:

  • The glomerular basement membrane acts as a barrier to prevent the loss of negatively charged and large proteins.
  • Reabsorption of small proteins in the PCT

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida visits your clinic for a regular antenatal check-up at 37 weeks of gestation. You perform the following grip by standing near the head end of the mother while facing her feet. What is this grip known as?
questions.solution:
The obstetric grip shown in the picture is the Fourth Leopold maneuver (also known as pelvic grip).

Pelvic grip (fourth Leopold) assesses the engagement, and attitude of the fetal head and determines the degree of descent. The examiner faces the mother's feet, and the fingertips of both hands are positioned on either side of the presenting part. They exert inward pressure and then slide along the axis of the pelvic inlet. It is the only grip performed facing the feet.

The fetal pole, lie, presenting part, engagement, and attitude of fetal head are assessed by Leopold's maneuvers:

First Leopold (Fundal grip ):

  • Performed by facing the patient’s face
  • Assesses the uterine fundus.
  • Helps in identification of fetal lie and determination of fetal pole at the fundus.
  • The breech gives the sensation of a large, irregular mass. 
  • The head feels hard and round and is more mobile.

Second Leopold (Lateral grip): 

  • Performed by facing the patient’s face
  • Assesses fetal orientation.
  • The palms are placed on either side of the maternal abdomen, and gentle but deep pressure is exerted.
  • The back is felt on one side as a hard, resistant structure.
  • The fetal extremities are felt on the other side as numerous small, irregular, mobile parts are felt.
  • Fetal orientation can be determined by noting whether the back is directed anteriorly, transversely, or posteriorly.
  • The position of the anterior shoulder is mainly assessed by this grip.

Pawlik's grip (third Leopold):

  • Performed by facing the patient’s face.
  • Assesses the presenting part with respect to the true pelvis.
  • The thumb and fingers of one hand grasp the lower portion of the maternal abdomen just above the symphysis pubis.
  • If the presenting part is not engaged it can be grasped distinctly.

questions.text:
Two patients presented to the tuberculosis OPD and were diagnosed with MDR-TB and XDR-TB, respectively. Both of them are resistant to which of the following drugs?
  1. Isoniazid
  2. Rifampicin 
  3. One of Fluoroquinolones 
  4. One of the second line injectables
  5. Linezolid/ Bedaquiline
questions.solution:
Both the patients diagnosed with MDR-TB and XDR-TB are resistant to Isoniazid and Rifampicin.

Muti-drug resistant (MDR) tuberculosis (TB) shows resistance to isoniazid and rifampicin. 

MDR-TB poses a serious problem in the treatment of TB as isoniazid and rifampicin are the most potent first-line drugs. 

The treatment of MDR-TB is curated with drugs grouped into different classes by the world health organization (WHO).

  • Group A: Levofloxacin, bedaquiline, linezolid
  • Group B: Clofazimine, cycloserine
  • Group C: Ethambutol, pyrazinamide, delamanid, ethionamide

In patients treated previously or with additional drug resistance, a longer MDR-TB regimen of 18-20 months is recommended. Drugs belonging to group A are preferred along with one drug from group B whenever possible. A shorter regimen of 6 months including bedaquiline with other drugs can be used in patients not treated before and without extensive disease. In pregnant women with MRD-TB, drugs such as bedaquiline and delamanid should be avoided. 

XDR-TB (extensively drug-resistant TB) is defined as multi-drug resistant  TB (resistant to rifampicin and isoniazid) which is also resistant to one fluoroquinolone (eg. ofloxacin) AND resistant to at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

It is usually seen in patients who have previously received treatment for TB and have either failed to complete treatment or relapsed.

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase
New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) 2 months H R Z E 4 months H R E

Classification based on drug resistance. 

The cases are classified as:

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

Standard DR TB regimen

Regimen class Drugs Comments
H mono-resistant/ poly-drug resistant TB regimen Lfx R E Z for 6 months

6 months long

Oral drugs only
BPaLM regime (New MDR regime by WHO) Bdq Pa Lzd Mfx for 6 months

6 months long
9- 11 months shorter oral bedaquiline regime (Shorter MDR)

Intensive Phase:

Lfx Bdq(6 months) Cfz Z Hh E Eto for 4-6 months

Continuation phase:

Lfx Cfz Z E for 5 months

9-11 months long totally

Injectables used in Intensive phase.
Longer MDR TB regimen Bdq(6 months or longer) Lfx Lzd Cfz Cs 

18-20 months long

Oral drugs only

This regimen is used for XDR TB patients for 20 months.

 

Criteria for patients to receive standard Drug Resistant TB regimen:

Standard Drug Resistant TB regimen Inclusion criteria Exclusion criteria
H mono-resistant/poly-drug resistant TB regimen Isoniazid resistant TB with rifampicin sensitive No specific criteria
BPaLM regimen (New MDR TB regimen by WHO)
  1. MDR/RR-TB or pre-XDR-TB ( MDR/RR-TB and resistance to fluoroquinolones). 
  2. Those with confirmed pulmonary TB and all forms of extrapulmonary TB (except for TB involving CNS, osteoarticular, and miliary TB).
  3. Patients >14 years of age.
 Pregnant and lactating women
9- 11 months shorter MDR TB regimen Patient with rifampicin resistant pulmonary or extra pulmonary TB Non drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • Pregnancy
  • Any extra pulmonary disease in PLHIV
  • Disseminated meningeal or central nervous system TB
  • Intolerance to any drug in the shorter MDR TB regimen
Drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • If DST/DRT result for FQ or SLI is resistant (XDR TB)
  • Presence of InhA mutation
  • Resistant to Z 
Longer MDR TB regimen Patients in whom shorter MDR TB regimen cannot be considered due to any reason None

Legend

FQ: Fluoroquinolone

SLI: Second Line Injectable

PLHIV: People Living with HIV

Lfx: Levofloxacin

Pa: Pretomanid

H: Isoniazid

Hh: High Dose Isoniazid

questions.text: A woman died due to septic abortion following Clostridium welchii infection. What color is the postmortem hypostasis likely to be in this case?
questions.solution:
Postmortem hypostasis seen in cases of septic abortion due to Clostridium welchii is mostly greenish-brown in color. Septic abortion due to Clostridium perfringens also produces a hypostasis of a brownish color and, in rare cases, bronze.

The terms postmortem hypostasis, postmortem staining, postmortem lividity, livor mortis, and suggillation all refer to the purple or reddish-purple discoloration of the skin occurring due to the postmortem collection of blood in toneless capillaries in dependant parts of the body.

Features:

  • Caused by engorged vessels showing through the skin
  • Occur on dependent parts due to the pooling of blood under the effect of gravity
  • Margins clearly defined
  • No swelling or abrasion

Fixation of hypostasis occurs 6–12 hours after death. It occurs earlier in summer and is delayed in asphyxial deaths and in intracranial lesions.  

Timing:

  • Mottled patches - 1–3 hours following death
  • Uniform area of staining - 3–6 hours following death
  • Fully developed and fixation of hypostasis - 6–12 hours following death

Postmortem hypostasis/lividity usually develops within 4 hours of death and persists until putrefaction.

Related Pearl: Color of Postmortem Hypostasis in Various Conditions

Poisoning/Condition Postmortem staining

Carbon monoxide   

Cherry red
Cyanides     

Brick red/dark pink

Potassium chlorate

 Chocolate brown 
Phosphorous  Dark brown 
Nitrites   

Red-brown

Hydrogen sulphide

Bluish-green
Opium  Greyish/black
Asphyxia Dark purple
Hypothermia Bright pink
Septic abortion (Cl. Perfringens infection) Pale bronze

questions.text: A young female patient presents to the hospital with complaints of right upper quadrant abdominal pain and infertility. She is scheduled for laparoscopic evaluation, and the surgeon notices the following finding during the procedure. Which of the following micro-organisms is responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
In the above image, adhesions between the liver and the anterior abdominal wall are visualized. This is a common finding in the case of Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome. The commonly implicated microorganisms are Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhea.

Fitz Hugh Curtis syndrome is a sequela of chronic pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), which refers to the inflammation of the liver capsule without the involvement of liver parenchyma. Laparoscopy reveals adhesive bands extending from the fallopian tube on the right side to the undersurface of the liver accounting for the right upper quadrant pain.

Pelvic inflammatory disease is characterized by inflammation of the upper genital tract involving the fallopian tubes and the ovaries. The most common causes of PID in sexually active young females are STDs caused by gonococci and chlamydia. In patients who have not had sexual contact yet, the etiology of pelvic inflammatory disease is usually tubercular.

A patient with PID may remain asymptomatic or present with infertility. Acute PID often presents with symptoms such as lower abdominal pain, fever, nausea, and vomiting. There may be dysuria and foul-smelling vaginal discharge due to STDs. Menstrual abnormalities may be seen in patients who have developed PID after a criminal abortion. Depending on the extent of tissue involved, PID can be classified into five stages

Stage I Acute salpingitis without peritonitis - No adhesions
Stage II Acute salpingitis with peritonitis - purulent discharge
Stage III Acute salpingitis with superimposed tubal occlusion or tubo ovarian complex
Stage IV Ruptured tuba ovarian abscess
Stage V  Tubercular salpingitis

 

Other complications of chronic pelvic inflammatory disease:

  • Hydrosalpinx
  • Chronic pyosalpinx
  • Chronic interstitial salpingitis
  • Tubo ovarian cyst

Treponema pallidum, human immunodeficiency virus, and Entamoeba histolytica are not associated with pelvic inflammatory disease.

Related Pearl: Organisms Responsible for Pelvic Inflammatory Disease

Sexually transmitted: Gonococcus, Chlamydia, Mycoplasma, Trichomonas 
Aerobes: Staphylococci , Streptococci ,E. coli
Anaerobes: Bacteroides fragilis, Peptococcus, Clostridium, Actinomyces (IUD)
Others: Tubercular salpingitis

questions.text: Which of the following values of a test applied to this population will be required to calculate the negative predictive value?
questions.solution:
A and B values are required to calculate the negative predictive value. A negative predictive value is given by the formula:

Negative Predictive Value = True Negative/Total negatives,

where Total negatives = True negative + False negative. 

From the diagram, 

A- True negative

B- False negative

C- False positive

D- True positive

So, NPV= A/ A+B

Related Pearl: Cut-off points in diagnostic tests

  • Highly sensitive test, when negative, rules out a disease. (Screening test)
  • Highly specific test, when positive, rules in a disease. (Confirmatory test)

Sensitivity (True-positive rate): High sensitivity indicates low false-negative rate.

Specificity (True-negative rate): High specificity indicates low false-positive rate.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: A 28-year-old male has an ACL injury and has difficulty walking down the stairs. But he requests a doctor to issue a medical certificate, certifying him as medically fit for a security job. The doctor can be charged under which section of the IPC if he issues a false certificate in this case?
questions.solution:
The punishment for issuing or signing a false certificate is dealt with under IPC 197.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman experiences an increased frequency of micturition, with pain relieved by micturition and aggravated by overdistension of the bladder. Urine routine tests showed no pus cells; urine culture tested negative, and cystoscopy revealed fissures and punctate hemorrhages in the bladder mucosa, with a characteristic appearance of ulcers, as shown in the image below. What is the most probable clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable clinical diagnosis in the reported case is interstitial cystitis. The image shows Hunner's ulcers, which are characteristic of interstitial cystitis. 

Interstitial cystitis (i.e. a chronic pelvic pain syndrome or bladder pain syndrome) is a persistent, painful form of chronic cystitis, which occurs most frequently in women.

Clinical features

  • Severe suprapubic pain
  • Urinary frequency
  • Urgency
  • Hematuria
  • Dysuria without evidence of bacterial infection

Ulcerations of the mucosa occur in the fundus of the bladder (Hunner's ulcer). It is characterized by marked submucosal edema of the bladder with mucosal ulceration, which is seen in the late phase of interstitial cystitis.

In the cystoscopic examination, fissures and punctate hemorrhages (glomerulations) are seen in the bladder mucosa.

Microscopy shows mucosal ulcers covered by fibrin and necrotic material and increased numbers of mucosal mast cells.

Late in the course, transmural fibrosis may appear, leading to a contracted bladder.

The pathologic findings are nonspecific, and the main role of biopsy is to rule out carcinoma in situ, which may mimic interstitial cystitis clinically.

Treatment is difficult and unsatisfactory. Hydrostatic dilatation under anesthesia may give relief for some months. Intravesical instillation of dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) results in an improvement in some patients. Other treatments that have been considered in interstitial cystitis include intravesical heparin, oral ranitidine, and steroid therapy.

Other options:

Malakoplakia (Option B) is a distinct form of inflammatory reaction seen in chronic cystitis. It has the following features:

  • Chronic inflammatory reaction, commonly affecting the urinary bladder, is seen due to acquired defects in phagocyte function.
  • It can also be seen in other organ systems like the gastrointestinal tract, female genital tract, and CNS.
  • Malakoplakia is seen in chronic bacterial infection, mostly by Escherichia coli or occasionally Proteus species.  
  • Grossly, malakoplakia takes the form of soft, yellow, slightly raised mucosal plaques, often misdiagnosed clinically as malignancy.
  • Microscopically, they are composed of large, foamy macrophages mixed with occasional multinucleate giant cells and lymphocytes.
  • The macrophages have an abundant granular cytoplasm due to phagosomes stuffed with undigested bacterial products.
  • In addition, intracellular deposition of calcium and iron within enlarged lysosomes forms laminated basophilic concretions, known as Michaelis–Gutmann bodies, pathognomonic of malakoplakia.

 The following image shows the Michaelis–Gutmann bodies marked in black arrows.


Tubercular cystitis (Option-C):

Tuberculous urinary infection is secondary to renal tuberculosis. Early tuberculosis of the bladder starts around the ureteric orifice or trigone, the earliest evidence being pallor of the mucosa due to submucous edema. Subsequently, tubercles may be seen and, in long-standing cases, marked fibrosis is seen, and the capacity of the bladder is greatly reduced. 

Thimble bladder is classically seen in tubercular cystitis. 


Polypoid cystitis (Option D): 

  • Polypoid cystitis is an inflammatory lesion resulting from the irritation of the bladder mucosa.
  • Although indwelling catheters are the most commonly cited culprits, any injurious agent may give rise to this lesion.
  • The urothelium is thrown into broad bulbous polypoid projections as a result of marked submucosal edema.
  • Polypoid cystitis may be confused with papillary urothelial carcinoma both clinically and histologically.

The given image below shows polypoid cystitis showing broad polypoid growth, prominent blood vessels, and metaplastic urothelium in H&E stain.

Related Pearl: Types of Cystitis

Type of cystitis Etiology Characteristic features
Interstitial cystitis Idiopathic Hunner's ulcer
Polypoid cystitis Catheterization of bladder Mimics malignancy
Malakoplakia Defective phagocytosis Michaelis– Gutmann bodies
Eosinophilic cystitis Systemic allergic disorders Submucosal eosinophils
Emphysematous cystitis Clostridium perfringens Associated with Diabetes
Follicular cystitis Prolonged urinary retention, intravesicular chemotherapy or BCG Lymphoid follicles within bladder mucosa
Hemorrhagic cystitis

Cyclo-phosphamide, BK virus, Adenovirus

 Prophylactic administration of mesna reduces the incidence

questions.text: A teenage girl is brought in for evaluation of truncal asymmetry. The findings of the physical examination and x-ray imaging are shown in the image below. Which of the following radiological signs could be helpful in assessing skeletal maturity in such cases?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, with the image showing a positive Adams (forward bend) test and lateral curvature of the spine seen on the radiograph, is suggestive of scoliosis. Risser's sign evaluates skeletal maturation using the ossification of the iliac apophysis in the evaluation of scoliosis. 

Risser's sign

The iliac apophysis is divided into four quadrants. Ossification of iliac apophyses normally proceeds from the lateral to the medial side and from the anterior superior iliac spine to the posterior superior iliac spine. The Risser grades correspond to the degree of ossification, ranging from grade 0 (no ossification) to grade 4 (ossification of all four quadrants). When the apophysis has fused completely with the ilium, ossification is graded as Risser grade 5 and the patient is considered skeletally mature. 

Adolescent idiopathic scoliosis (AIS)

AIS is the most common type of scoliosis and develops in children over the age of 10 years until they reach skeletal maturity. It is asymptomatic and usually identified on routine physical examination. The spine may have obviously deviated from the mid-line or a prominence may become apparent when the patient bends forward (the Adams test).

Confirmation of the diagnosis is through full-length lateral and PA x-rays. A Cobb angle of >10° is diagnostic. It is a measure of the degree of curvature using projected lines from the top of the uppermost and bottom of the lowermost vertebral bodies.

Use in scoliosis: Risser's grade 5 (fusion with the ilium) corresponds to the fusion of the apophysis in the vertebral ring. Once this occurs, there is no possibility of further progression of the scoliosis curve.

Other options - 

Option B - Lasegue's sign or straight leg raising test (SLRT) is used to diagnose radicular pain.

Option C - Kanavel's sign comprises the four cardinal signs of flexor tendon sheath infection:

  • Finger held in slight flexion
  • Uniform swelling of the digit
  • Tenderness along the flexor tendon sheath
  • Pain with passive extension of the digit

Option D - Froment's sign is used to test for ulnar nerve palsy. Abnormality is present when there is an inability to hold a piece of paper between the thumb and index finger of the affected hand as the examiner tries to pull it away.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the image shown below?

choices.text: Hot and humid weather is necessary for this change.
It is a late sign of death.

questions.solution:
The above image shows the mummification of the body. The false statement about mummification is that hot and humid weather is necessary for this change. The absence of moisture in the air and the continuous action of dry or warmed air and hot weather are necessary for the process of mummification.

Mummification is a process of dehydration or drying and shriveling of the cadaver that occurs from the evaporation of water. The natural appearances of the body and general facial features are preserved. The mummified body is odorless. It is a late sign of death.

Mummification begins in the exposed parts of the body and then extends to the entire body, including the internal organs. The skin becomes shrunken and contracted, dry, brittle, leathery, and rusty-brown to black in color, stretched tightly across anatomical prominences, followed by breakage of the subcutaneous adipose tissues, and the skin becomes translucent.

Unprotected bodies may become powdery and disintegrate, but properly protected bodies may be preserved for years. Collagen, elastic tissues, cardiac and skeletal muscle, cartilage, and bone tissues can be seen on the histologic examination of the mummified material.

questions.text: The illustration below depicts the mechanism of one of the hypersensitivity reactions. In which disease pathology is this mechanism involved?
questions.solution:
The given image shows type 3 hypersensitivity, and it is seen in post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.

Examples of type 3 hypersensitivity reactions:

  • Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Reactive arthritis
  • Polyarteritis nodosa
  • Serum sickness
  • Arthus reaction

Other options:

Option A: Atopic dermatitis - Type 1 hypersensitivity reaction

Option B: Autoimmune hemolytic anemia - Type 2 hypersensitivity reaction

Option D: Multiple sclerosis - Type 4 hypersensitivity reaction

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Hypersensitivity Reactions

Type

Immune Mechanisms

Histopathological lesions

Immediate
 hypersensitivity
(type I)

  • Anaphylaxis
  • Allergies
  • Bronchial asthma
  • Atopic dermatitis

Production of IgE antibody →immediate release of vasoactive amines from mast cells

Vascular dilatation, edema, smooth muscle contraction, mucus production, tissue injury, inflammation

Antibody-mediated hypersensitivity
(type II)

  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
  • Goodpasture syndrome

Production of IgG, IgM → binds to antigen on target cell or tissue → phagocytosis or lysis of target cell by activated complement or Fc receptors; recruitment of leukocytes

Phagocytosis and lysis of cells; inflammation;

Immune complex-mediated hypersensitivity
(type III)

  • SLE
  • Serum sickness
  • Arthus reaction

Deposition of antigen-antibody complexes → complement activation →recruitment of leukocytes by complement products and Fc receptors → release of enzymes and other toxic molecules

Inflammation, necrotizing vasculitis (fibrinoid necrosis)

Cell-mediated hypersensitivity
(type IV)

  • Contact dermatitis
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Type 1 diabetes
  • Tuberculosis

Activated T lymphocytes →

1. Release of cytokines, inflammation, and macrophage activation

2. T-cell-mediated cytotoxicity

Perivascular cellular infiltrates; edema; granuloma formation; cell destruction

Related Pearl: Types of Type II Antibody-Mediated Hypersentivity

There are 3 mechanisms involved in type 2 hypersensitivity reactions- 

  1. Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction- antibodies react with antigens present on cell surfaces or in the extracellular matrix cause disease by destroying these cells, triggering inflammation, or interfering with normal functions
    1. Myasthenia gravis (against acetylcholine receptor)
    2. Graves’ disease (against TSH receptor)
    3. Pemphigus Vulgaris (against epidermal cadherin)
    4. Pernicious anemia (against intrinsic factor)
    5. Insulin resistant diabetes (against insulin receptor
  2. Antibody-mediated opsonization and phagocytosis -antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement and Recruiting Phagocytes
    1. Transfusion reactions
    2. Erythroblastosis fetalis
    3. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
    4. Autoimmune thrombocytopenic purpura
  3. Complement and Fc receptor-mediated inflammation- antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement
    1. Goodpasture syndrome
    2. Vasculitis due to ANCA
    3. Acute rheumatic fever
    4. Vascular rejection in organ graft 

Related Pearl: Examples of Type IV Hypersensitivity

Type IV Hypersensitivity Reactions 

  • Tuberculin reaction
  • Lepromin test
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Chronic graft rejection
  • Contact dermatitis
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Primary biliary cirrhosis
  • Type I lepra reaction
  • Crohn’s disease
  • Psoriasis

questions.text:
A 9-month-old baby is brought for routine vaccination. The mother of the baby enquires about the vaccines to be given for the prevention of pneumonia. How is PPV23 vaccine different from PCV13 vaccine?

PPV23-Pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine 23

PCV13-Pneumococcal conjugate vaccine 13

choices.text: PPV23 cannot be given to children <2 years of age.
PPV23 can be given via the intramuscular route.
PPV23 can be given to splenectomized individuals.

questions.solution:
The correct answer is option A - PPV23 cannot be given to children <2 years of age. It is a polysaccharide vaccine and children below 2 years of age and immunocompromised patients do not respond well to the vaccine; hence, this vaccine is avoided in these groups.

Pneumococcal vaccines include the following:

  • Pneumococcal conjugate vaccines (PCV): 10-valent (PCV10) and 13-valent (PCV13)
  • Pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPV) 23: 23-valent polysaccharide vaccine (PPV23)
Pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV) 13 Pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPV)23
It includes purified capsular polysaccharides of 13 serotypes of Streptococcus pneumoniae conjugated to a nontoxic variant of diphtheria toxin. It contains polysaccharide antigens from 23 types of pneumococcal bacteria.
In India, 2 primary doses at 6 and 14 weeks and 1 booster is given at 9–12 months via the intramuscular route. It is available for adults and children over 2 years of age, who respond well to the vaccine. It can be given intramuscularly or subcutaneously. 
Regardless of the presence of underlying medical conditions (e.g., HIV-infected children, sickle cell disease, post-splenectomy state, or immunocompromised state due to other reasons), PCV should be given according to the national schedule.   

It is recommended for selected clinical settings, such as the following:

  • Post-splenectomy state 
  • Sickle-cell disease
  • Chronic diseases of heart, lung, liver, or kidney
  • Generalized malignancies
  • Organ transplants
 

When primary immunization is initiated with one of these vaccines, it is recommended that the remaining doses are administered with the same product. WHO recommends the inclusion of PCVs in childhood immunization programs worldwide.

questions.text: Garrod’s tetrad includes all of the following, except ____.
questions.solution:
Phenylketonuria is not a component of Garrod's tetrad.

Garrod’s tetrad includes the following:

  • Alkaptonuria: Due to homogentisate oxidase deficiency
  • Albinism: Due to tyrosinase deficiency
  • Cystinuria: A type of aminoaciduria that prevents proper reabsorption of basic, or positively charged, amino acids that includes cystine, ornithine, lysine and arginine(COLA)
  • Pentosuria: Due to the deficiency of L-xylulose reductase or xylitol dehydrogenase, which are necessary for xylitol metabolism

Garrod's tetrad is named after the British physician Archibald Garrod, who introduced the phrase "inborn error of metabolism" in a lecture in 1908. His insights provided a foundation for the developing field of biochemical genetics.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient is diagnosed with dengue fever. He developed a saddleback fever. Which of the following is an accurate description of this fever pattern?

choices.text: Temperature remains elevated above normal, without touching the baseline, and the degree of fluctuation is <0.6 °C
Acute fever followed by a remission lasting for 1–2 days; then, the fever reappears and lasts for 1-2 days
Fever lasts for 3–10 days, followed by an afebrile period of 3–10 days
Temperature remains elevated above normal, without touching the baseline, and the degree of fluctuation is >0.6 °C

questions.solution:
In the saddleback type fever, which is seen in dengue, acute fever followed by a remission lasting for 1–2 days; then, the fever reappears and lasts for 1-2 days.

Pel-Ebstein fever is a fever lasting for 3–10 days, followed by an afebrile period of 3–10 days. (option C)

Continuous fever is characterised by the temperature remaining elevated, without touching the baseline, and the fluctuation not exceeding 0.6°C. This type of fever is seen in cases of lobar pneumonia, infective endocarditis, enteric fever, etc.(option A)

Remittent fever is characterised by temperature fluctuations exceeding 0.6°C, but without touching the baseline. (option D)

Relapsing fever is characterized by several days of fever, followed by several days of an afebrile period, after which the cycle repeats (e.g. Borrelia infection and rat-bite fever)

Tertian fever occurs on the first and third days. (e.g. infection with Plasmodium vivax, Plasmodium ovale, and Plasmodium falciparum)

Quartan fever occurs on the first and fourth days. (e.g. Plasmodium malariae infection)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic feature of hematuria associated with glomerulonephritis?
questions.solution:
Hematuria associated with glomerulonephritis is typically painless.

Hematuria from within the glomerulus is often associated with brown-, cola-, or tea-colored urine. Urine analysis reveals RBC casts and deformed urinary RBCs (particularly acanthocytes).

Related Pearl: Nephrotic and nephritic syndromes

 

Nephrotic Syndrome

Nephritic Syndrome (Glomerulonephritis)

Primary pathology

Damage and dysfunction of glomerular filtration barrier, causing significant leakage of plasma proteins without much glomerular inflammation

Significant inflammatory injury of the glomerulus resulting in passage of RBCs, inflammatory cells & plasma proteins

The principal site of glomerular injury

 Visceral epithelial cell (Podocyte) Endothelial cells, glomerular basement membrane (GBM), Mesangial cells, Parietal epithelial cells (>Crescents)

Clinical features

Hallmark:

Heavy Proteinuria: 3.5 g/24 h or Urine protein:creatinine ratio >3) 

Hypoalbuminemia, 

Edema

Lipiduria, Hyperlipidemia

Microscopic hematuria

Hypertension

Hypercoagulability                                                    

Hallmark:

Hematuria (RBC casts/dysmorphic RBCs)

Varying degrees of proteinuria and pyuria

Renal dysfunction

Hypertension

Associated Glomerular pathology

Minimal change disease (Primary and secondary)

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) (Primary and secondary)

Membranous-nephropathy (Primary and secondary)

Diabetic nephropathy

Amyloidosis

Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (crescentic)

IgA nephropathy (Berger disease)

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis

Alport syndrome

These syndromes, however, are not mutually exclusive. Some glomerular diseases may progress from one pattern to another or may present with considerable overlap between them, as a nephritic–nephrotic syndrome; features of nephrotic syndrome can concurrently occur with any form of nephritic syndrome but are most commonly seen with diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (seen in systemic lupus erythematosus) and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman was brought to the casualty in an unconscious state after having suddenly collapsed. As there was no pulse, cardiopulmonary resuscitation was started and the monitor showed a weak electrical activity. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
As the patient has pulseless electrical activity (PEA), 1mg epinephrine IV has to be given immediately.

A pulseless electrical activity involves a heterogeneous group of cardiac rhythms, all without a pulse.

The immediate treatment for this is giving chest compressions and 1 mg epinephrine at the earliest until definitive therapy to the cause can be instituted.

It is essential to rule out the reversible causes of cardiac arrest because the treatment for each of them is different and PEA is likely to persist until the cause is treated. If left untreated, PEA may develop into asystole or ventricular fibrillation.

Other options:

Option A: Defibrillation delivers an electrical current to interrupt the disorganized cardiac activity in ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation (shockable rythms) to restore an organized cardiac rhythm. 

Option B: Synchronized cardioversion is a low-energy shock given in sync with the peak of the QRS complex in cases of unstable atrial fibrillation, atrial flutter, atrial tachycardia, and supraventricular tachycardias.

Option D: Atropine was removed from the 2010 ACLS guidelines as standard treatment for cardiac arrest patients with a non-shockable rhythm or adults with pulseless electrical activity (PEA) due to a lack of clear benefit. 

Related Pearl: Adult cardiac arrest algorithm (Updated as per 2020 guidelines)

The adult cardiac arrest algorithm is based on the AHA guidelines as shown below. 

Related Pearl: Reversible Causes of Cardiac Arrest

  • 5 H’s:
    • Hypovolemia
    • Hypoxia
    • Hydrogen ion (acidosis)
    • Hypokalemia or hyperkalemia
    • Hypothermia
  • 5 T’s:
    • Tension pneumothorax
    • Tamponade (cardiac)
    • Toxins
    • Thrombosis (pulmonary)
    • Thrombosis (coronary)

questions.text: A pap smear was done on a 39-year-old woman as a part of a routine health checkup. The cytology picture is shown below. The cell marked A in the smear is _______.
questions.solution:
The cell marked A in the smear is a superficial cell which is an estrogen-dominant cell. These are acidophilic (pink) cells with a pyknotic nucleus seen predominantly in the first half of the menstrual cycle.

  • Intermediate cells: Progesterone dominant cells which are basophilic (blue or green) with distinct margins and nuclei bigger than that of superficial cells. These are seen in the 2nd half of the menstrual cycle and pregnancy.
  • Basal and parabasal cells are seen when no hormone predominates. These are basophilic cells with no distinct outlines and a much larger nucleus. Seen in menopause and the postpartum period.
  • Human papilloma infected cells: Shows koilocytes. These cells have hyperchromatic enlarged nuclei and perinuclear halo.

The cytology image of a normal Pap smear is shown below.

The koilocytes(right side) compared to normal Pap smear(left side).

questions.text: A man complains of fatigue and numbness in his hands and feet. On examination, he looked pale and his reflexes were poor. The peripheral smear showed a megaloblastic picture. Which of the following tests can differentiate between megaloblastic anemia due to folate and vitamin B12 deficiency?

choices.text: Methylmalonic acid excretion in the urine
Hypersegmented neutrophils in peripheral blood smear

questions.solution:
Measurement of methylmalonic acid (MMA) excretion in urine can be used to differentiate between megaloblastic anemia due to folate and vitamin B12 deficiency. 

Methylmalonyl-CoA mutase is a vitamin B12–dependent enzyme. The activity of methylmalonyl-CoA mutase is greatly reduced in vitamin B12 deficiency, leading to the accumulation of methylmalonic acid in serum and its excretion in urine.

The test for MMA excretion is also used to assess the nutritional status of vitamin B12.

There are two vitamin B12–dependent enzymes:

  • Methionine synthase (homocysteine methyltransferase): This enzyme catalyzes the conversion of homocysteine to methionine. This requires both vitamin B12 and folate.
  • Methylmalonyl CoA mutase: Methylmalonyl-CoA, formed as an intermediate in the catabolism of valine, isoleucine, and propionyl CoA, is converted to succinyl CoA.

Homocysteine will be elevated in both vitamin B12 deficiency and folate deficiency. 

The figure below shows vitamin B12 serving as a cofactor of methionine synthase.

Related Pearl: Causes of Megaloblastic Anemia

Vitamin B12 Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Vegetarianism
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Intrinsic factor deficiency
    • Pernicious anemia
    • Gastrectomy
    • Malabsorption states
    • Diffuse intestinal disease (e.g., lymphoma, systemic sclerosis)
    • Ileal resection
    • Ileitis
  • Competitive parasitic uptake
    • Fish tapeworm infestation
    • Bacterial overgrowth in blind loops and diverticula of bowel

Folic Acid Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Alcoholism
    • Infancy
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Malabsorption states
    • Intrinsic intestinal disease
    • Anticonvulsants
    • Oral contraceptives
  • Increased Loss
    • Hemodialysis
  • Increased Requirement
    • Pregnancy, infancy
    • Disseminated cancer
    • Markedly increased hematopoiesis
  • Impaired Utilization
    • Folic acid antagonists
    • Unresponsive to vitamin B12 or folic acid therapy
    • Metabolic inhibitors of DNA synthesis and/or folate metabolism

questions.text:
A drug is instilled into the right eye of the rabbit, and the left eye is used as the control. The findings obtained after some time are shown in the table and image given below.
Reflex Right eye Left eye
Corneal reflex Present Present
Light reflex Absent Present

Which of the following drugs is likely to have been instilled?
questions.solution:
On instillation of the drug, there is mydriasis in the eye and loss of light reflex. The drug is likely to be atropine. It is an anticholinergic agent. It causes mydriasis, cycloplegia, loss of light reflex, and impaired accommodation.

Autonomic supply of the eye:

The radial muscle of the iris is controlled by α1 adrenergic receptor. Stimulation of this receptor causes mydriasis. 

The sphincter muscle of the iris is controlled by the M3 and M2 cholinergic receptors. Stimulation of these receptors causes miosis.

The ciliary muscle is supplied by the β2 adrenergic receptors as well as M3 and M2 cholinergic receptors. The β2 receptors cause relaxation of the ciliary muscle, which helps in far vision, while M3 and M2 receptors cause contraction of the ciliary muscle, which helps in near vision.

Lacrimal glands are supplied by the α receptors and M3 and M2 receptors. They increase lacrimal secretion.

Effects of various drugs on the eye

Class Muscarinic receptor antagonist Cholinesterase inhibitors Muscarinic receptor agonist Adrenergic agonist Local anesthetic
Drugs Atropine, homatropine, Scopalamine, Tropicamide Physostigmine, neostigmine, pyridostigmine, organophosphorus compounds, etc Pilocarpine Epinephrine Cocaine
Mechanism of action in the eye Blocks M3 and M2 receptors Stimulates M3 and M2 receptors Stimulates M3 and M2 receptors in the eye Stimulates α1 receptor  in the eye Blocks sodium channel and blocks norepinephrine transporter
Effect on iris Mydriasis Miosis Miosis Mydriasis Mydriasis
Corneal reflex Present Present Present Present Absent
Light reflex Absent Present Present Present Present
Lacrimal secretions Decreased Increased Increased  Increased ---

Related Pearl: Effect of ANS in the Eye

  Adrenergic System Cholinergic system
  Action Receptor Action Receptor
Iris radial muscle Contraction - Mydriasis α1 --------- ---------
Iris circular muscle --------- --------- Contraction - Miosis  M3
Ciliary Muscle Relaxation – Far vision β2 Contraction – Near vision M3
Lacrimal glands Secretion + α Secretion + M3, M2

questions.text: A woman presents with fever on the 3rd postpartum day and is put on antibiotics. Fever is still not brought under control. On further investigation, she is diagnosed to have septic pelvic thrombophlebitis. Which among the following is the next course of treatment for her?
questions.solution:
Antibiotics plus heparin is the next course of treatment for septic pelvic thrombophlebitis.

Septic pelvic thrombophlebitis refers to the presence of an endovascular thrombus in the setting of associated bacterial or fungal infection.

The treatment of septic pelvic thrombophlebitis is broad-spectrum antibiotics plus anticoagulation. Anticoagulation is thought to prevent further thrombosis and reduce the spread of septic emboli.

questions.text: A researcher plots the following graph while analyzing the UV  absorbance spectrum of amino acids. Which amino acid does the blue curve indicate?
questions.solution:
Here the blue curve represents tryptophan, which shows maximum UV absorbance at 280 nm wavelength.

Amino Acids absorb UV light due to aromatic ring. Aromatic amino acids such as tyrosine, tryptophan, and phenylalanine absorb 250 to 290 nm UV light. The maximum absorption of UV light is by tryptophan. Because tryptophan absorbs ultraviolet light about ten times more efficiently than either phenylalanine or tyrosine. It shows maximum absorption at 280 nm.

Absorption of UV light by amino acids:

  • Amino acids do not absorb visible light and thus are colourless.
  • Compounds with conjugated double bonds absorb UV light. That is why aromatic amino acids, porphyrins, purine, and pyrimidine bases absorb UV light. Among the aromatic amino acids, tyrosine, phenylalanine, and especially tryptophan absorb high-wavelength (250-290 nm) ultraviolet light.
  • Light absorbing capacity of aromatic amino acids is used to estimate the protein concentration with a spectrophotometer (an instrument that can measure the light absorbance from infrared to ultraviolet range).
  • With the absorbance value of a known concentration of protein solutions, a standard curve is made. The concentration of the protein is calculated using the standard curve.

The light absorption wavelength range of compounds:

Compound λ max (nm)(wavelength at which maximal light absorption occurs)
Peptide bond 190 - 230
Purine and pyrimidine bases 260
Aromatic amino acids 280
NADH & NADPH 340
Porphyrin 400

 

Given below is the image showing UV absorption spectra of different amino acids.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents with swelling in the lower part of the thigh.  During the night, he has severe pain in the region of the swelling, and the pain reduces after taking aspirin. The x-ray is shown below.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with the x-ray showing a peripheral sclerotic rim with central radiolucent nidus, is suggestive of osteoid osteoma.

Osteoid osteoma is a benign neoplasm, most often seen in men in the second to third decade of life. In most cases, the lesion appears in the lower extremities, commonly in the femur and tibia. A patient typically presents with pain that worsens at night and is relieved by taking NSAIDs.

Radiography shows a sclerotic peripheral rim with central radiolucent nidus. CT scan can be used to identify the nidus and confirm the diagnosis.

Anti-inflammatory medication can be used for long-term medical management. Percutaneous radiofrequency ablation can be used as an outpatient procedure. Removal of the entire nidus can be done by curettage or en-bloc resection.


Other options:

Option A - Ewing's sarcoma is a malignant bone tumor occurring mainly in the diaphysis of long bones. On x-ray, cortical destruction, and new bone formation in layers are seen, giving the typical onion-peel appearance, as shown below.


Option B- Chondroblastoma is a benign cartilaginous tumor that occurs mainly in bones around the knee joint. On x-ray, the tumor appears as a well-circumscribed, round, or oval lytic lesion in the center of the epiphysis of long bones, with areas of calcification within the tumor, giving the characteristic mottled appearance.

The image below shows an x-ray with a well-circumscribed, round, lytic lesion in the center of the epiphysis of the tibia, which is suggestive of chondroblastoma:


Option D - Osteoblastoma is a benign bone tumor occurring mainly in the spine. Symptoms are similar to those of osteoid osteoma. On X-ray, a radioopaque central nidus with a surrounding radiolucent halo is seen.

The image below shows an osteoblastoma in the C7 vertebra:

questions.text: A patient with HIV is on cotrimoxazole prophylaxis. He presents with a 4 cm laceration that requires suturing under local anesthesia. Which of the following local anesthetic agents would not be preferred in this case?
questions.solution:
The patient is on treatment with cotrimoxazole, a sulfonamide (sulfamethoxazole). The action of sulfonamides is inhibited by procaine, and so it would not be preferred in this patient.

Procaine is hydrolyzed in vivo to produce para-aminobenzoic (PABA) acid that inhibits the action of sulfonamides. All ester local anesthetics produce para-aminobenzoic acid. 

Prilocaine, lidocaine, and bupivacaine are amides and do not interact with sulphonamides.

Related Pearl: Classification of local anesthetics based on chemical structure

Plasma cholinesterase

Exception: Articaine - plasma cholinesterase.

Duration of action

Shorter-acting

Exception: Tetracaine

Longer-acting

Exception: Articaine 
Allergic reaction High incidence due to metabolite PABA Rare

questions.text: A healthy 55-year-old man presented with a 1-week history of fever, chills, right upper quadrant tenderness, and hepatomegaly. CT was suggestive of a pyogenic liver abscess. Identify the catheter shown below and its use in this condition.

choices.text: Pigtail catheter, used if surgery fails
Malecot catheter, used if surgery fails

questions.solution:
The image shows a pigtail catheter, which is routinely used for percutaneous drainage. It enables the slow decompression of cysts with viscous contents. Also, the risk of dislodgement is low with the pigtail catheter.

A drainage tube catheter is placed under US/CT guidance into the liver abscess. Empiric IV antibiotic therapy is the first-line treatment for pyogenic liver abscesses.

Surgical drainage using a laparoscopic or open approach is attempted only when antibiotic therapy and percutaneous drainage fail. Open drainage is increasingly becoming less common. Liver resection is only occasionally required in severe hepatic destruction.

Pigtail catheter:

The image below shows the Malecot catheter.

The Malecot catheter is a rubber catheter with a flower-shaped ending. It is never introduced per-urethrally.

It is a self-retaining catheter with an umbrella or flower tip. It contains sulfur and is therefore radio-opaque. It can be sterilized by boiling.

Uses:

  • Suprapubic cystostomy
  • Perinephric abscess
  • Pyonephrosis
  • Cabot’s nephrostomy
  • Subphrenic abscess
  • Cholecystotomy
  • Infected pseudocyst of pancreas
  • Amebic liver abscess
  • Gastrostomy

questions.text: An elderly patient presented with a rectal mass protruding through the anus after straining. The following procedure was planned for him. Which of the following statements is not true regarding the procedure shown in the image?

choices.text: It is done via the perineal approach.
It is associated with high surgical morbidity.
It has a high recurrence rate.

questions.solution:
The image depicts Delorme's procedure, which is associated with less surgical morbidity.

The perineal approach for the surgical correction of rectal prolapse is often preferred in patients with high operative risk and limited life expectancy, i.e. in the elderly. It is associated with less morbidity but has a higher recurrence rate. 

Rectal prolapse occurs when a mucosal or full-thickness layer of rectal tissue protrudes through the anal orifice. Rectal prolapse is of two types:

1) Partial rectal prolapse- in this type, only the mucosal layer of the rectum is prolapsed. It is seen in children. The first episode is managed by digital repositioning. If there is a recurrence, then Theirsch's wiring or sclerotherapy is done. 

2) Complete rectal prolapse- in this type, all the layers of the rectum are prolapsed. It is seen in adults due to the weakening of the pelvic floor. It is managed by using the following approaches:

  • The perineal approach- It is easy to perform, has fewer complications but a high recurrence rate. It is preferred in elderly patients with comorbidities. The surgeries done using this approach for rectal prolapse are the following:
    • Thiersch's wiring- A steel wire/silastic/nylon tape is placed around the anal canal. Largely obsolete now due to problems with chronic perineal sepsis, anal stenosis, and obstructed defecation. This procedure is rarely used now.
    • Delorme's mucosectomy- in this procedure, the rectal mucosa is stripped circumferentially from the rectum over the length of the prolapse. The underlying muscle is plicated with a series of sutures. The excess rectal mucosa is excised and a mucosal anastomosis is performed.
    • Altemeier's rectosigmoidoscopy- in this procedure, the rectum is prolapsed through the anal canal and a full-thickness resection is performed, incorporating any associated colonic prolapse. Restoration of colorectal continuity can be performed by hand-sewn/stapled anastomosis. This is the procedure of choice in patients presenting with incarcerated and strangulated prolapse.

The perineal approach is often preferred in patients with high operative risk and limited life expectancy, i.e. in the elderly. It is associated with less morbidity but has a higher recurrence rate. 

  • The abdominal approach- It is difficult to perform and has more complications, but a lower recurrence rate. The surgeries done using this approach are the following: 
    • Ripstein's procedure- It involves the placement of a prosthetic mesh around the mobilized rectum, with the attachment of the mesh to the presacral fascia (anterior) below the sacral promontory.
    • Well's procedure- it involves posterior rectopexy. 
    • Suture rectopexy
    • Mesh rectopexy
    • Lateral (Orr-Loygue)
    • Ventral
    • Resection rectopexy (Frykman–Goldberg)

The principle of all abdominal operations for rectal prolapse is to fix the rectum in its normal anatomical position. Abdominal approaches (laparoscopic, robotic, or open) are preferred for younger patients, particularly those with constipation or associated pelvic floor disorders.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man hailing from Mumbai presents to you with complaints of abdominal pain and malaise. On examination, he is icteric and the liver is palpable 6 cm below the costal margin. On further questioning, he informs you that a few weeks back the drains surrounding his house were overflowing due to the monsoon flooding. Which of the following is the most likely etiology?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario with icterus, hepatomegaly, and environmental history is suggestive of acute viral hepatitis, likely to be caused by hepatitis A or E viruses. 

Hepatitis A and E are transmitted by feco-oral route. Overcrowding, poor hygiene, and fecal contamination of water supplies such as after monsoon flooding can lead to spreading of the disease. Hepatitis E in particular is linked to fulminant hepatitis in pregnant individuals and has a poor prognosis. 

Hepatitis B, C, and D are transmitted by parenteral routes, e.g. blood transfusions.

questions.text: A  newborn male baby was found to have a very small occiput and posterior fossa. MRI imaging showed the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a baby with a very small occiput and posterior fossa and an image showing herniation of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum is suggestive of Chiari malformation. It is the most common malformation of the posterior fossa and hindbrain.

Children present with headaches that are worse with straining and other maneuvers that increase intracranial pressure. Symptoms of
brainstem compression, such as diplopia, oropharyngeal dysfunction, spasticity, tinnitus, sleep apnea, and vertigo, can occur due to brain stem compression. Incidental Chiari malformation with radiological findings compatible with Chiari malformation with no clinical manifestations of the disease is also seen. 

Chiari malformations are classified based on their morphology and severity of anatomic defects, typically through imaging or autopsy to Chiari I - Chiari IV. The Chiari I malformation is the most common type evaluated using magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), typically in a child or adult. Chiari II to IV malformations is often first evaluated by ultrasound in utero, with fetal MRI assessment performed for further characterization.

Muscle relaxants, NSAIDs, and the temporary use of a cervical collar are used to treat headaches and neck pain.  The main treatment for re-establishing the CSF flow across the craniovertebral junction and relieving pressure on the cerebellum and hindbrain by decompressing the posterior fossa in Chiari malformation is surgical. This can be achieved by a suboccipital craniectomy in conjunction with C1 and C2 laminectomy. 

Other options:

Option A- Mega cisterna magna/ Arachanoid cyst can also cause hydrocephalus. It is characterized by an enlarged CSF space inferior and dorsal to the cerebellar vermis. Persisting Blake pouch is a cyst that obstructs the subarachnoid space. 

The image below shows a CT of an arachnoid cyst. 

 

Option B- Joubert syndrome is an autosomal recessive ciliopathy associated with cerebellar vermis hypoplasia and molar tooth sign (a deepening of the interpeduncular fossa with thick and straight superior cerebellar peduncles). It is characterized by developmental delay, hypotonia, ataxia, breathing abnormalities including episodic apnea and hyperpnea.

The image below shows an MRI of Joubert syndrome demonstrating the molar tooth sign.  

 

Option C- Dandy-Walker syndrome is a congenital malformation that involves:

  • Cystic dilation of the fourth ventricle
  • Hypoplasia of the cerebellar vermis
  • Hydrocephalus
  • Enlargement of the posterior fossa.

The below MRI shows dilation of the fourth ventricle with hypoplasia of the cerebellar vermis.

questions.text: A 20-month-old child diagnosed with severe acute malnutrition (SAM) is brought to your clinic. Being a case of complicated SAM, you decide to carry out inpatient management. Which of the following is incorrect regarding hypoglycemia detected in the stabilization phase?

choices.text: It is diagnosed when blood glucose is <54 mg/dL
If the patient is unconscious, immediately start 10% IV glucose
Asymptomatic hypoglycemia need not be treated

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement regarding hypoglycemia, in the stabilization phase of severe acute malnutrition(SAM) management, is option D.

The treatment for asymptomatic hypoglycemia includes 10% glucose 50 mL given orally or by nasogastric tube followed by the first feed. Feed every 2 hours for at least the first day.

The general inpatient treatment of complicated SAM involves 10 steps in 2 phases:

Initial stabilization phase: It focuses on restoring homeostasis and treating medical conditions and requires 2–7 days of inpatient treatment.

Mnemonic: SHIELDED

  • Sugar deficiency(hypoglycemia) 
  • Hypothermia
  • Infection
  • ELectrolyte imbalance
  • DEhydration
  • Deficiency of nutrients

Rehabilitation phase: It focuses on rebuilding wasted tissue and generally takes several weeks.

Hypoglycemia is diagnosed when the blood glucose is <54 mg/dL (<3 mmol/L). Treatment of asymptomatic hypoglycemia is discussed above. For symptomatic hypoglycemia i.e, when the patient is unconscious, give 10% glucose 5 mL/kg IV immediately followed by 50 m: of 10% glucose oral or by NG tube. Feed every 2 hours at least for the first day.

Hypoglycemia and hypothermia can coexist and they are signs of severe infection. Thus keep the patient warm and start broad-spectrum antibiotics as well.

questions.text: The snake shown in the image is found in the ocean. Its venom is most likely to be:
questions.solution:
The snake in the given image is a sea snake, and its venom is myotoxic. 

The venom of sea snakes is myotoxic. Myotoxin causes severe muscle necrosis via a non-enzymatic mechanism.
