questions.text: A 10-year-old girl presents with a 2-day history of fever and joint pain. She had a sore throat 3 weeks back, for which she was not given any medications. She has a rash on her body as shown in the image below. Identify the skin rash.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a young girl presenting with fever, joint pain, and a recent history of sore throat is suggestive of acute rheumatic fever. The associated evanescent macular rash, with central clearing in the image, is erythema marginatum.

Erythema marginatum is included as a major manifestation in the Jones criteria. It is an evanescent, non-pruritic rash over the trunk and extremities seen in rheumatic fever.

Related Pearl: Revised Jones criteria for diagnosis of Acute Rheumatic Fever (ARF)

Revised Jones criteria for the diagnosis of rheumatic fever are as follows:

Major criteria
Low-risk populations* Moderate- and high-risk populations*
   
Carditis- Clinical or subclinical Carditis- Clinical or subclinical
Arthritis- Polyarthritis only Arthritis- Polyarthritis/polyarthralgia/monoarthritis
Chorea Chorea
Erythema marginatum Erythema marginatum
Subcutaneous nodules Subcutaneous nodules
   
Minor criteria 
Polyarthralgia Monoarthralgia
Fever (≥38.5°C) Fever (≥38°C)
ESR ≥60 mm in the first hour and/or CRP ≥3.0 mg/dL ESR ≥30 mm/hr and/or CRP ≥3.0 mg/dL
Prolonged PR interval, after accounting for age variability (unless carditis is a major criterion) Prolonged PR interval, after accounting for age variability (unless carditis is a major criterion) 
   
For all patient populations with evidence of preceding Group A Streptococcal infection:(Increased ASLO/ anti-DNAse B titer or positive throat culture for group A streptococcus or positive rapid streptococcal carbohydrate antigen test) 
Diagnosis of initial ARF 2 Major criteria or 1 major plus 2 minor criteria
Diagnosis of recurrent ARF 2 Major or 1 major and 2 minor or 3 minor criteria

*Low-risk populations are those with ARF incidence ≤2 per 100 000 school-aged children or all-age rheumatic heart disease prevalence of ≤1 per 1000 population per year. If the incidence exceeds the given limit, then it is moderate-high risk populations.

Related Pearl: Skin rashes (Erythemas)

Erythema marginatum is an evanescent, non-pruritic rash over the trunk and extremities seen in rheumatic fever.

 

Erythema nodosum is an acute, nodular, erythematous, painful eruption, occurring probably due to a delayed hypersensitivity reaction to a variety of antigens. Lesions are usually seen over the extensor aspects of the legs. Its causes include infections (tuberculosis), autoimmune (IBD and sarcoidosis), idiopathic.

 

Erythema migrans has a bull's-eye appearance (central erythema and necrosis) and is seen in Lyme disease.

 

Erythema multiforme lesions usually have a target appearance; it is mediated by the deposition of immune complexes in the superficial microvasculature of the skin and oral mucosal membrane. It is usually triggered by certain infections (herpes simplex virus) and drugs.

questions.text: A patient presented with fever, malaise, and pharyngitis. On examination, splenomegaly was present and lymph nodes were normal. Peripheral smear showed a predominance of lymphocytes. The heterophile antibody test result is negative. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Fever, malaise, pharyngitis, splenomegaly with lymphocytosis suggest infectious mononucleosis. Cytomegalovirus is the most common causative agent of heterophile-negative infectious mononucleosis.

Patients may develop CMV infectious mononucleosis spontaneously or after transfusion of leukocyte-containing blood products. They present with fever, malaise, pharyngitis and splenomegaly. Cervical lymphadenopathy is rare. Some patients develop rubelliform rashes after exposure to ampicillin. Unlike EBV mononucleosis, heterophile antibodies are negative. This condition is less severe than the infectious mononucleosis caused by Epstein-Barr virus (EBV).

questions.text: A resident asks you to calculate the obstetric score of a pregnant patient on her first antenatal visit. What is incorrect regarding parity in this score?

choices.text: One who is nulligravida is always a nullipara.
Still birth is counted in parity.

questions.solution:
The current pregnancy is not included in defining parity.

GPAL system was followed earlier: 

  • G - Gravidity - the total number of pregnancies, including the present one
  • P - Parity - the total number of pregnancies crossing the period of viability, which is 28 weeks in India 
    • This includes both live births and stillbirths.
    • The current pregnancy is not included
    • Multifetal pregnancies count as one for both gravida and para. 
  • A - Abortion - the number of pregnancy losses before 20 weeks of gestation, including induced abortions, spontaneous miscarriages, and ectopic or molar pregnancies
  • L - Living children at present

Terminology

  • Nulligravida: One who is not and has never been pregnant 
  • Primigravida: One who is pregnant for the first time
  • Multigravida: One who has previously been pregnant
  • Nullipara: One who has never completed a pregnancy to the stage of viability
  • Primipara: One who has delivered only once (fetuses born alive or dead after becoming viable)
  • Multipara: One with 2 or more pregnancies to the stage of viability or more
  • Parturient: A woman in labor
  • Stillbirth: Birth of a newborn after the period of viability, but without any signs of life at birth

Thus, a woman who is a nulligravida is always a nullipara.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old male chronic smoker presents with intermittent claudication pain of the legs for a few months. On examination, a gangrenous ulcer was present in the right big toe. Angiography revealed skip lesions in the right lower limb. Which of the following is the best treatment modality in this case?

Blood glucose and lipid profile within normal limits.
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette is suggestive of Buerger's disease or thromboangiitis obliterans (TAO). The best treatment in the above case is amputation.

A young male smoker, presenting with claudication pain, with no history of diabetes and hyperlipidemia and ulcer along with angiography showing skip lesions, are points in favor of Buerger's disease.

The treatment in the given scenario is amputation. Bypass graft will not be successful due to multiple arterial occlusions. Absolute tobacco cessation can cause clinical remission but cannot reverse the present condition (gangrenous ulcer). No effective pharmacological treatment is available.

Buerger's disease is a nonatherosclerotic segmental inflammatory occlusive vascular disorder involving small and medium-sized arteries of the upper and lower limb.

It is predominantly seen in young male smokers. Patients mainly present with claudication pain of extremities and later with ischemic rest pain and ulcers. Atherogenic conditions like diabetes and dyslipidemia should be excluded.

They may also present with pain, paresthesia, and color changes of the digits of the hand and feet in response to cold and anxiety. This is called as Raynaud phenomenon. 

The image below shows the Raynaud phenomenon in the digits of the hand.

The following criteria must be met for the diagnosis of TAO:

  • Age younger than 45 years
  • History of tobacco use
  • Distal extremity ischemia like claudication pain or ulcer
  • Autoimmune diseases, hypercoagulable state, dyslipidemia, and diabetes mellitus must be excluded
  • Consistent arteriographic findings in the limbs
  • A proximal source of atheroemboli must be excluded

Angiography shows segmental occlusions as skip lesions of the small and medium-sized vessels with the formation of extensive collaterals around the occlusions. These are called corkscrew collaterals. These represent dilated vasa vasoram of the occluded vessels.

questions.text:
A middle-aged woman presented with redness and itching over the nipple of her left breast. Histopathological findings of the lesion are shown below. Which of the following statements correctly describes the typical cells seen here?

 DCIS- Ductal carcinoma in situ, LCIS- Lobular carcinoma in situ.

choices.text: ER negative, malignant cells arising from underlying DCIS
ER positive, benign cells arising from underlying DCIS
ER positive, malignant cells arising from underlying LCIS
ER negative, benign cells arising from underlying LCIS

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image showing Paget's cells (malignant cells with abundant pale cytoplasm and pleomorphic nuclei) are suggestive of Paget's disease of the nipple. These cells are ER-negative, malignant cells arising from underlying DCIS.

Paget's disease of the nipple is a rare form of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). The characteristic Paget's cells are scattered individually throughout the squamous epithelium. They do not breach the basement membrane but extend via the lactiferous sinuses into the nipple skin.

The following images show Paget's cells that do not breach the basement membrane.

It presents as a unilateral erythematous eruption with a scale crust. A palpable mass is seen in about half the patients with this disease.

The underlying carcinomas are usually poorly differentiated, ER-negative, and overexpress HER2. The prognosis of Paget's disease depends on the features of the underlying carcinoma.

Paget's disease may mimic the following conditions:

  • Eczema (clinical appearance) - Can be differentiated by the presence of malignant cells on biopsy.
  • Superficial spreading melanoma (histological appearance) - Paget's cells are PAS-positive and diastase resistant, unlike melanoma cells.

Note: Paget's disease of the bone is a distinct condition that results in abnormal bone metabolism due to osteoclastic overactivity.

questions.text: A patient with melioidosis was prescribed imipenem. Why was this drug administered along with cilastatin?

choices.text: Cilastatin blocks the hepatic metabolism of imipenem.
Cilastatin blocks the renal metabolism of imipenem.
Imipenem blocks the hepatic metabolism of cilastatin.
Imipenem blocks the renal metabolism of cilastatin.

questions.solution:
Imipenem is administered with cilastatin because cilastatin blocks the renal metabolism of imipenem.

Imipenem is rapidly hydrolyzed by the enzyme dehydropeptidase, which is present in the renal tubules. Therefore, imipenem is administered with cilastatin, an inhibitor of dehydropeptidase. Cilastatin inhibits the breakdown and prolongs the action of imipenem. This drug combination is used to treat infections caused by cephalosporin-resistant nosocomial bacteria.

Imipenem is a carbapenem beta-lactam antibiotic. It has a broader spectrum of action than other beta-lactams. It binds to penicillin-binding proteins and disrupts cell wall synthesis, leading to the death of susceptible microorganisms. It is resistant to hydrolysis by most β-lactamases. It is not absorbed orally. The dose should be modified for patients with renal insufficiency.

The FDA approved Recarbrio (a combination of imipenem-cilastatin and relebactam) to treat hospital-acquired bacterial pneumonia and ventilator-associated bacterial pneumonia in patients aged ≥18 years. It was previously approved for the treatment of patients with complicated urinary tract infections and complicated intra-abdominal infections who have limited or no alternative treatment options.

Note: Melioidosis, caused by Burkholderia pseudomallei, resembles glanders disease, which is due to Burkholderia mallei and primarily affects horses, with the potential for transmission to humans. It can present as acute melioidosis, leading to pneumonia with upper lobe infiltrates and symptoms similar to tuberculosis, such as fever, cough, and hemoptysis, potentially progressing to septicemia. In its chronic form, it results in caseous or suppurative lesions, skin abscesses, lymphangitis, and lymphadenopathy, and may also impact bones and internal organs.

questions.text: Which of the following lesions does not show the true isomorphic response?
questions.solution:
Image 3 shows shiny, pearly white papules, with the characteristic umbilicated (dimple at the center) appearance, which are findings suggestive of molluscum contagiosum. It does not show the true isomorphic response/Koebner phenomenon. Molluscum contagiosum shows the pseudo-Koebner phenomenon.

Koebner/isomorphic phenomenon refers to the appearance of new skin lesions on healthy skin at the site of cutaneous injury. They are typically linear, as they follow the route of the injury.

This phenomenon is seen in several conditions:

  • Psoriasis (image 1)
  • Erythema multiforme (image 2)
  • Lichen planus (image 4)
  • Lichen nitidus
  • Necrobiosis lipoidica
  • Lupus erythematosus
  • Hailey-Hailey disease
  • Darier disease
  • Vasculitis
  • Pityriasis rubra pilaris

Koebner phenomenon is diagnosed clinically using the following characteristics:

  • Linear lesions develop at the site of cutaneous injury on previously healthy skin.
  • Lesions have the same clinical and histological features as the underlying dermatosis.
  • Lesions are not due to the seeding of an infectious agent, allergic reaction, or skin breakdown.

The exact cause of such a response is unclear. Theories involving T-cell-mediated response, involvement of the dermis, and microvasculature have been implicated.

Various triggers for the Koebner phenomenon have been identified:

  • Trauma: Insect and animal bites, burns including thermal and electric, excoriation, friction, shaving, lacerations, cryotherapy, pressure sores, and orthotics
  • Chemical irritation: Tattoo-associated skin reaction, BCG vaccination, tuberculin skin test, hair dye allergy
  • Diseases: Urticaria, inflammatory dermatoses
  • Others: Phototherapy, sunburn, withdrawal of methotrexate therapy

Other features of the Koebner phenomenon:

  • Graded response to trauma: The intensity of response to trauma is unique to each patient and the underlying disease.
    • No Koebner response to injury
    • Abortive Koebner response: Lesions appear, but spontaneously vanish after a few weeks
    • Minimal Koebner response: Lesions develop at the site of trauma
    • Maximal Koebner response: Widespread lesions develop across the entire site of trauma
  • All-or-nothing response: Patients who develop the Koebner phenomenon in response to one type of injury may also develop similar responses to other types of injuries. If a patient does not exhibit the Koebner response to one type of injury, it is unlikely that it will be exhibited after any other type of injury.
  • Time taken to develop the skin lesions is unique to the patient and the specific dermatosis. It may vary from 3 days to 2 years, normally taking around 10–20 days.

Koebner phenomenon can be classified into the following types:

  • True koebnerization: New skin lesions seen with the clinical features mentioned above, as seen in vitiligo, psoriasis, and lichen planus.  
  • Pseudo-koebnerization: Appearance of similar skin lesions at the site of injury in infective lesions, like plane warts and molluscum contagiosum, due to the spread of the infective agent (virus) to the new site by seeding, especially due to scratching.

The image below shows the Koebner phenomenon seen in a psoriatic patient at the site of trauma:

Other phenomena associated with cutaneous trauma:

  • Reverse Koebner phenomenon: Disappearance of skin lesions after trauma to the area, which is seen in psoriasis after dermabrasion or surgery.
  • Remote reverse Koebner phenomenon: Occurrence of spontaneous repigmentation in distant patches after autologous skin graft surgery in vitiligo
  • Wolf's isotopic response/isotopic phenomenon: Emergence of new dermatosis at the site of a previous unrelated dermatosis, as seen in granuloma annulare developing at the site of herpes zoster and psoriasis developing at the site of contact dermatitis
  • Pathergy: Occurrence of non-specific papules and pustules secondary to heavy neutrophilic infiltrates after an injection or venipuncture, as seen in pyoderma gangrenosum and Behçet disease.
  • Renbök/inverse Koebner phenomenon: Disappearance of an existing skin condition after the onset of a new dermatosis at the same site, as seen in the retention of hair follicles on the psoriatic plaques on the scalp while hair loss is present in areas not affected with alopecia areata 

 

Related Pearl: Koebner phenomenon

Koebner or isomorphic Phenomenon is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin. The new lesions have 'iso' (same) and 'morphic' (morphology) as the existing lesions.

The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

True Koebner's phenomenon In immune-mediated conditions

Psoriasis

Vitiligo

Lichen planus
False Koebner's phenomenon In infectious diseases

Viral warts

Molluscum contagiosum
     
Remote reverse Koebner phenomenon

Spontaneous repigmentation of vitiligo patches distant from the autologous skin graft sites (trauma)

Generalized granuloma annulare

Vitiligo

Psoriasis

Some rare causes of True Koebner Phenomenon are : Darier's disease, Hailey-Hailey disease, Erythema multiforme, Kaposi's Sarcoma and Lichen sclerosus.

Image: Koebner phenomenon with linear psoriasis patch on the abdomen

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman who is a known case of tuberculosis was admitted to the hospital. Physical examination showed diffuse rales on auscultation and hepatosplenomegaly on palpation. Chest x-ray showed bilateral diffuse alveolar opacities and faint reticulonodular infiltrates. The image below shows the lung specimen of this patient. By which route would have TB bacilli spread to give rise to this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image point towards a diagnosis of miliary tuberculosis, and it is spread via hematogenous dissemination. The gross image shows characteristic millet-sized white nodules scattered throughout the lung parenchyma, which is typically seen in miliary tuberculosis.

Chest x-ray appearance of ARDS varies, depending on the severity and typically shows bilateral diffuse alveolar opacities with dependent atelectasis in some cases. The opacities can have a patchy ground-glass appearance. Hematogenous dissemination of the bacteria through arterial and venous systems leads to the manifestations of the disease in various organ systems.

Miliary pulmonary disease occurs when organisms draining through the lymphatics enter the venous blood and circulate back to the lung. It can result from progressive primary disease, reactivation of latent foci, and iatrogenic exposure (lithotripsy, urethral catheterization, cardiac valve homograft placement, and solid organ transplantation).

The risk factors for the development of miliary TB include extremes of age, alcohol use, malignancy, HIV, corticosteroid use, connective tissue disease, renal failure, diabetes, and pregnancy.

The clinicopathological patterns of this condition include acute miliary TB (which may present as multi-organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS) and ARDS, as in this patient), late generalized TB, and anergic TB (defined histologically by the absence of granulomata). Individual lesions either microscopic or small <2 mm foci of yellow-white consolidation scattered throughout the lung parenchyma. The lesions may coalesce resulting in large areas of consolidation. Serous pleural effusions, tuberculous emyema or obliterative fibrous pleuritis may occur

Laboratory tests may show pancytopenia due to bone marrow infiltration. Other findings could include anemia, thrombocytopenia/cytosis, hyponatremia, and sterile pyuria.

Chest radiography shows a faint reticulonodular pattern distributed fairly uniformly throughout the lungs. 

Histopathology shows granulomas of tuberculosis characteristically contain epithelioid macrophages, Langhans giant cells, and lymphocytes with central caseation necrosis.

Other tests include genetic testing and AFB smear/culture. Montaux test is negative in miliary TB.

questions.text: A patient has soft tissue sarcoma in the sole of the left foot. MRI shows that the tumor has infiltrated only up to the first layer of the sole. Which of the following muscles is most likely to be spared by the tumor infiltration?
questions.solution:
The flexor digiti minimi brevis is a component of the third layer of the sole. Hence, it is most likely to be spared by the tumor.

The muscles of the sole of the foot are arranged in 4 layers. From superficial to deep, the layers are numbered from one to four.

Muscles of the sole of the foot:

1st layer: This is the superficial layer which includes abductor hallucis, abductor digiti minimi, and flexor digitorum brevis.

2nd layer: It consists of flexor accessorius and the four lumbrical muscles,the tendons of flexor hallucis longus and flexor digitorum longus run in the same plane as the muscles of the second layer.

3rd layer: It contains the shorter intrinsic muscles of the toes, which are flexor hallucis brevis, adductor hallucis and flexor digiti minimi brevis.

4th layer: It consists of plantar and dorsal interossei and the tendons of tibialis posterior and fibularis longus.

questions.text: A young patient is being evaluated for medical fitness to participate in a sports event. Laboratory investigations reveal low levels of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) and normal levels of unbound T3 and T4. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Low levels of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), along with normal levels of unbound T3 and T4, suggest subclinical hyperthyroidism.(Option D)

The first step in the evaluation of thyrotoxicosis is to measure TSH and unbound T4 levels.

If the TSH is low and T4 is high, then it is a case of primary thyrotoxicosis. Patients with Graves' disease may have additional features like diffuse goiter on palpation, ophthalmopathy, and a personal or family history of autoimmune disorders. Primary thyrotoxicosis due to multinodular goiter or toxic adenoma can be identified using a radionuclide (99mTc, 123I, or 131I) scan. 

If the TSH is low and unbound T4 is normal, then measure unbound T3 levels. Elevated unbound T3 levels mean T3 thyrotoxicosis, whereas normal T3 levels mean that the patient has subclinical hyperthyroidism.

If the TSH levels are normal or increased with high unbound T4 levels, it means that increased T4 is a result of increased actions of TSH. It is caused due to TSH-secreting pituitary adenoma or thyroid hormone resistance syndrome.

If the TSH is high and unbound T4 and T3 is normal , it indicates subclinical hypothyroidism. Symptoms of hypothyroidism usually appear at TSH levels >10 mIU/L with accompanying fall in unbound T4 levels, which is referred to as clinical hypothyroidism or overt hypothyroidism. 

Related Pearl: Thyroid storm / Thyrotoxic crisis:

It is an emergency caused by an acute exacerbation of hyperthyroidism. 

Precipitating factors:

  • When a thyrotoxic patient has been inadequately prepared for thyroidectomy
  • Abrupt cessation of antithyroid medications
  • Stress
    • Infection
    • Thyroid or non-thyroid surgery
    • Trauma in patients with untreated thyrotoxicosis
  • Acute iodine load
    • Amiodarone administration 
    • Exposure to iodinated contrast agents
    • Following RAI therapy

Clinical features:

  • Fever
  • Tachycardia
  • Altered mentation (delirium, psychosis, coma)
  • GI symptoms (nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea)
  • Atrial fibrillation and cardiac failure - most common causes of death

Treatment of thyroid storm:

Treatment modality Effect
IV Fluids, ice packs Rehydration and external cooling
Propylthiouracil
(DOC)

Reduces peripheral T4 to T3 conversion
Propranolol

Block adrenergic effects

Reduces peripheral T4 to T3 conversion
Corticosteroids

Inhibits the release of thyroid hormone from the gland

Reduces peripheral T4 to T3 conversion
Lugol’s iodine/ sodium ipodate Inhibits the release of thyroid hormone from the gland
Digoxin Controls the associated atrial fibrillation
Diuretics and administration of oxygen

To manage cardiac failure

Related Pearl: Radioiodine uptake of thyroid gland

Radioactive iodine uptake (RAIU) scans are interpreted as follows:

  • High (or normal) radioiodine uptake indicates de-novo synthesis of the hormone. Therefore, there is increased hormone synthesis
  • Low (nearly absent) radioiodine uptake indicates:
    • Inflammation and destruction of thyroid tissue with release of the preformed hormone into the circulation
    • Extrathyroidal source of thyroid hormone

Conditions with high and low RAIU are given below:

High RAIU Low RAIU
  • Graves’ disease
  • Toxic multinodular goiter
  • Toxic adenoma
  • Thyroid cancer
  • Hydatidiform mole
  • TSH-secreting pituitary adenoma

 

 

 
  • Acute phase of Hashimoto’s thyroiditis
  • Drug-induced— iodine, amiodarone-induced thyroiditis
  • Subacute/ Dequervain thyroiditis
  • Radiation thyroiditis
  • Metastatic follicular thyroid carcinoma
  • Factitious (iatrogenic) thyrotoxicosis
  • Struma ovarii (extrathyroid source)
  • Hamburger thyrotoxicosis (exogenous source)

questions.text: An infant was brought by his mother for evaluation of a large head. On examination, there was growth retardation and hepatosplenomegaly. Blood investigations revealed pancytopenia. X-ray imaging is shown in the image below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the x-ray image showing dense bones is suggestive of osteopetrosis.

Osteopetrosis/Marble bone disease/Albers–Schönberg disease is a disorder involving defective bone resorption due to mutation of CLCN7 (in osteoclasts).

Clinically patients present with macrocephaly (due to hydrocephalus), developmental delay, pancytopenia (reduced bone marrow cavity), and hepatosplenomegaly (compensatory extramedullary hematopoiesis)

Blood investigations shows low serum calcium and phosphorus levels with elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH) and normal vitamin D levels.

Plain radiographs are usually diagnostic. Diffuse bone sclerosis with clubbing of metaphyses. Bone within the bone appearance and "sandwich" appearance of the vertebral bodies can be seen. The skull base shows uniform radiodensity.

Treatment: Symptomatic treatment and hematopoietic stem cell transplantation can be done.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male patient, with a history of upper respiratory tract infection, presents with rapidly progressing, symmetric, ascending paralysis since 7 days. The knee jerk reflex is absent bilaterally. Investigations show elevated CSF protein levels. Which of the following is affected by this disease?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of progressive, ascending, symmetrical weakness, following a respiratory infection is suggestive of Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS). It is an immune-mediated disease, where autoimmune cells attack the myelin proteins of the peripheral nervous system. 

GBS is caused by an immune response and/or antibodies produced against external antigens (e.g. Campylobacter jejuni, Mycoplasma pneumoniae, and human herpesvirus [HHV]) introduced by infections  or by vaccines such as influenza vaccine. These autoantibodies target similar proteins present in the person's nervous tissue—a phenomenon called molecular mimicry.

GBS manifests as a rapidly evolving motor paralysis with areflexia (or hyporeflexia), with or without sensory disturbance. It is an ascending paralysis that affects the lower limbs more than the upper limbs. It can also affect the cranial nerves, leading to features of bulbar paralysis like difficulty articulating words and excessive drooling.

Glia (Greek: glue) are cells that help in communication within the CNS. They are classified into 2 types according to their sizes—microglia and macroglia. Macroglia are of 3 types—astrocytes, oligodendrocytes, and Schwann cells.

Schwann cells and oligodendrocytes are responsible for myelin formation around the axons of the peripheral nerves and nerves in the brain and spinal cord respectively. Myelin protein zero (P0) and hydrophobic protein PMP22 are components of the myelin sheath in the peripheral nervous system. They are affected in different conditions: 

  • Multiple sclerosis - Patchy destruction of the myelin sheath in the central nervous system
  • Guillain-Barre syndrome - Autoimmune destruction of myelin protein genes (P0 and PMP22)
  • Charcot-Marrie-Tooth disease - Mutations in the myelin protein genes (P0 and PMP22) causing disruption of myelin and axonal degeneration.

Related Pearl: Glial cells and their functions

Cells

Functions

Microglia (immune system cells)

Scavenger cells that remove debris resulting from injury, infection, and disease.

Oligodendrocytes

Myelin formation in central nervous system

Schwann cells

Myelin formation in peripheral nervous system

Astrocytes :

  • Fibrous – in white matter
  • Protoplasmic – in grey matter

Astrocytes form the tight junctions making blood–brain barrier

Produce substances that are tropic to neuron

They help maintain the appropriate concentration of ions by taking up K+

They take up glutamate and convert into  glutamine

questions.text: A 40-year-old asthma patient complains of a cough with brownish expectoration. He is not responding to his usual therapy for asthma. He has elevated circulating levels of IgE and prominent peripheral eosinophilia. His chest X-ray is given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A history of asthma in this patient, along with cough with brownish expectoration and elevated circulating IgE and eosinophilia, and a chest radiograph showing the characteristic finger-in-glove sign, suggest a diagnosis of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA).

ABPA is a hypersensitivity reaction to colonisation of the airways by Aspergillus fumigatus. The risk factors predisposing to ABPA include asthma and cystic fibrosis. There is an obstruction of the bronchioles due to the inflammatory secretions, leading to breathlessness, coughing, and brown sputum casts.

The total circulating IgE and Aspergillus-specific IgE is elevated, and there is peripheral eosinophilia. Chest radiographs may show central bronchiectasis and finger-in-glove signs due to mucous impaction in the airways. The treatment of ABPA is with itraconazole and glucocorticoids.

Other options: 

Option B: Loffler syndrome refers to transient pulmonary infiltrates with eosinophilia that occur in response to the passage of helminthic larvae through the lungs, most commonly larvae of Ascaris species.

Option C: Bronchiectasis is characterised by irreversible dilatation of bronchi and bronchioles. Patients have recurrent episodes of cough with copious amounts of sputum, often foul-smelling. Radiographic features include:

  • Tramline appearance is seen in chest radiograph
  • CT shows bronchial dilatation and lack of tapering of bronchial lumen
  • A signet ring sign is seen when the diameter of the bronchi is greater than the adjacent pulmonary artery in a cross-section, as shown in the image below.

Option D: Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia (TPE) is a type I hypersensitivity reaction that occurs due to the inflammatory response to the microfilariae. The patient has a history of residence in a filaria endemic area and usually presents with nocturnal paroxysmal wheezing and cough.

questions.text: A patient with allergic rhinitis was prescribed cetirizine which is a drug acting on the H1 receptor. What is the mechanism of action of this drug in relation to its receptor?
questions.solution:
Cetirizine is a second-generation H1 receptor antagonist. All H1 receptor antagonists act by inverse agonism at the H1 receptor site.

They act by constitutively reducing the activity of the receptor and compete with histamine binding to the receptor.

H1 antagonists are divided into first-generation and second-generation drugs. First-generation antihistamines have a strong sedative property and also block autonomic receptors. They include drugs like diphenhydramine, promethazine, chlorpheniramine, cyproheptadine, and cinnarizine.

questions.text: Which of the following features is unlikely to be seen in  Miller-Fisher syndrome?
questions.solution:
Dystonia is unlikely to be seen in Miller Fisher syndrome.

Miller Fisher syndrome (MFS) is a rare variant of Guillain-Barré Syndrome, it accounts for about 5% of cases, and is characterized by a triad of ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and areflexia (without weakness). It is often associated with pupillary paralysis. 

Patients present with diplopia followed by gait and limb ataxia. Cranial nerves other than ocular motor nerves may be affected. 

The ataxia is attributed to a peripheral mismatch between proprioceptive input from the muscle spindles and the kinesthetic information from joint receptors. Motor strength is characteristically preserved.

Serum IgG antibodies to the ganglioside, GQ1b, are found in more than 90% of patients with MFS.

The prognosis is good with recovery starting within 2-4 weeks of the onset of symptoms. It is treated with IVIG (intravenous immunoglobulins) or plasmapheresis.

Related Pearl: Antibodies seen in Guillian Barre syndrome

Type Antibody
AIDP Anti GM1
AMAN Anti GD1a
AMSAN Anti GD1a
Miller Fisher syndrome Anti GQ1b
  • AIDP-Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy 
  • AMAN-Acute motor axonal neuropathy 
  • AMSAN-Acute motor sensory axonal neuropathy

questions.text:
A G2P1L1 female visits the antenatal clinic during her 4th month of gestation. She had received two doses of Td vaccine during her last pregnancy. You still recommend that she receives 2 doses of Td for the current pregnancy. What is the likely interval between her two pregnancies?

Td- Tetanus and Diphtheria
questions.solution:
The likely interval between her two pregnancies is 5 years (beyond 3 years) because she was recommended the full schedule of 2 Td doses in the current pregnancy.

Recommendations for tetanus vaccination in pregnant women:

Category Td vaccination recommendation
Previously immunized pregnant women
  • A booster dose is considered sufficient as long as the patient has been immunized within the past 3 years.
  • If the previous immunization was beyond 3 years, 2 doses of Td are administered 4 weeks apart.
  • Ideally, Td-2 or booster doses are given before 36 weeks of pregnancy.
  • Td is given to a woman in labor if she has not previously received Td.
Unimmunized pregnant women
  •  Two doses of tetanus and adult diphtheria (Td) vaccine should be given, the first as early as possible during pregnancy and the second at least a month later and at least 3 weeks before delivery.
  • These doses may be given at 16–36 weeks of pregnancy.

The tetanus and adult diphtheria (Td) vaccine is a combination of tetanus and diphtheria toxoids, with a lower concentration of diphtheria antigen (d), as recommended for older children and adults.

The MoHFW recommends the replacement of the TT vaccine with the Td vaccine for all age groups, including pregnant women. A dose of 0.5 mL is administered via the intramuscular route in the upper arm.

questions.text: You are studying the various body fluid levels using the technique shown in the image below. What is the physiological basis for using Evans blue dye (T-1824) to measure plasma volume using this method?

choices.text: The dye enters the RBCs in the plasma.
The dye leaks out of vessel wall but does not enter the cells.
The dye leaks out of vessel wall and enters the cells.
The dye does not leak out of vessel wall.

questions.solution:
The correct answer is option D- The dye does not leak out of the vessel wall. A volume of a particular body compartment using the dye-dilution technique can be measured only if the dye remains in the vascular compartment after being injected.

Figure in the question shows:

If none of the substance leaks out of the compartment, the total mass of the substance after dispersion in the compartment (Volume B × Concentration B) will equal the total mass of the substance injected (Volume A × Concentration A). By rearrangement of the equation, one can calculate the unknown volume of chamber B as,

  Volume Indicators
Total body water
  • 3H2O
  • 2H2O
  • antipyrine
ECF
  • 22Na
  • 125I-iothalamate
  • thiosulfate
  • inulin
ICF (Calculated as total body water − extracellular fluid volume)
Plasma volume
  • 125I-albumin
  • Evans blue dye (T-1824)
Blood volume

51Cr-labeled red blood cells

or calculated as

blood volume = plasma volume/(1 −hematocrit)
Interstitial fluid (Calculated as extracellular fluid volume − plasma volume)

questions.text: A 35-year-old obese woman on combined oral contraceptive pills is diagnosed with cholelithiasis for which an elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy is planned. What would you advise her about the usage of these pills before the surgery?

choices.text: Stop using pills 2 weeks before surgery
Stop using pills one day before surgery
Stop using pills 4 weeks before surgery

questions.solution:
Usage of combined oral contraceptive pills (COCPs) can be continued to the day of surgery and in the peri-operative period.

Estrogens are found to increase thromoembolic risk in patients. But modern oral contraceptives contain low amounts of estrogen. In this scenario, the risk of accidental pregnancy outweighs the significance of not taking the contraceptives prior to surgery. So, oral contraceptives can be continued. Estrogens must be discontinued only if the patient is deemed high risk for post operative venous thromboembolism. 

Barrier methods can be used during this period to prevent unwanted pregnancies. In case of emergency surgeries in patients on combined OCPs or hormone replacement therapy, perioperative thromboprophylaxis should be started.

Contraindications of COCPs:

  • Cardiac disease, hypertension, smoker over 35 years.
  • Diabetes.
  • History of thrombosis, myocardial infarct, sickle cell anemia, severe migraine.
  • Chronic liver diseases such as cholestatic jaundice of pregnancy, cirrhosis of the liver, adenoma, porphyrias.
  • Breast cancer, gall bladder disease.
  • Patient on enzyme-inducing drugs like rifampicin, and antiepileptic except sodium valproate.
  • Lactating woman.
  • Monilial vaginitis.

questions.text: A young man presented with the features of pancreatitis. Subsequent investigations showed the pancreatic anatomy to be as depicted in the image below. What is the likely embryological defect in this case?

choices.text: Failure of the complete rotation of the ventral pancreatic bud
Failure of fusion of the dorsal and ventral pancreatic buds
Failure of the complete rotation of the dorsal pancreatic bud
Hypoplasia of the dorsal and ventral pancreatic buds

questions.solution:
The given image shows pancreas divisum, which occurs due to the failure of fusion of the dorsal and ventral pancreatic buds. It is the most common congenital anomaly of the pancreas.

During embryogenesis, the developing pancreatic ducts usually fuse in such a way that most of the dorsal duct drains into the proximal part of the ventral duct. The proximal portion of the dorsal duct usually persists as an accessory duct.

In about 10% of the population, there is a failure of fusion of the dorsal and ventral pancreatic buds, leading to a condition called pancreatic divisum or pancreas divisum. Pancreatic drainage is accomplished mainly through the accessory papilla.

Since most of the pancreatic exocrine secretions exit through the dorsal duct, pancreas divisum can lead to a partial obstruction due to the small minor papilla, leading to the development of relapsing acute or chronic pancreatitis.

Option A - Failure of a complete rotation of the ventral pancreatic bud gives rise to annular pancreas.

Related Pearl: Pancreas - Most Commons

M/C cause of acute pancreatitis: Gallstones

M/C cause of chronic pancreatitis: Alcohol

M/C cause of chronic pancreatitis in children: Cystic fibrosis

M/C cause of pancreatic calcification: Alcohol

M/C congenital variant: Pancreas divisum

M/C site of thrombosis in chronic pancreatitis: Splenic vein 

M/C site of pseudoaneurysm in chronic pancreatitis: Splenic artery

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl is being administered HPV as a prophylactic measure against cervical carcinoma. Among the three types of available HPV vaccines, Cervarix, Gardasil, and Gardasil-9, which of the following characteristics is not common?
questions.solution:
Among the three types of available HPV vaccines, Cervarix, Gardasil, and Gardasil-9, protection against anogenital warts is not a common characteristic.

Cervarix is a bivalent vaccine giving protection against HPV subtypes 16 and 18. Anogenital warts are commonly caused by subtypes 6 and 11. Thus, Cervarix does not confer protection against anogenital warts.

The available vaccinations against HPV are summarized below.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents with a 2-week history of vulval swelling with increasing pain and fever for the past two days. She had no similar complaints in the past. Local examination revealed a right-sided, erythematous, tender swelling on the posterior half of the labium majus, similar to that seen in the image given below. Which of the following is the preferred management for this patient?

choices.text: Incision and drainage with Word catheter placement

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of an infection of the Bartholin gland, namely, Bartholin abscess. Incision and drainage with Word catheter placement is the preferred management for this patient as she presents with symptoms for the first time.

Bartholin glands are homologous to the male bulbourethral or Cowper glands. The ducts of these glands open in the groove between the hymen and the labia minora at approximately the 5 and 7 o’clock positions.

  • Obstruction of the Bartholin ducts by proteinaceous material or by inflammation from infection may result in Bartholin cyst formation. Symptomatic or recurrent cysts may require marsupialization or gland excision.
  • An infected Bartholin cyst can lead to a Bartholin abscess. It usually requires surgical drainage. Infection is generally polymicrobial. Bacteroides species, Peptostreptococcus species, Escherichia coli, and Neisseria gonorrhoeae are frequently encountered in the culture of purulent drainage. Less typically, Chlamydia trachomatis may be identified.

Clinical features include abdominal and vaginal discomfort with dyspareunia. A vulval cleft of the 'S' shape is usually noted on inspection. A fluctuant swelling with positive transillumination can be seen as the fluid collected is generally clear.

Treatment comprises analgesics for pain and antibiotics for combating infections. Specific treatment of Bartholin's abscess is preferably done by incision and drainage with Word catheter placement in an outpatient set-up. Previously, incision and drainage led to recurrent abscess formation due to adhesion of the incised edges and re-infection. With the advent of Word catheter placement, this method is tried first for abscess management.

Marsupialization involves the complete excision of the sac and cyst, with drainage of the contents therein and clear approximation of the edges. This method greatly reduces the recurrence rates. As it requires a greater degree of analgesia and an operation theatre set-up, this method is reserved for patients with recurrent abscess formation, Word catheter failure, and latex allergies.

Bartholinectomy is a very invasive surgery and carries a high morbidity profile. This procedure is also associated with the loss of lubricant function. 

Notes:

Recurrent Bartholin cysts in any woman above the age of 40 years should raise a suspicion of Bartholin gland cancer, and the cyst wall should be sent for biopsy.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old woman who delivered a healthy baby at 38 weeks of gestation through cesarean section passed away due to amniotic fluid embolism. Identify the incorrect statement about the condition.

DIC- Disseminated intravascular coagulation
ISTH - International Society on Thrombosis and Haemostasis

choices.text: It commonly occurs in the peripartum period.
Placenta abruption is a risk factor.
Definitive diagnosis is made by ISTH score >2.

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement about amniotic fluid embolism (AFE) is that the definitive diagnosis is made by the ISTH score >2. There are no definitive diagnostic tests for AFE hence a clinical suspicion should always be made in a patient with a peripartum cardiopulmonary compromise of sudden onset.

The International Society on Thrombosis and Haemostasis (ISTH) has a scoring system to determine the presence of DIC in pregnancy. A score of > 3 indicates DIC. Though most of the patients present with DIC features in amniotic fluid embolism, the scoring alone cannot be taken for a definitive diagnosis of AFE.

According to the American Society for Maternal-Fetal Medicine, the diagnostic criteria for amniotic fluid embolism include:

  • Sudden onset cardiorespiratory arrest, or both hypotension and respiratory compromise
  • Overt DIC
  • Onset during labor or within 30 minutes of delivery of the placenta
  • No fever with temperature of ≥38°C

Amniotic fluid embolism presents with a classic triad of hemodynamic and respiratory compromise, along with DIC. Usually, it presents during the late stages of labor or immediate postpartum (peripartum period). Gasping for air, seizures, and cardiorespiratory arrest are other features. Other causes for a similar presentation such as myocardial infarction, pulmonary embolism, and anaphylactic shock needs to be ruled out. 

Risk factors include rapid labor, meconium-stained liquor, cesarean delivery, placenta previa, eclampsia, placental abruption, polyhydramnios, uterine tears, post-term pregnancy, and advanced maternal age.

The currently accepted mechanism is the entry of fetal material into the maternal circulation which leads to the activation of proinflammatory mediator systems. This results in pulmonary vasoconstriction and hypertension. The tissue factor present in fetal material also activates factor VII resulting in DIC.

The condition can be fatal and management includes cardiopulmonary resuscitation and advanced cardiac life support.

Autopsy findings, as shown in the image below, include the presence of squamous cells shed from the fetal skin, lanugo hair, fat from vernix caseosa, and mucin derived from the fetal respiratory or gastrointestinal tract in the maternal pulmonary microvasculature.

Related Pearl: Causes of Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC)

Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is an acute, subacute, or chronic thrombohemorrhagic disorder occurring as a secondary complication in a variety of diseases. It is characterized by the activation of the coagulation sequence that leads to the formation of microthrombi throughout the microcirculation of the body. As a consequence of the thrombotic diathesis, there is a consumption of platelets, fibrin, and coagulation factors and, secondarily, activation of fibrinolytic mechanisms.

Causes of DIC:

Obstetric complications
  • Abruptio placenta
  • Retained dead fetus
  • Septic abortion
  • Amniotic fluid embolism
  • Toxemia
Infections
  • Sepsis
  • Meningococcemia
  • Histoplasmosis
  • Aspergillosis
  • Malaria
  • Toxemia 
Neoplasms
  • Ca. pancreas
  • Ca. prostate
  • Ca. lung
  • Acute promyelocytic leukemia
Massive Tissue Injury
  • Traumatic injury
  • Burns
  • Extensive surgery
Miscellaneous
  • Acute intravascular hemolysis
  • Snake bite
  • Shock
  • Stroke
  • Vasculitis
  • Aortic aneurysm
  • Liver disease

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman presents with recurrent attacks of dizziness and abdominal pain for 3 months. CT abdomen showed a well-defined 1-cm lesion in the head of the pancreas. A diagnosis of insulinoma was made. Which of the following is not a component of the classical Whipple's triad seen in this condition?

choices.text: Relief of symptoms after intravenous administration of glucose

questions.solution:
Increased levels of 72-hour-fasting insulin is not a part of classic Whipple's triad.

Whipple’s triad describes the clinical symptoms of insulinoma:

  1. Symptoms of hypoglycemia after fasting or exercise
  2. Plasma glucose levels of <2.8 mmol/L or 50 mg/dL
  3. Relief of symptoms after intravenous administration of glucose

The investigation of choice for insulinoma is the determination of 72-hour-fasting glucose and serum insulin levels.

Insulinomas having diameter of <2 cm without signs of vascular invasion or metastases are considered benign. Tumor enucleation is the technique of choice for benign insulinomas.

Distal pancreatectomy is advised for the following:

  • Tumors deep in the pancreatic body or tail
  • Tumors of size >2 cm
  • Tumors located within 2 mm of the main pancreatic duct

Medical management to treat hyperinsulinism includes frequent intake of carbohydrate-rich meals and octreotide or diazoxide.

Related Pearl: Whipple's Triad

Whipple’s triad describes the clinical symptoms of insulinoma.

  • Symptoms of hypoglycemia after fasting or exercise
  • Plasma glucose levels <2.8 mmol/L or 50 mg/dL.
  • Relief of symptoms after intravenous administration of glucose.

Related Pearl: Pancreatic Endocrine Neoplasms

Endocrine neoplasm

Clinical features

Glucagonoma

Mild diabetes mellitus, a characteristic skin rash (necrolytic migratory erythema), and anemia

Insulinoma

Clinically significant hypoglycemia

Gastrinoma

Peptic ulceration often unresponsive to therapy and in unusual locations such as the jejunum

Somatostatinoma

Diabetes mellitus, cholelithiasis, steatorrhea, and hypochlorhydria

VIPoma

Watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, achlorhydria, or WDHA syndrome

Pancreatic polypeptide-secreting endocrine tumors

Present as mass lesions as even high plasma levels of this hormone fail to cause symptoms

Islet hyperplasia (previously known as nesidioblastosis) is seen in maternal diabetes, Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome , and rare mutations in the β-cell K+-channel protein or sulfonylurea receptor.

In maternal diabetes, the fetal islets respond to hyperglycemia by increasing their size and number. In the postnatal period, these hyperactive islets may be responsible for serious episodes of hypoglycemia.

questions.text: A man drinks excessive water while running a marathon and develops headache, dizziness, and confusion. To correct the underlying electrolyte abnormality, large volume of hypertonic fluids were  rapidly administered to him. Following this he developed quadriparesis and pseudo bulbar palsy. What is the likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario the patient has developed hyponatremia. Rapid correction of hyponatremia with large volume of hypertonic fluids lead to osmotic demyelination syndrome (ODS). 

Rapid correction of hyponatremia, i.e. >8–10 mmol/24 hours or >18 mmol/48 hours, can result in ODS, which is characterized by central pontine myelinolysis. It may also cause extrapontine myelinolysis affecting the cerebellum, putamen, thalamus or lateral geniculate bodies. 

The rapid correction of hyponatremia results in water being driven out of the cell, which has adapted to a chronic state of hypotonicity, thereby leading to damage to the myelin sheath of these cells.

The clinical features of ODS include acute onset of quadriparesis, ataxia, pseudobulbar palsy and abnormal extraocular movements.

MRI is useful in establishing the diagnosis and may also identify partial forms of hyponatremia that present as confusion, dysarthria, and/or disturbances of conjugate gaze without paraplegia. MRI findings include:

  • Owl's eye appearance - due to the sparing of the peripheral pontine fibers and the descending corticospinal tracts
  • Monkey sign - due to signal alteration in the basal pons

Prevention depends on therapeutic guidelines for the restoration of severe hyponatremia. The correctin of severe hyponatremia should aim for a gradual correction, i.e. ≤8 mmol/L (8 meq/L) within 24 hours and 15 mmol/L (15 meq/L) within 48 hours.

Other options: 

Option A: Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS) is a life-threatening complication that can occur anytime during antipsychotic treatment. Haloperidol is known to cause NMS. Clinical features include motor and behavioral symptoms like muscular rigidity, dystonia, akinesia, mutism, obtundation, and agita­tion. Autonomic symptoms include fever, diaphore­sis, and increased pulse and blood pressure.

Option B: Cerebral salt wasting syndrome results from hypersecretion of atrial natriuretic peptide. It is seen primarily with central nervous system disorders including brain tumors, head trauma, hydrocephalus, neurosurgery, cerebrovascular accidents, and brain death. It is associated with hyponatremia, polyuria and elevated urinary sodium excretion. Treatment is by restoring intravascular volume with sodium chloride and water.

Option D: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy is an encephalitis caused when JC polyomavirus infects the oligodendrocytes and leads to demyelination. It usually occurs in immunocompromised individuals. The patients develop focal and progressive neurological symptoms.

questions.text: A middle-aged man admitted to a medicine department develops hypersplenism. All of the following statements pertaining to this  are true except _____

choices.text: Patient can have combination of anemia, leucopenia or thrombocytopenia.

questions.solution:
Hypoplastic bone marrow or bone marrow failure is not seen in a patient with hypersplenism.

Hypersplenism is an indefinite clinical syndrome that is characterized by:

  • Splenic enlargement.
  • Combination of anemia, leucopenia, or thrombocytopenia.
  • Compensatory bone marrow hyperplasia.
  • Improvement after splenectomy.

questions.text: A woman with a deformed nasal tip is set to undergo an augmentation rhinoplasty. The plastic surgeon is performing the procedure using an autologous auricular graft. Images A and B show the donor and recipient sites, respectively. What type of tissue is the structure that is being harvested during the procedure?
questions.solution:
The structure that is being harvested for the rhinoplasty procedure is a part of the auricular cartilage. It is a type of elastic cartilage.

Elastic cartilage, like hyaline cartilage, contains individual or small groups of chondrocytes that are surrounded by type II collagen fibrils. However, it differs from hyaline cartilage in that, much of the interterritorial matrix consists of fine yellow elastic fibers containing elastin protein.

Microscopic fidings of elastic cartilage:

  • Chondrocytes within lacunae
  • Elastic fibers in the matrix
  • Perichondrium with outer fibrous layer and the inner cellular layer

questions.text:
A 35-year-old obese woman has recently been diagnosed with NASH. She is non-diabetic and non-hypertensive, and she has never consumed alcohol. On evaluation, there is no evidence of cirrhosis and cardiovascular diseases. Which of the following can be considered the first line of treatment for this lady?

NASH: Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis
questions.solution:
Vitamin E can be considered the first line of treatment in this patient with nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH).

Vitamin E is well tolerated and has been shown to modestly improve aminotransferase levels, radiographic features of hepatic steatosis, and/or histologic features of NASH. However, vitamin E should only be considered as the first-line pharmacotherapy for non-diabetic, noncirrhotic NASH patients who are at low risk for cardiovascular disease or prostate cancer. 

Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is associated with diabetes and obesity. The fatty change may also be the effect of toxins (including certain medications), protein malnutrition, dyslipidemia, and anoxia. Bleomycin, methotrexate, doxycycline, and l-asparaginase are other drugs causing hepatic steatosis.

NASH is characterized by hepatic steatosis, which is complicated by histologically evident hepatocyte death and inflammation.

Most patients with NAFLD and NASH are asymptomatic. They are usually diagnosed incidentally on routine blood work.

Some patients with NASH may present with right upper quadrant pain owing to the stretching of the liver capsule as a result of hepatomegaly or acanthosis nigricans due to insulin resistance; some may present with signs like palmar erythema, spider telangiectasia, jaundice, splenomegaly, and ascites if they have liver cirrhosis.

Currently, biopsy is the gold standard investigation to establish the diagnosis.

The current approach to NAFLD management focuses on treatment to avoid or decrease the risk factors for NASH like obesity, insulin resistance, metabolic syndrome, and dyslipidemia.

Thiazolidinediones help in improving adipocyte insulin sensitivity and preventing inappropriate lipolysis but have side effects like weight gain and osteoporosis. For patients with morbid obesity, bariatric surgery can be done. In patients with decompensated cirrhosis, liver transplantation is can be considered. 

Note: The FDA in 2024 has approved Resmetirom, a thyroid hormone receptor-beta (THR-beta) agonist for noncirrhotic NASH with moderate to advanced fibrosis.

questions.text: A patient underwent an imaging study; the findings are shown in the image given below. Which of the following compounds is used for this investigation?
questions.solution:
The image shows a positron-emission tomography (PET) scan. PET involves the use of a radiolabeled bio-compound such as 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is injected intravenously. This compound is taken up and broken down in the cells.

It is based on the principle that tumor cells have a high metabolic rate and can metabolize FDG. However, tumor cells can metabolize FDG only to FDG-6-phosphate, and no further. Hence, it accumulates in tumor cells and can be detected and quantified.

Applications of PET:

  • Oncologic:
    • Detection, staging, drug response
    • Differentiation between radiation necrosis and recurrence
  • Neurologic:
    • Early diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease
    • Localization of seizure focus in the interictal phase
    • Localizing eloquent areas (e.g. speech, motor function)
  • Cardiac:
    • Identification of hibernating myocardium

questions.text: Choose the incorrectly matched pair among the following substances of abuse with their respective feature of chronic use.
questions.solution:
Image 3 is a picture of heroin, which is incorrectly matched with amotivational syndrome that is a feature of chronic use of cannabis.

Heroin (an opioid) :

  • It is known as morphinism/morphinomania
  • Addicts have dry skin and show abscesses or scars of healed abscesses. Sometimes tattooing from needles may be seen.
  • Larger doses lead to disinterest and recurring periods of depression.
  • The patient becomes restless and irritable and sleep is disturbed by dreams or there is insomnia.
  • Loss of memory, mental fatigue, and gradual intellectual and moral deterioration occur.
  • Hallucinations may occur.
  • Constipation, contracted pupils, anorexia, emaciation, and weakness and impotence are frequent.
  • Sudden cessation of opioid use in dependent pregnant women may be life-threatening to the foetus.

Image 1 :

Cannabis - Running amok: Heavy marijuana users may develop manic or paranoid psychosis. The person may run amok, i.e., he develops a psychic disturbance marked by a period of depression, followed by violent attempts to kill people (impulse to murder)

  • When used in excess, it causes degeneration of the central nervous system and insanity.
  • Chronic use reduces serum testosterone and sperm count and is associated with gynecomastia.
  • There is loss of appetite, weakness, wasting, tremors, sleepy facial expression, vacant look, red eyes, impotence, and moral and mental deterioration.
  • Rarely do users become insane (hashish insanity), and may suffer from auditory and visual hallucinations and delusions of persecution.
  • Chronic use may lead to amotivational syndrome with loss of age-appropriate behavior, like lethargy, and lack of interest in day-to-day activities at home and school.
  • Marijuana is a potential carcinogen.

Image 2 :

LSD - Flashback phenomenon: This may occur days, weeks or even months after the ingestion of a dose, and the person experiences a recurrence of the emotional and psychological aspects of the previous 'LSD' trip. These delayed recurring symptoms may lead to eccentric behavior, suicide, or even homicide. Repeated use by an addict can lead to permanent psychosis.

 Image 4 :

Cocaine - Magnan's symptom: Magnan's symptom or cocaine bugs is characteristic, in which there is a feeling as if grains of sand are lying under the skin or some small insects are creeping on the skin. It gives rise to itching sensation (formication, tactile hallucination) with resultant excoriation, leading to irregular scratches and ulcers.

  • Chronic use is also known as cocainism, cocainophagia or cocainomania.
  • It causes :
    • Digestive disturbances
    • Anorexia
    • Salivation
    • Tachycardia
    • Tachyapnoea
    • Insomnia.
  • Tongue and teeth turn black.
  • A manic, paranoid, or depressive psychosis may develop (cocaine psychosis or excited delirium)
  • Complications :
    • Persistent rhinitis
    • Nasal erosions
    • Sinusitis
    • Chronic cough
    • Bronchitis
    • Sniffing habit leads to ulceration of the nasal septum
    • Degeneration of the central nervous system occurs, and the patient may suffer from hallucinations, convulsions, delirium, and insanity.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old male patient presented with a painless, hard testicular lump with a dragging sensation. The blood investigations showed raised AFP levels. Which of the following is least likely to be included in further management of this case?

AFP- Alpha Fetoprotein

choices.text: CT of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
The given clinical features of painless testicular swelling with raised AFP levels point towards the diagnosis of non-seminomatous germ cell tumor (NSGCT) of the testis. Orchidectomy via inguinal approach is done in this case rather than a scrotal approach due to fear of seeding the tumor in the scrotal skin. Hence, it is least likely to be the management of this case.

Management of testicular tumors:

  1. Ultrasound of the testis should be done in all suspected cases of testicular tumor.
  2. Tumor markers (AFP, hCG, LDH) are measured for the staging of cancer.
  3. CT - chest, abdomen, and pelvis is done to detect metastasis.
  4. Orchidectomy via an inguinal incision (high inguinal orchidectomy) is the best line of treatment in case of suspected testicular tumor.
  5. Further management is based on staging. The older staging is preferred over the TNM staging for treatment and is given below:
    • Stage I: Tumour is confined to testis and epididymis
    • Stage II: Nodal tissue is present but is confined to nodes below the diaphragm
    • Stage III: Nodal involvement above the diaphragm
    • Stage IV: Non-lymphatic metastatic spread (mostly in lungs)
  6. Stage I tumors:
    • Combination chemotherapy with bleomycin, etoposide, and cis-platinum (BEP chemotherapy) is given for NSGCTs, as they are radio-resistant.
    • Chemotherapy with cisplatinum and radiotherapy to para-aortic lymph nodes can be given in seminomas as they are radiosensitive.
  7. Stage II-IV tumors (seminomas and NSGCTs) are treated with BEP chemotherapy and retroperitoneal lymph node dissection if needed.

Note:

In case of suspected testicular tumors,

  • No scrotal approach.
  • No FNAC.
  • No incisional biopsy.

Related Pearl: Seminomatous germ-cell tumors (GCTs) vs Non-seminomatous GCT

Features Seminoma Non- seminomatous GCT
Age 2nd or 3rd decade (Never seen in prepubertal children) Occur at any age
Presentation Localized to the testis for a long time Aggressive tumors; present at an advanced clinical stage
Spread Lymphatic Hematogenous
Macroscopy Homogenous Variegated
Cell type Composed of primordial germ cells Composed of undifferentiated cells
Tumor marker Placental alkaline phosphatase AFP, HCG
Radio-therapy Radiosensitive Radioresistant
Prognosis Better Poor

AFP: Alpha-fetoprotein 

HCG: Human Chorionic Gonadotropin

Related Pearl: TNM staging of testicular tumour: American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) and Union Internationale Contre le Cancer (UICC)

Primary tumor (T)

The extent of the primary tumor is usually classified after radical orchiectomy (except for pTis and pT4) and, for this reason, a pathologic (p) stage is assigned.

pTx - Primary tumor cannot be assessed

pT0 - No evidence of primary tumor (e.g., a histologic scar in testis)

pTis -  Germ-cell neoplasia in situ

pT1 - Tumor limited to the testis and epididymis without vascular/lymphatic invasion; tumor may invade into tunica albuginea but not tunica vaginalis

pT2 - Tumor limited to testis and epididymis with vascular/lymphatic invasion or tumor extending through the tunica albuginea, with the involvement of tunica vaginalis

pT3 - Tumor invades spermatic cord with or without vascular/lymphatic invasion

pT4 - Tumor invades the scrotum with or without vascular/lymphatic invasion

Regional lymph nodes (N)

NX - Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed

N0 - No regional lymph node metastasis

N1 - Metastasis with lymph node mass ≤2 cm in greatest dimension; or multiple lymph nodes, none more than 2 cm in greatest dimension

N2 - Metastasis with lymph node mass, 2–5 cm in greatest dimension; or multiple lymph nodes, anyone mass >2 cm but not more than 5 cm in greatest dimension

N3 - Metastasis with lymph node mass >5 cm in greatest dimension

Distant metastasis (M)

MX - Distant metastasis cannot be assessed

M0 - No distant metastasis

M1 - Distant metastasis

M1a - Nonregional nodal or pulmonary metastasis

M1b - Distant metastasis at site other than nonregional lymph nodes or lung

Serum tumor markers (S)

SX - Marker studies unavailable or not performed

S0 - Marker study levels within normal limits

  S1 S2 S3
LDH <1.5 × N 1.5–10 × N  >10×N
hCG(MIU/mL) <5000 5000–50,000  >50,000 
AFP(ng/mL) <1000 1000–10,000  >10,000

N indicates the upper limit of normal for the LDH assay

Related Pearl: Tumor Markers in Testicular Germ Cell Tumors

 

AFP

b-hCG

+++

Choriocarcinoma
