 Note:

 Alpha-fetoprotein AFP: Raised in

  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Yolk sac tumor
  • Teratocarcinoma
  • Mixed germ cell tumor

AFP is never raised in pure seminomas or pure choriocarcinoma

Human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG): Only the β subunit is measured by the most commonly available serum assays. Can be raised in

  • Choriocarcinoma
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Teratocarcinoma
  • Seminoma (only in about 15% Seminomas)
  • Mixed germ-cell tumors

 Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH):

  • LDH has limited sensitivity and specificity for seminoma, but LDH levels >2000 U/L are more consistent with bulky disease, and rising levels are an accurate indicator of recurrence.
  •  In non-seminomatous germ-cell tumors (NSCGT), LDH is directly related to tumor burden.

questions.text: A man presents with pain and swelling in the forearm. On examination, there is a restriction of rotational movements of the arm. He gives a history of trying to avoid a lathi-charge by police with his forearm. Which of the following fractures is he most likely to have sustained?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of nightstick fracture/isolated ulna fracture.

Nightstick fracture occurs due to a direct blow on the ulna along its subcutaneous border.

Other options:

Option A: Greenstick fractures are partial-thickness fractures. They mostly occur in the pediatric population. Here, the cortex and periosteum are interrupted only on one side but are intact on the other side.

Option C: Galeazzi fracture is a fracture of the lower third of the radius with dislocation or subluxation of the distal radioulnar joint.

Option D: Monteggia fracture is a fracture of the upper third of the ulna with dislocation of the head of the radius.

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.

questions.text: An old homeless wanderer who had chronic pruritus and hyperpigmentation of the skin was diagnosed with vagabond's disease. Which of the following organisms causes this condition?
questions.solution:
Vagabond’s disease or pediculosis corporis is caused by the body louse.

In people with chronic pediculosis corporis infestation with clothing body louse, the skin is often hyperpigmented and this post-inflammatory phenomenon is called Vagabonds’ disease or Morbus errorum. It is a disease of poor, homeless, and wandering people (vagabonds), hence, the name Vagabond’s disease. Itching is due to the reaction to salivary antigens of the louse bites.

The image shows scraping lesions on the upper back and numerous lice in the seams of clothing which are suggestive of pediculosis corporis.

Body lice are vectors of important diseases like relapsing fever (Borrelia recurrentis), trench fever (Bartonella quintana), and epidemic typhus (Rickettsia prowazekii). The following image shows the body louse.

Management is done by systematic decontamination of the bed linens and clothing. Although this is usually enough in most cases, thorough washing of the body with soap followed by application of pyrethrins/pyrethroids or malathion for 8–24 h can also be recommended.

Other options:

Option B: Head louse causes pediculosis capitis. It is associated with intense itching and nits on the scalp and posterior cervical lymphadenopathy.

Option C: Crab louse or pubic louse causes pediculosis pubis. Itching is usually increased in the evening and night. Lice are seen grasping hairs close to the skin surface, and the eggs are seen to be attached to the hair shafts.

Option D: Itch mite causes scabies. The typical lesions of scabies are pruritic papules, excoriations, and burrows. Itching is worse at night and lesions are typically seen in the finger webs, wrists, axillae, and elbow flexures.

Related Pearl: Lice

  • There are 3 kinds of lice. They are:
    • Head lice (Pediculus capitis)
    • Body lice (Pediculus corporis)
    • Crab louse (pubic louse – Phthirus pubis).
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a pair of antennae, three pairs of legs attached to the thorax, and a segmented abdomen.
  • The stages in their life cycle are eggs (nits), larva (nymph), and the adult, which live for 30 to 50 days.
  • They are spread by direct or indirect contact.
  • They are vectors for epidemic typhus, relapsing fever, trench fever, and pediculosis.
  • Insecticidal control of lice is mainly by malathion in the form of lotion or powder.
  • There are reports of resistance to DDT and HCH.
  • Personal hygiene is of utmost importance to prevent infestation.

questions.text:
Match the RNA polymerases with the products synthesized by them.
RNA polymerases RNA synthesized
1. RNAP1 a. tRNA
2. RNAP2 b. rRNA
3. RNAP3 c. mRNA
questions.solution:
The correct match of RNA polymerases with their products is 1-b, 2-c, 3-a.

RNA polymerases

Major Products

RNA polymerase I

rRNA

RNA polymerase II

mRNA, miRNA, snRNA, lncRNA

RNA polymerase III

tRNA, 5srRNA


rRNAs (ribosomal RNA) are involved in protein synthesis. They facilitate the interaction of mRNA, tRNA, and amino acids with each other for the translation process. 

mRNA (messenger RNA) is a protein-coding RNA that is directly involved in protein synthesis.

miRNA (micro RNA) is derived from large primary transcripts through specific nucleolytic processing. It modulates gene expression by altering mRNA function. They bind to matching pieces of mRNA, turn it into a double strand and arrest the translation. 

tRNA (transfer RNA) helps to transport amino acids from the cell cytoplasm to the ribosome where protein synthesis occurs. Since they are soluble in nature, they are also known as soluble RNA (sRNA).

Related Pearl: RNA polymerase in Humans and Their Major Products

Types

Major Products

RNA polymerase I

rRNA

RNA polymerase II

mRNA, miRNA, snRNA, lncRNA

RNA polymerase III

tRNA, 5srRNA

Related Pearl: Types of RNA

Protein coding RNA

Non Protein coding RNA

mRNA

Ribosomal RNAs (rRNA)

Long noncoding RNAs (lncRNAs)

Transfer RNAs (tRNA)

Small nuclear RNAs (snRNAs)

Micro and silencing RNAs (miRNAs and siRNAs)

questions.text: A middle-aged man with a history of smoking for 20 years decides to quit this habit. However, he develops symptoms of tobacco withdrawal. Which of the following symptoms is unlikely to be seen in him?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient has symptoms of tobacco withdrawal. So, tachycardia is unlikely to be seen in him. Patients with tobacco withdrawal usually have a decreased heart rate. 

Symptoms of tobacco withdrawal include:  

  • Intense craving for tobacco
  • Irritability and difficulty concentrating
  • Decreased heart rate, and blood pressure
  • Drowsiness or altered sleep
  • Decreased motor performance, and increased muscle tension. 

Tobacco use disorder is among the most prevalent substance use disorder. The majority of tobacco is smoked as cigarettes. Around 0.5 mg of nicotine is delivered by smoking one cigarette. Other forms of use include cigars, snuff, chewing tobacco, and pipes.

The psychoactive component of tobacco is nicotine. It acts on the nicotinic subtype of acetylcholine receptors. Its addictive properties are thought to be due to the activation of the dopaminergic pathway in the ventral tegmental area.

The major cause of addiction is due to its effects. It causes improved attention, and problem-solving ability decreases tension and lifts the mood of the users.

Adverse effects of nicotine intoxication: 

  • Doses of 60 mg are toxic to the person and can cause respiratory paralysis. 
  • Nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, diarrhea
  • Salivation
  • Increased blood pressure, tachycardia, and tremors. 

Treatment of nicotine addiction includes: 

  • Behavioral therapy - elimination of the factors that favor smoking in the patient's environment, hypnotic sessions, etc
  • Pharmacotherapy used in the treatment of nicotine addiction is - 
    • Nicotine replacement therapy is used to reduce the symptoms of nicotine withdrawal. It is available in various forms like nicotine gum, lozenges, patches, nasal spray
    • Non-nicotine medications - bupropion, varenicline, clonidine  

Related Pearl: Substances of abuse

Substance
Withdrawal symptoms
Intoxication features
Alcohol
Tremors, delirium, seizures
Blackouts, nystagmus and slurring of speech
BZD
Tremors, insomnia, anxiety
Lethargy and drowsiness.
Opioid/ Heroin
Diarrhea, yawning, mydriasis, lacrimation, piloerection, cold turkey phenomenon
Euphoria, depressed mental status, miosis, respiratory depression, constipation.
Nicotine/ Tobacco
Increased appetite
Shows a biphasic pattern. 
Early stimulatory symptoms of vomiting, hypertension and tachycardia. Later depressive symptoms of hypotension and bradycardia.
Cannabis
Irritability, sweating, tremors, decreased appetite
Increased appetite, euphoria, conjunctival injection, dry mouth, panic, synesthesia, impaired time perception, amotivational syndrome, run amok and flashbacks.
Amphetamine
Depressed mood, suicidal thoughts, unpleasant dreams
Acute: Sympathetic overactivity, paranoid hallucinatory syndrome, violent behavior, psychosis and diaphoresis.
Chronic: Runs & crashes, choreiform movements, tooth decay. Can resemble schizophrenia.
Cocaine
Depressed mood, suicidal thoughts
Acute: Sympathetic overactivity, agitation, euphoria, chest pain, seizures and mydriasis
Chronic: Cocaine psychosis (Magnan sign) and black pigmentation of the tongue.
LSD/ Haluccinogen
Nothing significant
Synesthesia, brisk tendon reflex, tachycardia, hypertension, panic, ataxia, visual hallucinations, euphoria and dysphoria.
Phencyclidine (PCP)
Nothing significant 
Tachycardia, hypertension, ataxia, hallucinations, violent behavior, dissociation, amnesia and nystagmus.

questions.text: A class is being conducted on the various structures present in the next. Neck dissection is performed, and the given image shows the lateral aspect of the neck. All of the following muscles are supplied by nerves arising from the structure 'A' and its branches, except _____.
questions.solution:
The structure marked as A in the above image is the inferior root of ansa cervicalis, and it supplies all the above-mentioned muscles, except the thyrohyoid.

The inferior root descends on the lateral side of the internal jugular vein, crosses it a little below the middle of the neck, and continues forwards to join the superior root anterior to the common carotid artery, forming the ansa cervicalis (ansa hypoglossi).

Ansa cervicalis: 

  • It is a loop of nerves that are a part of the cervical plexus. It is made up of two roots. The upper root has contributions from the first cervical spinal nerve, and the lower root has contributions from the second and third cervical spinal nerves.
  • It innervates sternohyoid, sternothyroid, and omohyoid muscles.

The thyrohyoid and geniohyoid are not supplied by ansa cervicalis. They are supplied by the first cervical spinal nerve, via the hypoglossal nerve.

questions.text: A young male patient presented with a high fever, muscle aches, and easy fatigability. He gives a history of diarrhea and abdominal pain about 20 days ago. His blood investigations revealed eosinophilia. His muscle biopsy findings are given in the image below. What is the most likely organism responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the muscle biopsy findings showing encysted spiral larvae are characteristic of Trichinella spiralis.

Trichinella spiralis is known as the pork worm since the infection is acquired by consuming raw or undercooked pork. The initial infection presents as diarrhea and abdominal pain. In the later phase of the infection, the larvae move from the intestines into the circulation and migrate into muscles where they are encysted. This causes symptoms like fever, myalgia, etc.

The larvae more commonly infect active muscles like the diaphragm, tongue, intercostals, extraocular muscles, etc. These larvae are calcified in about 5-6 months. Eosinophilia caused by parasitic infection also comes down after 6 months.

It can be treated using albendazole along with steroids to control inflammation.

Related Pearl: Infective form and diagnostic forms - Worms

Hint: The infective and diagnostic forms are usually the same in the parasites causing autoinfection.

Related Pearl: Skin tests for the diagnosis of parasitic infections

Skin tests are performed by injecting parasitic antigen intradermally and observing the reaction. In immediate hypersensitivity reaction, wheal and flare response is seen within 30 minutes of injection, whereas in delayed type of hypersensitivity, erythema and induration are seen after 48 hours of injection.

The table below shows some of the important skin tests used in the diagnosis of parasitic infections.

questions.text: On applying firm sliding pressure on unblistered skin in a bullous eruption, the epidermis gets separated from the dermis in some conditions, as shown in the image given below. In which of the following conditions is this sign not seen?
questions.solution:
The sign shown in the image, which is elicited by applying firm tangential sliding pressure with a finger on lesional or perilesional skin is called Nikolsky's sign. This sign is not elicited in epidermolysis bullosa simplex.

In Nikolsky's sign, a tangential/lateral pressure applied on the affected, perilesional or normal skin around the blister, results in separation between the upper and lower layers of the epidermis, producing an erosion. It is positive when there is extension of the blister with or without removal of epidermis in the tested area. This is because the underlying pathology is common to the affected as well as the normal skin.


Nikolsky's sign is found to be positive in the following conditions:

  • Pemphigus vulgaris
  • Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome(SSSS)
  • Pemphigus foliaceus
  • Bullous eruptions in chikungunya infection
  • Severe cases of acute graft vs host disease

Nikolsky sign is negative in bullous pemphigoid and generalized epidermolysis bullosa simplex.

Nikolsky's sign can be wet or dry depending on the underlying type of skin that is seen after elicited after applying the pressure. Active pemphigus vulgaris will elicit a wet sign while a dry sign is seen with pemphigus foliaceus or in reepithelialisation beneath a pemphigus vulgaris blister.

Marginal Nikolsky’s sign occurs when there is an extension of erosion onto the normal skin, surrounding the lesion. This is elicited by rubbing the skin surrounding the existing lesions.

Direct Nikolsky’s sign is elicited by the induction of erosions on the normal skin that are far from the lesions.

Microscopic Nikolsky’s sign may be a better and sensitive method for rapid diagnosis of epidermal acantholysis. It refers to the classical microscopic changes for pemphigus vulgaris or pemphigus foliaceus in the epidermis, that can be confirmed by a skin biopsy.

Note:

False Nikolsky’s sign/Sheklakov’s sign is positive in sub-epidermal blistering disorders like:

  • Bullous pemphigoid
  • Cicatricial pemphigoid
  • Dermatitis herpetiformis
  • Epidermolysis bullosa
  • Bullous systemic lupus eythematosis

It is seen after pulling the peripheral remnant roof of a ruptured blister, thereby extending the erosions onto the surrounding normal skin, which are limited in size, do not extend spontaneously and heal rapidly.

Pseudo-Nikolsky sign/epidermal peeling sign occurs where epidermal separation is due to the necrosis of epidermal cells, instead of acantholysis, which is seen in the true Nikolsky's sign. A pseudo-Nikolsky sign can be elicited only in affected areas of the skin. This sign is positive in:

  • Stevens-Johnson Syndrome
  • Toxic epidermal necrolysis
  • Bullous ichthyosiform erythroderma
  • Some burn cases

Nikolsky's phenomenon is elicited on palpation by feeling the movement of the detached epidermis over the dermis. This results in the formation of blisters after some time instead of an immediate reaction to form Nikolsky's sign.

Related Pearl: Classification of Vesiculobullous Disorders

questions.text: A G3A2 pregnant woman with a history of two previous second-trimester abortions presents at 13 weeks of gestation. USG shows funneling of the cervix, with the length of the cervix being 20 mm. The following procedure is performed. Identify the procedure.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cervical incompetence, and McDonald's cerclage is the procedure shown in the image.

In McDonald's stitch, the nonabsorbable suture material is placed as a purse-string suture as high as possible (level of internal os), at the junction of the rugose vaginal epithelium and the smooth vaginal part of the cervix below the level of the bladder. The stitch should be removed at the 37th week or earlier if labor pain starts or features of abortion appear.

In cervical incompetence, the retentive power of the cervix (internal os) may be impaired functionally and/or anatomically. Repeated mid-trimester painless cervical dilatation (without apparent cause) and escape of liquor amnii, followed by painless expulsion of the products of conception are highly suggestive of cervical incompetence.

Diagnosis in pregnancy

  • Clinical examination (speculum): Painless cervical shortening and dilatation
  • Sonography: Short cervix with length <25 mm; funneling of the internal os with width >1 cm
  • Speculum examination: Detection of dilatation of internal os with herniation of the membranes

Prophylactic cerclage is done around 14 weeks of pregnancy or 2 weeks earlier than the previous fetal loss. Rescue or emergency cerclage is done anytime within 24 weeks of gestation. It should only be done when there is a bulging of membranes through the dilated cervix. 

Commonly used types of procedures for cervical cerclage during pregnancy:

  • McDonald's procedure - Non-absorbable (mersilene) material is placed as a purse-string suture at the level of the internal os.

 

  • Modified Shirodkar's procedure - Non-absorbable (mersilene) tape is passed subcutaneously through a transverse anterior incision and tied posteriorly.

 

Fothergill operation (also known Manchester operation) - Anterior colporrhaphy with the amputation of the cervix is done. 

Abdominal wall cervicopexy (modified by Purandare and Mathre) - A sling is attached to the cervix posteriorly, near uterosacral ligaments. Both these surgeries are done to manage genital prolapse.

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely to result as a complication of CKD?
questions.solution:
Chronic kidney disease is typically associated with anemia due to associated low erythropoietin levels, not polycythemia.

Complications of declining kidney function include:

  • Volume overload
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Metabolic acidosis
  • Hyperphosphatemia
  • Mineral and bone disorders
  • Hypertension
  • Anemia
  • Dyslipidemia

CKD is a spectrum of pathophysiological processes resulting in abnormal kidney function, with a progressive decline in glomerular filtration rate (GFR). According to the Kidney Disease Improving Global Outcome (KDIGO) classification, CKD can be stratified using both GFR and albuminuria to predict the risk of progression of CKD:

Stages of CKD based on GFR (mL/min/1.73 m2):

Stage GFR  Description
G1 ≥90 Normal or high
G2 60-89 Mildly decreased
G3a 45-59

Mildly to moderately decreased
G3b 30-44 Moderately to severely decreased
G4 15-29 Severely decreased
G5 <15 Kidney failure

Stages of CKD based on albuminuria (mg/g):

Stage Albuminuria Description
A1 <30 Normal to mildly increased
A2 30-300 Moderately increased
A3 >300 Severely increased

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with cardiac arrhythmia was prescribed a drug that acts on potassium channels. All of the following drugs have an effect on potassium channels, except ____.
questions.solution:
All of the given options have an effect on potassium channels, except propranolol. 

Propranolol exerts its antiarrhythmic action through its β-receptor-blocking action. It is a class II antiarrhythmic. 

Other options:

Option A: Quinidine is a class IA anti-arrhythmic agent. It slows conduction and prolongs the QRS duration by blocking sodium channels; it also prolongs action potential by blocking the potassium channels.

Option B: Amiodarone is a class III anti-arrhythmic agent. It prolongs the action potential by blocking potassium channels. It also enhances inward current via sodium channels. 

Option C: Vernakalant is a multi-ion channel blocker. It blocks the early-activating potassium channels, among other channels.

questions.text: The histopathological section of the cardiac tissue of an 82-year-old man shows some pigmentation, as seen below. Intracellular accumulation of which of the following is likely to be seen in this case?
questions.solution:
Intracellular accumulation of lipochrome (brown lipid) is seen in this patient. Lipochrome is also known as the wear-and-tear pigment or lipofuscin; it is an insoluble, brownish-yellow, granular intracellular material, which accumulates in various tissues like the heart, liver, and brain. It is seen in normal aging patients.

Accumulation of the brown pigment in large amounts can give a characteristic appearance to the tissue called brown atrophy.  

Lipofuscin (brown lipid):

  • Derived through lipid peroxidation of polyunsaturated lipids of subcellular membranes
  • Not injurious to the cell or its functions
  • Indicates free radical injury and lipid peroxidation
  • Seen in cells undergoing slow, regressive changes
  • Prominent in the liver, brain, and heart of aging patients, patients with severe malnutrition, and cancer cachexia

Other options:

Option A: Dutcher bodies are pale-staining intranuclear inclusions within plasma cells seen in multiple myeloma.


Option C: Mallory bodies are seen in Indian childhood cirrhosis and Wilson’s disease.


Option D: Cholesterol deposits are seen in atherosclerosis and xanthomas.

questions.text: Which of the following pregnant women with plasmodium falciparum malaria will receive artemether-lumefantrine combination therapy?

choices.text: A 4-month pregnant lady from Madhya Pradesh

questions.solution:
A 6-month pregnant lady from Assam with Plasmodium Falciparum malaria will receive artemether-lumefantrine combination therapy.

Artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT) consists of an artemisinin derivative and a long-acting antimalarial such as sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine, lumefantrine, or mefloquine. It is given for P. falciparum malaria in the 2nd and 3rd trimesters of pregnancy. ACT is preferably avoided in the first trimester, and quinine is the preferred drug in the 1st trimester.

Artemether-lumefantrine is used for the treatment of falciparum malaria in the northeastern states of India. Artesunate- Sulfadoxine-Pyrimethamine (ACT-SP) is given for the treatment of falciparum malaria in the other states.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presented with complaints of bleeding from the gums while brushing his teeth and purplish rashes on his legs for the past 10 days. On examination, you notice several pinpoint petechiae over both of his shins. His spleen and liver are palpable. Blood work reveals anemia and thrombocytopenia, and a peripheral smear showed macrophages with a crumpled-paper appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and the macrophage showing a crumpled paper appearance (Gaucher cells) strongly point towards the diagnosis of Gaucher's disease.

It is a lysosomal storage disorder caused due to the deficiency of Β-glucosidase (beta glucocerebrosidase) enzyme leading to the accumulation of glucosylceramide in the cells. It is an autosomal recessive disorder. 

There are three types of Gaucher's disease—type 1, type 2, and type 3. 

Clinically, patients present with:

  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Skeletal involvement due to ischemia, necrosis, and osteopenia may range from bone pain and bone crisis to compression fractures and avascular necrosis.
  • Hematological findings - Anemia and cytopenias are seen due to infiltration of the bone marrow by the lipid-laden macrophages called Gaucher cells.
  • Neurological manifestations are typically seen in types 2 and 3, including cognitive decline, myoclonic seizures, and eye movement disorders. 

Other options-

Option A - Tay-Sachs disease is caused due to hexosaminidase A deficiency leading to the accumulation of Glucocerebroside. Clinical symptoms include mental retardation, blindness, and muscular weakness.

Option C - Fabry disease is caused due to alpha-galactosidase deficiency leading to the accumulation of Glucocerebroside. It is an X-linked recessive disorder, hence full symptoms are only seen in males. They usually present as skin rashes and kidney failure.

Option D - Niemann-Pick disease is caused due to sphingomyelinase deficiency leading to the accumulation of sphingomyelin. Clinical features include mental retardation and hepatosplenomegaly.

questions.text: You join a dedicated COVID health center where pediatric cases are prioritized and monitored on the basis of the patient's body temperature. A compilation of the temperature readings (in Celsius) of all the patients arranged in a meaningful order represents data in which of the following scales of measurement?
questions.solution:
The temperature readings (in celsius) of the patients represent interval scale data.

Similar to ordinal data, interval scale data can be placed in a meaningful order, but in addition, the items have meaningful intervals between them, which are usually measured quantities. In the given scenario, the temperatures of the patients can be arranged from high to low and the difference between the temperatures of each patient is quantifiable in measured quantities. This scale of measurement does not have an absolute zero; hence, the ratios of the scores are not meaningful.

All data can be measured in one of four scales—nominal, ordinal, interval, or ratio scale (mnemonic: NOIR).

Related Pearl: Scales of data measurement

Data can be quantitative (numerical values) or qualitative (types, labels).

Quantitative data can be discrete variables or continuous variables.

 

Description

Example

Discrete data

Can take certain values and none in between

Number of cancer patients in a hospital. 

Continuous data

Can take any value usually in between limits or a range. 

Most biomedical data is continuous.

Height, weight, blood pressure, etc.

 

Data always forms one of four scales of measurement – nominal, ordinal, interval, or ratio scales (mnemonic: NOIR):

 

Nominal Scale Data

Ordinal Scale Data

Interval Scale Data

Ratio Scale Data

Example

Male/female; red/green; sub-urban/rural

Students ranked 1st/2nd/3rd in their class. 

A customer feedback survey using terms like very good, good, poor and very poor or the Likert Scale.

Severity of a disease as mild, moderate, severe

 

 Measurements on the celsius scale. Pulse rate; 

Notes

Have no quantitative value.

They have no order or ratio. 

Arranged in a meaningful order.

No size interval is defined

Arranged in a meaningful order with a well defined size interval.

Example: Temperature in Celsius. If temperature in A is 40 deg Celsius and that in B is 20 deg Celsius, then A is 20 deg Celsius hotter than B (taking difference)

Does not have an absolute zero.

For example, Celsius scale has no such thing as “no temperature”. So the value cannot be zero.

Arranged in a meaningful order with a well defined size interval.

Eg: A pulse rate has well defined intervals and is meaningful in comparison. A 100/min pulse is exactly twice of 50 beats/min.

 

Has an absolute zero.

Eg: There can be a value of zero for pulse.

Type

Qualitative

Qualitative

Quantitative

Quantitative

questions.text: All of the following statements belong to the 10 steps of successful breastfeeding recommended by the Baby Friendly Hospital Initiative (BHFI), except _____.

choices.text: Help mothers initiate breastfeeding within 4 hours of birth
Practice rooming in 24 hours a day

questions.solution:
BHFI recommends breastfeeding as soon as possible after birth.

BFHI is sponsored by the WHO and the United Nations Children’s Fund to promote breastfeeding.

Related Pearl: Baby-friendly hospital initiative (revised 2018)

Ten steps to successful breastfeeding (Revised 2018)

Critical management procedures

1  a. Comply fully with the International Code of Marketing of Breast-milk Substitutes and relevant World Health Assembly resolutions.

    b. Have a written infant feeding policy that is routinely communicated to staff and parents.

    c. Establish ongoing monitoring and data-management systems.

2. Ensure that staff has sufficient knowledge, competence, and skills to support breastfeeding.

Key clinical practices

3. Discuss the importance and management of breastfeeding with pregnant women and their families.

4. Facilitate immediate and uninterrupted skin-to-skin contact and support mothers to initiate breastfeeding as soon as possible after birth.

5. Support mothers to initiate and maintain breastfeeding and manage common difficulties.

6. Do not provide breastfed newborns any food or fluids other than breast milk, unless medically indicated.

7. Enable mothers and their infants to remain together and to practice rooming-in 24 hours a day.

8. Support mothers to recognize and respond to their infants’ cues for feeding.

9. Counsel mothers on the use and risks of feeding bottles, teats, and pacifiers.

10. Coordinate discharge so that parents and their infants have timely access to ongoing support and care.

questions.text: A clinical trial is in its third phase, which aims to research and provide a new drug to the market for combating hypertension. This phase includes a randomized control trial (RCT). Why is the Intention-to-treat analysis done in RCT?

choices.text: To include the dropouts of the trial
When the sample size is large

questions.solution:
Intention-to-treat (ITT) analysis is done to include the dropouts of the trial. Exclusion of the dropouts or non-compliant participants from the trial may introduce bias.

It ignores non-compliance, protocol change, withdrawal, cross-over, and any changes that occur after randomization, during the analysis.

questions.text: Study of which of the following is known as emporiatrics?
questions.solution:
Emporiatrics is the study of the health of travelers.

It is also called travel medicine. It deals with the prevention and management of health problems of international travelers.

questions.text: You are attending a quiz competition, and the quiz master asks you to enlist the components of Saint's triad. Which of the following will not form a part of your answer?
questions.solution:
Renal stones are not a component of Saint’s triad.

Components of Saint's triad:

  • Gallstones
  • Hiatus hernia
  • Diverticulosis coli

There is no underlying pathophysiology that explains the simultaneous presence of these three conditions.

questions.text: As an intern in the department of community medicine, you are tasked with calculating Chandler's index for a rural community near your medical college. This index is used to calculate the load of which parasite in the community?
questions.solution:
Chandler's index is used to identify the importance of hookworm infestation as a public health problem in a community. It is calculated based on the average number of hookworm eggs/gram of stool:

  • <200: no significance
  • 200-250: the potential danger
  • 250-300: minor public health problem
  • >300: major public health problem

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

Related Pearl: Recommendations - WHO Guidelines for preventive chemotherapy to control soil-transmitted helminth infections in at-risk population groups

WHO has recently in September 2017 has proposed guidelines for preventive chemotherapy (deworming) to control soil-transmitted helminth infections in at-risk population groups.

The main soil-transmitted helminths includes the roundworm (Ascaris lumbricoides), the whipworm (Trichuris trichiura) and the hookworms (Ancylostoma duodenale and Necator americanus).

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presents to the emergency department with complaints of palpitations and breathlessness. He has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. His ECG is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical feature and the ECG are pointing towards the diagnosis of multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT).

Identifying features in ECG:

  • Heart rate >100 bpm
  • Irregular rhythm
  • Discrete P waves with >3 different morphologies (black arrows)
  • Variable PR interval
  • Narrow QRS complex

MAT is characterised by at least three distinct P-wave morphologies with rates typically between 100 and 150 beats/min.

It is the most common arrhythmia seen in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). It is also seen in hypoxia and pulmonary hypertension.

Other options:

Option A: Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia has a rate of 150-200 bpm. It also has a regular rhythm. P wave may be buried in the QRS complex. PR interval may not be possible to measure. Narrow QRS complex. It can occur in a normal heart. The drug of choice for PSVT is adenosine.

Option B: Atrial fibrillation has an irregularly irregular rhythm. The rate is >300 bpm. The 'P' wave is absent, these irregular waves are known as fibrillation waves, which are characteristic of atrial fibrillation.

Option C: Atrial flutter has a regular rhythm. The rate is 250-300 bpm. Normal P waves are replaced by saw-tooth-shaped waves known as flutter waves.

questions.text: A young woman with atrial fibrillation is started on unfractionated heparin. After 6 days, she complains of reddening, swelling, and severe pain in her lower limbs. Her platelet count is 90,000/μL. Laboratory investigations reveal the presence of antibodies against heparin-platelet factor 4 complexes. Which of the following is the next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Discontinue unfractionated heparin and start warfarin
Discontinue unfractionated heparin and start lepirudin
Reduce the dose of unfractionated heparin and start with low molecular weight heparin

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of deep vein thrombosis due to heparin-induced thrombocytopenia. The next step in the management of this patient is to discontinue unfractionated heparin and start lepirudin.

Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) results due to the formation of antibodies against heparin-platelet 4 complexes. These antibodies also bind to the platelet Fc receptors and promote thrombosis. Features of HIT are usually seen after 5-10 days of starting heparin and are more common in females than in males. The platelet count usually drops to less than ≤100,000/μL or decreases to ≥50% compared to the levels before the initiation of heparin. The patients can also show the features of deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, acute myocardial infarction due to extensive formation of thrombi.

Stop heparin immediately and start with parenteral direct thrombin inhibitors, such as lepirudin, argatroban, or bivalirudin, or factor Xa inhibitors, such as fondaparinux or rivaroxaban. Do not give platelet transfusions. Warfarin is not given until the platelet count returns to its baseline level. Patients with HIT already have low levels of protein C. Giving warfarin to these patients without thrombin inhibitors further decreases its levels and causes skin necrosis. Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) should also not be used to treat HIT patients because most HIT antibodies exhibit cross-reactivity with LMWH.

Heparin acts by activating antithrombin. The antithrombin inhibits thrombin and factor Xa. It can be given subcutaneously or by continuous intravenous infusion. Heparin therapy requires monitoring and can be monitored using the activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) or anti-factor Xa level.

Important side effects of heparin are:

  • Bleeding- is the most common side effect. Recent surgery, trauma, concomitant use of antiplatelet or antifibrinolytic agents increases the risk. Serious bleeding due to heparin is treated using protamine sulfate.
  • Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia
  • Osteoporosis
  • Modest elevations of hepatic transaminases.

Related Pearl: Classification of Anticoagulants

2) Direct thrombin inhibitors (DTI)

Bivalent DTI- Lepirudin, Desirudin, Bivalirudin

4) Indirect factor Xa inhibitors Fondaparinux

questions.text: Blood samples of a patient who died of arsenic poisoning were collected and found to have arsenate compounds in them. These compounds inhibit which of the following glycolytic enzymes?
questions.solution:
Arsenate compounds inhibit the glycolytic enzyme phosphoglycerate kinase. 

Inhibitors of glycolytic enzymes are :

  • Iodoacetate: It inhibits glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase. Thus conversion of glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate to 1,3 bisphosphoglycerate is inhibited.
  • Arsenate: It inhibits phosphoglycerate kinase. It converts  1,3 bisphosphoglycerate to 3 phosphoglycerate. Arsenate competes with inorganic phosphate (Pi) in this reaction to give 1-arseno-3-phosphoglycerate which undergoes spontaneous hydrolysis to 3-phosphoglycerate without forming ATP.
  • Fluoride: It inhibits enolase enzyme which is responsible for the conversion of 2-phosphoglycerate to phosphoenolpyruvate.

Other options:

Option B: Arsenic compounds (arsenite) also inhibit the α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase enzyme. But it is an enzyme of the TCA cycle.

Option C: Enolase is inhibited by fluoride compounds.

Succinate dehydrogenase is inhibited by malonate compounds.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with splenomegaly and pancytopenia.  Suspecting a hematological malignancy, you prepare a peripheral blood smear, which revealed the findings shown in the given image. These cells were also found to be annexin A1 positive. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given peripheral smear shows abnormal B cells with fine hair-like cytoplasmic projections characteristic of hairy cell leukemia.

Hairy cell leukemia:

  • It is associated with BRAF mutations.
  • It mainly occurs in older males.
  • Splenomegaly is the most common physical finding. 
  • It is extremely sensitive to chemotherapeutic agents.
  • Overall prognosis is excellent.
  • Pathology:
    • Hairy cell leukemia is limited to the red pulp of the spleen, which is heavily infiltrated. This leads to the obliteration of white pulp and a beefy red gross appearance.
    • Hairy cells can be identified in the peripheral blood smear.
    • Pancytopenia results from marrow infiltration and splenic sequestration.
    • A "dry tap" is common on aspiration.
    • Detection of annexin A1 in bone marrow specimens has been shown to have 100% sensitivity and specificity in differentiating hairy cell leukemia from other B-cell malignancies.
    • Trephine biopsy: Leukemic cells have a nucleus surrounded by a cytoplasmic halo giving them a fried-egg appearance.
    • CD11c, CD25, and CD103 are the characteristic immunophenotype diagnostic markers.
    • Cells test positive for pan-B-cell markers such as CD19, CD20, and CD22.
    • Cells stain positive for tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP).

The image given below shows small cells with clear cytoplasm and a round central nucleus—fried-egg appearance.

Option A - Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) is a peripheral B-cell neoplasm. The classical immunophenotypic feature of CLL is CD19+, CD20+, CD23+, and CD5+. It also shows BCL2 positivity.

The image shows small round lymphocytes and smudge cells seen in CLL.

Option B: Follicular lymphoma is characterized by t(14;18). Tumor cells are positive for CD19, CD20, CD10, and BCL2 and negative for CD5. Histopathology of the enlarged nodes shows nodular expansion of tumor cells, composed of small cells with cleaved nuclei (centrocytes) and larger cells with more cytoplasm (centroblasts).

The following image shows a lymph node biopsy in follicular lymphoma:

Option C: Chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) is a myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized by t(9;22), a translocation between the BCR and ABL genes that leads to the formation of the Philadelphia chromosome. This results in the activation of tyrosine kinase, which causes abnormal cellular proliferation.

The image below shows peripheral smear findings of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) with neutrophils, myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and band cells.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presented with facial asymmetry. On evaluation, the lesion was found to be at the tympanic segment of the facial nerve. Which of the following tests will give normal findings in this patient?
questions.solution:
In this patient, the tympanic part of the facial nerve is affected; hence, the Schirmer test will be normal. This test is a function of the facial nerve's geniculate part (proximal to the tympanic part) and tests the quantity of lacrimation. 

The Schirmer test is done by hooking a filter paper strip into the lower fornix of each eye to measure and compare the wetness of the strip from both eyes. Decreased lacrimation indicates a lesion proximal to the geniculate ganglion as the secretomotor fibers to the lacrimal gland leave at the geniculate ganglion via the greater superficial petrosal nerve (first branch given at the level of the geniculate ganglion).

Injury proximal to the geniculate ganglion will lead to injury of the greater superficial petrosal nerve, nerve to stapedius, chorda tympani, and muscular branches. There is loss of lacrimal secretion, loss of stapedial reflex, loss of taste in the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, and facial paralysis. 

When the lesion is distal to the geniculate ganglion, there may be an injury to the nerve to the stapedius, leading to loss of stapedial reflex and hyperacusis, which can be detected by tympanometry. Injury to the chorda tympani nerve leads to the loss of taste from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, which is detected by the electrogustometry/taste test, as well as reduced submandibular and sublingual salivary flow, which is detected by the salivary flow test.

The course and branches of the facial nerve can be better understood from the following diagram.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old female patient with multiple sclerosis presents with complaints of visual difficulties and headache. An ophthalmologic examination of the patient is given below. What is the most likely site of the lesion?

MLF - medial longitudinal fasciculus

PPRF - paramedian pontine reticular formation
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of internuclear ophthalmoplegia and the most likely site of the lesion is the right medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF). On the left gaze in the image, there is impaired adduction of the right eye and nystagmus on the abduction of the left eye. Hence, the lesion is in the right MLF.

Internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO) occurs due to a lesion in the MLF. INO is caused by demyelinating diseases (such as multiple sclerosis, and Guillian Barre syndrome), strokes, and tumors. In unilateral INO, the following features are seen:

  • Straight eyes on primary gaze
  • Defective adduction on the side of the lesion
  • Nystagmus of the contralateral eye on abduction
  • Normal gaze to the side of the lesion
 

Bilateral INO would present with a limitation of ipsilateral adduction and nystagmus of the contralateral eye for both sides.

When the gaze is initiated, the horizontal gaze center or the paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF) generates the eye movements. The PPRF has two outputs:

  • To the ipsilateral 6th cranial nerve nucleus - causes abduction of the ipsilateral eye
  • To the contralateral MLF which sends an impulse to the 3rd nerve nucleus- causes adduction of the contralateral eye

These two outputs from PPRF lead to conjugate movement of the eyes to the same side.

A PPRF lesion would lead to ipsilateral horizontal gaze palsy. The patient will not be able to look in the direction of the lesion.

questions.text: Which of the following effects indicate the stochastic effect of radiation seen in a person working in a diagnostic center and having an increased risk of radiation exposure?
questions.solution:
Heritable mutations are stochastic effects that occur as a result of radiation exposure.

The harmful effects of radiation may be classified into two general categories:

  • Stochastic effects
  • Nonstochastic or deterministic effects

Stochastic effects (chance or random effects): These effects of ionizing radiation are chance events. The probability of the effect increases with the dose. But the severity of the effect is independent of the dose received. There is no threshold. These effects are associated with damage to the DNA of cells.

Examples of stochastic effects include secondary malignancies and heritable mutations.

Non-stochastic/Deterministic effects (non-random effects): These effects are related directly to the absorbed radiation dose. The severity of the effect increases as the dose increases. A deterministic effect typically has a threshold below which the effect does not occur.

Examples of nonstochastic or deterministic effects include radiation-induced skin erythema, lens opacification, and transient decrease in sperm count.
